name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the discussion on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council meeting on 9 and 10 March, including the Rome declaration. Before the speakers' speeches, I want to thank on behalf of the European Parliament the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, the Italian Prime Minister, Paolo Gentiloni, and the Maltese Deputy Prime Minister, Louis Grech , for accepting the invitation to participate in this discussion on the future of Europe. First of all, I want to remind you that today the Netherlands go to the polls and no one can offend a democratic country that goes to elections, thus offending all European citizens and the values ​​in which we recognize ourselves. We are much more than a market and a currency and we must start again from here. For this reason today's discussion is particularly important: we cannot limit ourselves to a formal ceremony to remember what were the best 60 years in the history of free Europe and the anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome must be, first of all, an opportunity to bring Europe closer to its citizens. We must give concrete answers on unemployment, especially youth unemployment, terrorism and immigration, promoting our values ​​in the world. Parliament opened this debate with the approval of the Verhofstadt, Bresso-Brok, Berès-Böge reports in the last part-session in Strasbourg. Two weeks ago the Commission presented its White Paper and at the last European Council, the Heads of State and Government held a broad discussion on this issue. A solemn declaration is also expected to be signed in Rome on 25 March by the leaders of the European institutions. Today more than ever we need European unity: of course, the Union must be changed but not weakened.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, Prime Minister Gentiloni, deputy Prime Minister Grech, President Juncker, Members of the European Parliament, leaders met last Thursday for the March European Council, and, a day later, 27 leaders met to discuss the future of the European Union before the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome. Our discussions were constructive and focused, despite a little drama at the beginning. I will start with the European Council meeting itself. Following an implementation report from Prime Minister Muscat, we discussed the progress on our migration priorities as set down by leaders in the Malta Declaration of 3 February. Work has begun but now needs to accelerate in order to start delivering results ahead of what we know will be a challenging summer. Secondly, leaders discussed the prospects for the EU and euro area economies, together with the President of the European Central Bank. Things are getting better, and they are getting better in every Member State of the Union. This proves that our economic strategies are on the right track. Although unemployment is at its lowest level since 2009, leaders were clear on the need to get it down further, particularly in the most affected regions. Job creation will remain our priority. It is the best means to tackle inequality and social injustice. Leaders confirmed the EU’s position as the champion of open, rules-based free and fair trade. Trade is central to European economic success and as I mentioned several weeks ago, Europe needs to intensify trade talks with our partners around the world, not least due to signs of protectionism emerging elsewhere. We agreed to swiftly advance ongoing negotiations, such as with Japan, which are most advanced, with Mercosur and Mexico. Already next week we will discuss with President Juncker how to progress in our trade deal with Japan when we host Prime Minister Abe in Brussels. Our sincere hope is to finalise these talks this year. Leaders expressed their will to strengthen trade relations with China. At the same time, we will not hesitate to defend ourselves against unfair trading practices, wherever necessary. We welcome the European Parliament’s strong commitment to making quick progress on the relevant legislation. It will help Europe set the global standard for free and fair trade. In the evening, we discussed the tense situation in the Western Balkans. It was clear to all that forces inside and outside are working vigorously to destabilise the region. That is why leaders reaffirmed their unequivocal support for the Western Balkans, and its European perspective. We also expressed our full commitment to support EU-oriented reforms and ongoing projects. The European Union remains faithful to the promise of Thessaloniki and fully committed to the region’s stability and prosperity. I hope this positive signal from Europe will be heard. Leaders also reviewed progress made in the area of security and defence cooperation, where the European Council gave a new impetus last December as a strategic priority. Leaders agreed to come back to this again in June. Dear Members, on Friday, we met informally as 27 ahead of the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome. There was an honest and constructive discussion about our common future. It focused on what should be the main elements of the Rome Declaration and our agenda going forward. It was clear from the debate that the unity of the 27 will be our most precious asset. At our last meeting in Malta, subsequent opinions voiced by some Member States as well as the European Commission’s White Paper leave us in no doubt that the idea of a multi-speed Europe will be one of the discussions ahead of the Rome anniversary, and I understand the reasons for this. Some expect systemic changes that would loosen intra-EU ties and strengthen the role of nations in relation to the Community. Others, quite the opposite, are looking for new, deeper dimensions of integration, even if they would apply only to some Member States. Such a possibility is indeed foreseen in the Treaties currently in force. However, considering the interests of the community of 27 countries in the context of the upcoming Brexit negotiations as well as the long-term strategic interests of the EU, I will be urging everyone to strive towards maintaining political unity among the 27. This is why, when discussing the various scenarios for Europe, our main objective should be to strengthen mutual trust and unity among 27. After last week’s debate, I can openly say that all 27 leaders agree with this objective. It was a relatively optimistic discussion about our common future, with a positive approach from all sides, without any exception. As I said after the meeting itself, ‘If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together’. It is our collective intention to mark the 60th anniversary with the sense of celebration and sober reflection that it deserves. Jean-Claude and I continue to work closely with Prime Ministers Gentiloni and Muscat on this, and I want to thank them both for their efforts and dedication. Finally, on my re-appointment as President of the European Council, I have nothing further to say except to reiterate that I am really grateful for the trust that has been placed in me and absolutely determined to work with all Member States and institutions to make the EU better and more united. Dear Members, Brexit was not on our agenda last week, but let me share two remarks, given that this is our last meeting before the UK triggers Article 50. I will do everything in my power to make sure that the EU and the UK will be close friends in the future. Britain will be dearly missed as an EU Member State. At the same time, I would like to stress again that the EU’s door will always remain open for our British friends. When it comes to negotiations, we will have no choice but to start the withdrawal talks once the UK notifies. We are carefully preparing for these negotiations, in close consultation with Member States and the European Parliament. It is our wish to make this process constructive, and conducted in an orderly manner. However, the claims, increasingly taking the form of threats, that no agreement will be good for the UK, and bad for the EU, need to be addressed. I want to be clear that a ‘no deal scenario’ would be bad for everyone, but above all for the UK, because it would leave a number of issues unresolved. We will not be intimidated by threats, and I can assure you they simply will not work. Our goal is to have a smooth divorce and a good framework for the future, and it is good to know that Prime Minister Theresa May shares this view. There is one final thing I would like to say about the Netherlands, after what happened over the weekend. The Netherlands is Europe, and today I want to say that Europe is the Netherlands. A place of freedom and democracy. And for sure Rotterdam, the city of Erasmus, brutally destroyed by the Nazis, which today has a Mayor born in Morocco. If anyone sees fascism in Rotterdam, they are completely detached from reality.  (Applause) We all show solidarity with the Netherlands. Out of respect for our friends in the Netherlands, let me repeat this in Dutch. Nederland is Europa en Europa is Nederland, plaats van vrijheid en democratie. Zeker Rotterdam, stad van Erasmus, door de nazi’s kapotgeschoten, vandaag met een in Marokko geboren burgemeester. Dat heeft met fascisme niets te maken. We zijn allen solidair met Nederland. Yes, we are Europeans and we are proud. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: President Tusk, thank you, and my congratulations on your election for the second time as President of the European Council. Thank you also for your speech. I totally agree with you, as I said at the beginning of this plenary, on the situation in the Netherlands.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, my Dutch is better than yours, but I will not prove that now. I have a good passive understanding of Dutch, and when I speak Dutch it is better than that spoken by the President of the Council, but I recognise that he made a huge effort to address the Dutch nation. By the way, following your assessment, I was scandalised by what was said by Turkey about the Netherlands, Germany and others. I will never accept this comparison between the Nazis and governments now.  (Applause) My home country, Luxembourg, was occupied by the Nazis. Our people suffered. My father was forced into the German army, together with his three brothers. If you are drawing a comparison between that period and the present time, this is totally unacceptable. The one doing this is distancing himself from Europe, not trying to enter the European Union. The European Union is not joining Turkey. Turkey is joining the European Union.  (Applause) I would like to congratulate my good friend Donald on his re-election. (Applause) It was the first meeting the European Council had in its new building. I refer to this new building as the Tusk Tower. I prefer the Tusk Tower to the other one. I am happy that Donald has been re—elected because not only do we have excellent personal relations, but we also have good interinstitutional relations. I am very grateful for that. Things could have happened differently, because my first ambition was to become President of the European Council. Now you are there, I am here and it is excellent like that. I am the best President of the Commission in comparison to you, and you are a better President of the European Council in comparison to me, so everything is OK. (Murmurs) I am happy that I have woken up the extreme right of the Parliament.  Lors du Conseil européen de la semaine passée, nous avons eu un débat intense sur les Balkans occidentaux. Je voudrais dire ici, au nom de la Commission et au nom de la Haute Représentante, qui est aussi Vice-présidente de la Commission – donc une personnalité obligatoirement schizophrène – qu’en tant que Commission, nous voulons offrir aux pays des Balkans occidentaux, une perspective européenne non équivoque. Je sais que lorsque j’ai dit au début de notre mandat qu’il n’y aurait pas de nouvelles adhésions avant 2019, cette phrase a créé la confusion dans les Balkans. Or, nous continuons nos débats, nos négociations d’adhésion avec les pays des Balkans. C’est la région la plus compliquée d’Europe et nous devons apporter à nos relations avec les pays des Balkans occidentaux tous les soins requis. Les conclusions que nous avons adoptées à 27 – parce que la Pologne, pour des raisons inexplicables, n’a pas pu se joindre aux conclusions du Conseil européen –, disent très clairement quelles sont nos ambitions et nos intentions en ce qui concerne les Balkans occidentaux. Nous avons évoqué, entre nous, la situation économique de l’Union européenne et de la zone euro en particulier. Nous nous sommes félicités du fait que le chômage baisse, que la croissance augmente, que le taux d’emploi ne cesse d’augmenter, qu’il y a une création d’emplois tout à fait remarquable, mais cela ne devrait pas nous induire en erreur: l’Europe n’est pas sortie de la crise économique qui est la sienne. La crise sociale perdure et nous devons donc apporter à toutes ces questions gravitant autour du sujet économico-social, toute notre attention. Je voudrais que nous soyons prêts en avril, en tant que Commission, pour adopter nos propositions concernant la mise en place d’un pilier des droits sociaux. Au mois de novembre, en Suède, nous aurons tous ensemble un débat sur la poursuite de la politique sociale en Europe. Je veux dire par là, un meilleur «ameublement» de la dimension sociale insuffisamment «meublée» jusqu’à ce jour. Je voudrais qu’en novembre, nous puissions terminer ce débat. La raison pour laquelle la politique sociale n’a pas eu toute l’attention que certains d’entre vous auraient voulu qu’elle ait lors de la présentation du livre blanc, réside dans le fait qu’en matière de politique sociale, nous sommes sur le court terme, nous voulons mener à bon port le débat social au cours de cette année, alors que le livre blanc porte sur une durée plus longue puisqu’il vise, en termes d’accomplissement de nos ambitions, l’année 2025. Il ne faut donc pas lire le livre blanc comme prenant congé, et prenant de la distance, par rapport aux ambitions sociales de l’Europe. C’est pour tout de suite: l’Europe sociale ne peut plus attendre, il faut la faire maintenant et pas seulement en 2025. (Applaudissements) Je suis tout de même toujours impressionné que lorsqu’on fait des blagues, lorsqu’on attaque les autres, les applaudissements du Parlement sont nourris mais lorsqu’on parle de la politique sociale, vous êtes d’une timidité qui m’impressionne. (Applaudissements) Wir haben, Herr Präsident, anlässlich des Rates der letzten Woche auch über unsere Handelsbeziehungen mit anderen Teilen der Welt gesprochen. Ich möchte hier noch einmal zum Ausdruck bringen – ich, der ich kein free trader bin – passt nicht zu mir –, dass wir als Europäische Union unsere Chancen nützen müssen. Die Amerikaner gehen – so, wie es aussieht – auf Distanz zu multilateralen Handelsverträgen. Das ist bedauernswert, aber es ist eine Chance für uns, denn je mehr Menschen ich aus Asien, Afrika und von sonst woher empfange, umso deutlicher wird mir klar, dass andere in der Welt von uns erwarten, dass wir die Führung in internationalen Handelsfragen übernehmen. Das sollten wir auch tun! Die Welt wartet auf Europa, und wir müssen da sein, wenn die Welt auf uns wartet. Deshalb werden wir so schnell wie möglich – Donald hat dies erwähnt – mit Japan zum Abschluss der Freihandelsverhandlungen kommen. Nicht zu den Bedingungen, die uns nicht passen, sondern zu den Bedingungen, Wünschen, Herausforderungen, Bedürfnissen, die wir uns selbst geschrieben haben. Wir – Herr Tusk und ich – werden den japanischen Premierminister am 21. März, glaube ich, in Brüssel empfangen. Und wir werden dies so schnell wie nur irgendwie möglich in die richtige Richtung bewegen. Und ich hätte gerne – Ist Frau Malmström da? –, dass Frau Malmström sich vor Abschluss der Verhandlungen mit Japan noch einmal mit den Sozialpartnern zusammensetzt, weil ich strikt der Auffassung bin, dass wir nicht alleine – so aus Gottes Gewalt heraus – Handelsverträge abschließen können. Wir müssen auch mit anderen darüber reden: mit der Zivilgesellschaft, mit den Sozialpartnern und mit anderen. Zu Verteidigungsfragen sage ich nichts, weil Federica da führend ist. Only one sentence on defence: I think that the point the US is making is right. We have to take care of our own defence and we have to increase our defence budget. Mr Trump is not the first one to say this. Mr Trump is the fourth President of the United States I have had to deal with. George W Bush, Clinton and Obama were saying exactly the same, and we made a commitment. I think in Wales – which is part of Britain – we signed a commitment, and we have to respect that commitment, but I am strictly against this restricted concept of defence. International – planetary – stability is more than defence expenditure. Aid development, money for humanitarian action by our countries, is as important as military expenditure, and I would like to insist on that. Was das Weißbuch der Kommission anbelangt, haben wir – obwohl das nicht auf der Tagesordnung stand – uns damit beschäftigen müssen. Ich werde dazu nichts weiter sagen, als dass ich hier noch einmal wiederhole, dass es eine Verkürzung der Lektüre des Weißbuches ist, diese Lektüre ausschließlich auf das Europa der zwei oder mehreren Geschwindigkeiten zu begrenzen. Hätte Frau Merkel nicht in einer Pressekonferenz nach dem vormaligen Europäischen Rat davon gesprochen, dann hätte dies überhaupt nicht die Bedeutung gekriegt, die es gekriegt hat.  Ich möchte noch einmal deutlich machen: Es geht uns nicht darum, einen neuen Eisernen Vorhang zwischen Ost und West in Europa zu ziehen. Es geht uns darum, dass wir deutlich machen, dass, wenn nicht alle können oder wollen, wir in Sachen Vertiefung der Europäischen Integration nicht weitergehen können. Und im Übrigen, wenn Sie sich das mal im Detail ansehen: Dort, wo es bis jetzt verstärkte Zusammenarbeit gegeben hat, werden Sie unschwer feststellen können, dass in allen Fällen alle sogenannten neuen Mitgliedstaaten – ich mag diesen Ausdruck nicht – bei verstärkter Zusammenarbeit mitmachen, aber einige Gründungsmitglieder nicht mitmachen. Beispiel Europäische Staatsanwaltschaft: Wer macht nicht mit? Die Niederlande. Wer macht mit? Alle 2004 beigetretenen Mitgliedstaaten der Europäischen Union. Also diese Vorstellung, dass dies ein Entwurf wäre, um Europa wiederum in zwei Teile aufzuteilen, ist ein Vorwurf, der die Wirklichkeit nicht trifft. Ich wäre froh, wenn jetzt alle in Europa – Europaparlament, nationale Parlamente, whosoever – sich an dieser breit angelegten Debatte über die europäische Zukunft beteiligen würden. Die Kommission wollte nicht ein Diktat vorlegen. Wir wollten nicht sagen: So muss es sein, und so darf es nicht sein – obwohl ich das Szenario 2 hier im Parlament ausgeschlossen habe. Europa ist mehr als Binnenmarkt, als Macht, als Geld und als Warenaustausch! Europa ist zuvorderst das Europa der Menschen! Deshalb erhält dieses kleine Szenario, das nur einen europäischen Binnenmarkt vorsieht, nicht meine Zustimmung. Aber ich hätte gerne, dass wir alle diese Optionen diskutieren. Das sind nicht die Optionen der Kommission, das sind die Optionen, die sich zurzeit in der Debatte befinden. Und ich hätte gerne, dass wir uns bei dieser Debatte nicht ducken, sondern dass wir alle Elemente in Betracht ziehen, auch die Berichte, die das Europäische Parlament im letzten Monat angenommen hat.  Ich bedanke mich für die Aufmerksamkeit.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Italian Prime Minister. - Thank you Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the President of the European Parliament for this opportunity to address you ten days after the sixty anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome. I believe that it must first of all be an occasion to remind our public opinions, our fellow European citizens of the results that have been achieved in these sixty years: peace, freedom, the levels of social protection that, despite all the difficulties, we have achieved, the single market, a success story that has led to the definition of the European Union as a "quiet" superpower and, finally, the work we have done in the field of culture, values, sharing our common ways of life. Remembering these results serves, I believe, to reflect on the future. If we did not do the first thing we would be in difficulty in imagining the next years of the European Union and we must do so above all because we are aware that we are going through one of the difficult moments of the European construction, perhaps one of the most uncertain moments of these sixty years, which somehow the years preceding that signing of the treaties of Rome, in which there were difficulties, different attempts, but we lived in a world very, very far from today's. Today the difficulties come from the legitimate choice made on 23 June by a large European country to leave the Union, deriving from the fact that the effects of the economic crisis are not at all behind us and as well as from the difficulties we are encountering in finding a common response on migratory flows. These are difficulties that we must not underestimate: someone even spoke of the risk of a sort of "1989 upside down", in which Europe is characterized by rebuilding walls, while 27 years ago it was characterized by breaking down walls. It is a risk that we can and must prevent. Looking to the future, I believe whereas we are all aware that a fundamental contribution can come from the European Parliament; first of all a contribution to the discussion that has opened on the future of the Union. An important contribution to this reflection has been made through the Böge-Berès, Bresso-Brok and Verhofstadt reports, which goes somewhat in parallel with the work that Jean-Claude Juncker and the Commission have prepared with their White Paper and that we have much appreciated, because it is a useful tool to set up this discussion. But it is not only the contribution to reflection: it is the awareness that there is at least on the part of the Italian government, that only from a stronger democratic legitimacy can an answer to the difficulties of the European Union come. It could be said, in a sense, that the co-decision powers of the European Parliament were the most important achievement of these ten years after Lisbon and that in the next ten years the European Parliament, this House, can be one of the driving forces of the future of Europe. I hope that there is a common awareness on this part of all of us. The Rome Declaration wants to give a message in this context of trust in the Union and in its next ten years. The Italian government is in favor of the relaunch of the Union, of its integration: as always, the declaration will be the compromise between different needs, drives, aspirations, ambitions. But I believe that some choices need to be clearly and strongly indicated, and we discussed them first in Malta and then in Brussels a few days ago. First, to respond to the demand for growth, investment and jobs. If we do not come out of the crisis, if we do not reduce the levels of unemployment, especially among young people, in our Union and in particular in some countries, we will not have confidence in the future of the Union. Secondly, sharing the commitment for the security of our borders and for a common strategy to manage migratory flows. If the countries that they are at the forefront of managing migratory flows are left alone there will be no confidence in the future of the European Union. (Applause) Thirdly, to strengthen our role in the world, including through concrete steps towards a common defense - the President of the Commission has now spoken. If we give in to nationalisms, to the opposition between individual states, even in the European Union, there will be no confidence in the future of the Union. And finally, putting social Europe at the center, the protection of the weakest, dialogue with the social partners, as advocated by the rapporteur Maria João Rodrigues: if we leave the weakest behind, there will be no confidence in the future of the European Union . (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, these are principles on which we must work step by step: the conditions are not there today to make enormous institutional leaps forward, but we must get back on track now. A firm Europe is a Europe destined to turn back. Some progress can be made with enhanced cooperation, as provided for in the treaties. This, I want to say very clearly in the hall of the European Parliament, will never lead to a Europe of Serie A and a Europe of Serie B; it will never lead to a Europe of the small and a Europe of large countries; to an Eastern Europe and a Western Europe. But everyone has their own level of ambition; everyone can choose to participate - they can do it now and they can do it in the future - in forms of enhanced cooperation and everyone will be involved in the common project. Having said all this, Europe cannot stand still and has a duty towards its citizens to respond to the emergencies and challenges we face. More democracy, with citizens and their elected representatives at the center, is basically the strongest guarantee for this common project to go on over the next ten years. As Jean Monnet said: "We do not combine states, we unite men". For this we count on you and for this thank you.

name: Louis Grech
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – President Tajani, President Tusk, President Juncker, Prime Minister Gentiloni, dear Members, dear colleagues, as pointed out by previous speakers, the European Union is not about Brussels, it is not about Strasbourg, nor is it about the institutions to which many of us involved in today’s debate belong. The European Union is about its 500 million citizens and about their hopes, their fears and their aspirations.  Malta’s Presidency is taking place within the context of the major political and economic upheavals that we have witnessed in recent years, including Britain’s decision to leave. Brexit is an unfortunate reality, but we have to move on. We cannot allow Brexit, no matter how much it may be in the headlines and how complex and delicate an issue it is, to distract us from, and create wedges in, our central mission. Talk of an existential crisis has become the norm. Yes, we are living in times of extraordinary unpredictability and it would be a big mistake to underestimate the major setbacks and challenges, but it would be an even bigger mistake to fall into a negative mind-set and resign ourselves to doing nothing. The buck stops with us.  Never has there been a more important time for Member States and the institutions to remain united, never has there been such a crucial time for all of us to focus on the big picture and shut out potentially distracting, unnecessarily divisive issues. We must face up to the reality that Europeans’ horizons have shifted. Many feel disenfranchised or disillusioned. It is up to us to show why European added value can be tangibly translated into citizen added value. As Presidency, our overarching theme is reunion – a reunion which fosters a climate in which the Union can once again regain the trust and confidence in the European project and secure its strong and viable existence. At this critical moment, we have to avoid unnecessary divisions and internal strife, and we have deliberately steered the debate on Europe’s future in this direction. We must rethink our priorities, rethink what resources we put into various policies, and usher in reform where necessary.  Having said that, reform does not mean a whole redesign of Europe. We have the Commission’s White Paper, as well as a number of Parliament reports on Europe’s future. Some options, to me, seem to be more attractive than others and, who knows, there may be other options which have not yet been brought to the table. However, I also believe that, whichever way we eventually choose to go, it will not create first and second-class citizens or result in kneejerk reactions or quick-fix solutions which foster unnecessary tensions and distrust. This could pave the way for the eventual erosion of unity. Irrespective of whether Member States opt to drive in second, third or fourth gear, neutral is not an option. We must use as a basic platform the established principles: respect for human rights and dignity, freedom, equality and rule of law. These are the values that reflect the soul of the Union and form the core of any future Europe.  We – I think I should rephrase that – most of us believe in a future Europe that upholds the fundamental value of solidarity on issues like migration, and in a Europe that strives to guarantee the safety and security of its citizens. We believe in creating better conditions for growth, jobs and higher living standards through the Union’s single market. Current indicators show that we have, once again, started to register successes. We believe that the Union should be should be robustly positioned to shape and manage better globalisation, not merely react to it. A strong Europe is needed to bring about the right balance in a world order which is shifting.  We believe in a Europe that fights for a healthy environment, yet Europe will only be viable if it is socially responsible, equitable and just, and if it is significantly moulded from the bottom up, not from the top down. Make no mistake: Europe will only be credible if it delivers on its decisions. In Rome, Member States will reaffirm our commitment to a united Europe, but the declaration is not an end in itself: far from it. Any progress registered on the future of Europe must be followed up and translated into action. A coordinated action by the institutions is absolutely vital. Having spent almost nine years myself in this institution, I know how crucial and meaningful Parliament’s continuous role and participation is in this defining moment for the future shaping of the European project.  Colleagues, we need to draw on this momentum and galvanise and energise our forces to forge a stronger, better Union. We have a fragile balancing act to perform: a balance between flexibility, which is not so loose as to threaten the meaning of a real Union, and intransigent rigidity which would undermine the whole process of the European project. We believe that success belongs to those who can harness positive forces that unite rather than divide. We believe in a better Europe, our young people believe in a better Europe, and we believe that the Union has what it takes to move forward.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Thanks to Prime Minister Gentiloni for taking the time to come to the European Parliament and listen before the Rome celebrations. That is a very good sign of the partnership. But first I would like to congratulate Donald Tusk on his re-election. Two and a half years of excellent work are behind you. It was a time of merging and not of division. It was a time when you tried to show the ability to act and not to accept blockade. It was a strong two years in your presidency. We are therefore happy to be re-elected. Congratulations! Ladies and gentlemen! I will not comment on the first hour of the Council meeting on Thursday, because otherwise some Polish media might say again that the German would speak here at the lectern. That's why I don't want to give propaganda in Poland a present. I think the development is self-directed. And I would like to thank the socialists because President Hollande said in the European Council that he appreciates the work of Donald Tusk, that Muscat, as President of the Council, was also very, very much the management of Thursday's session did well. The socialists in the European Council have shown that now is not the time to practice party politics, but now is the time for us to stand together and defend the European idea together. Thanks for that! Today it is about the Council, but of course above all about the Future of Europe, the Rome Declaration. For us as the EPP Group, the first issue is the question of competencies. Yes, the ideas that Jean-Claude Juncker put forward are good. The openness of the debate is good, we are balanced and, to a certain extent, pragmatic. We see new areas of responsibility in some areas - defense and foreign policy - but there are many cases where we as the EPP Group also say: Europe has to withdraw more. Jean-Claude Juncker has already achieved a great deal in the detailed regulations that we as a European level withdraw and trust the nation states more. Finding the balance is an important task. But in all honesty, I think that is not necessarily the most central debate - it is an important debate, but not necessarily the most important. Because what is much more important is how we succeed in ensuring that the people in Europe finally perceive the European level - Strasbourg, Brussels - as a normal political level and not as an external force that tells them something that they have to suffer from, that they are supposed to have carried out and have no feeling of doing it. What is necessary for this? The first thing that is necessary for this: We have to take responsibility. I'll tie this to my own country: in the last few years, the German federal government has approved 148 legislative decisions in the European Council 140 times - and 140 times approved 148 decisions. But I rarely see a German minister who then explains why he agrees here in Berlin. That goes for Italy, that goes for the Czech Republic, that goes for France. Therefore: take responsibility! If we decide something in Europe, please explain it to the people at home too. The second: we must allow Europe to achieve success, not just here in the European Parliament when we sometimes give Sunday speeches - let's be honest with what we sometimes hear here. We need to talk at home about what we have achieved. Even the right-wing extremists, the right-wing populists that we have in our house, must see that Croatia and Slovenia, for example, have developed much better economically than Macedonia or Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is also the former Yugoslav region, in the last few years and decades since the fall of the Wall was. It's for everyone Obviously, the parts that are members of the European Union are today in a much better economic position than those that are not members of the European Union. Poland / Ukraine - that's obvious. That is why we should grant Europe these successes, which we have in common, and explain them to people in everyday life and not only record them nationally, which unfortunately is the case with God today. Of course, we also have to consider how Europe can become more assertive, how Europe reaches people in everyday life. That means that we also need a debate about the executive power of Europe. Since then there are not only Greek officials at the Greek border, but Frontex officials with the European symbol, there are many people in Greece who feel better protected than in earlier times. It is good that Europe has an independent presence there. Finally, I would like to say that Europe must also talk about borders. We are currently discussing the Western Balkans. My group fully supports the prospect of EU accession for these states. You belong to Europe, there is no question about that. But we are also discussing Turkey. I thank our leading presidents for expressing solidarity with the Netherlands. The Netherlands deserves the support of all of us, they deserve the support. But with regard to the Turkey question, we have to clarify now how things will go in the long term. Everyone can see that Turkey is moving away from Europe, whether we like it or not. And that's why we have to put the question of whether full membership is realistic after the referendum is over. My group wants us to develop a close partnership - in economic areas, on visas, on student exchanges - but we have to be honest that full membership for Turkey in the European Union is not a realistic position for the foreseeable future. And We should honestly say that to the European citizens.As I said, it is about more than just the question of the division of competencies between the European and national levels.It is more about emotions, about taking responsibility, about being honest.And that's where we want Rome to leave.Prime Minister, we wish you all the best!(Applause)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, best wishes to President Tusk. I thank President Juncker, Prime Minister Gentiloni and Deputy Prime Minister Grech for the important speeches they made. In particular, I thank Prime Minister Gentiloni for his strong recognition of the essential role of the European Parliament. I draw from your words the urgency of strong action to relaunch the European project and we socialists are there. If there is one thing we cannot afford in Rome, it is to speak in vain or to use rhetoric or slogans. President Tajani, you know you can count on the trust of our group: but if the final declaration of Rome is too weak, does not contain significant references to social Europe and to the governance of the eurozone, we will ask you not to sign it. We would have liked the whole of Parliament to be more involved in drafting this declaration, through an ad hoc resolution, even though it is true that there have been three important reports and resolutions in which we recognize ourselves. We socialists do not resign ourselves to the status quo. Populists are strong, not only when we don't know how to explain our successes; they are strong even when we appear weak or resigned. United and brave we can defeat them. The magic word of these days - it was also recalled today - is "speed". But a multi-speed Europe is not the panacea for all evils: it is a method, it is not the substance, nor the strategy. Gentiloni said wise things today. I recognize that this method has served Europe in the past because it is inadmissible for one Member State to veto it if others want to move forward: but it would still be a mistake to focus solely on speed. The problem of Europe today is not one, two, three, four speeds, but the direction of travel, the substance; let's agree on the direction: where do we want to go? What is the landing place? And I me I hope that all the Member States and all the pro-European political families will move in this direction and, if someone does not agree, it is his responsibility to call himself out and he cannot prevent the others from moving forward. If the direction is austerity, for example, we are going to crash. That is why the problem is the content, it is substance and not the method. First comes the substance, then the method. In Rome we have three major challenges to face. The first concerns the unity of Europe: our social and territorial cohesion. We need common social standards, better living conditions. This means a strong social pillar, a European investment strategy that creates jobs through the energy transition, the circular economy, digital connectivity for all. And to those who ask where we will find the resources to do these things, I reply that tax evasion steals billions of euros from European citizens every year. There are resources there, we must give them back to our citizens. The second major priority concerns collective defense and foreign borders. It is impossible to have a market without internal borders without sharing responsibility for managing the external borders and without having a European asylum system. The third priority concerns the projection of Europe into the world: while Trump isolates America and threatens the international order, while important countries - you said so and I fully agree with President Juncker's reaction - while Turkey is pushing towards an illiberal, authoritarian and personal dimension of power, Europe must be the reference point for those who believe in democracy and human rights. Dear President, the dream that animated the constituents sixty years ago has experienced alternating phases: peaks of enthusiasm and periods of stagnation or decline. It may seem strange but the more the European Union is threatened, the more I believe in Europe; the darker the times, the more I understand the meaning and the need for European integration.And I realized that only if we really believe in that project can we change and save it.Half sentences, compromises on words, shyness and ambiguities are no longer needed: in Rome everyone can freely choose the field in which they are located and then let's move on to change Europe and save the European project.

name: Raffaele Fitto
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Presidents Tusk, Juncker, Gentiloni, politicians are generally divided into two basic categories, those which come to light in one particular circumstance, namely when their recipes are contradicted by reality. Here comes the difference: there are politicians guided by reasonableness, who know how to humbly recognize their mistakes and try to change their recipes; and then there are the politicians obsessed with ideology, who instead think they can keep the recipes and change reality. Here, unfortunately, there is a risk of belonging to the second category. The boat sinks and the cruising speed is taken care of. And if someone points to the approaching iceberg they are told to shut up, because he is not an expert or he is not a pro-European. If there is a wave of rejection throughout Europe, some questions should be asked about the reasons for this phenomenon. Blaming the voters is never wise: rather, wondering about the inefficiency of the European Union might be more appropriate. The current European Union has shown that it does not know how to cope with emergencies of medium gravity, such as the case of Greece, nor emergencies of maximum gravity, such as the case of immigration, nor the ordinary challenge of exiting the economic crisis and returning to sustained and strong growth. But the Union has gone further: it has become too centralized and too distant from the citizens. The push towards a closer Union is not a hope for citizens to work together; it has become a dogma to justify the creation of a centralized state with less and less respect for the rights of its member states. But the cause, the origin, are always the wrong policies that unfortunately continue to be defended. For these reasons, on the occasion of the sixtieth anniversary of the signing of the Treaties, we recall some clear choices: the first, to promote a new process of true renegotiation, which invests all existing European rules and treaties and which concerns all Member States of the European Union; to exclude further transfers of sovereignty in favor of the current institutions of the European Union, even more so in the absence of democratic guarantees and full control by citizens; to say no to the prospect of a single European finance minister. Today Europe does not need a final cage but, on the contrary, of competition between different models and systems, so that the countries and territories capable of cutting taxes, spending and public debt, and therefore of promoting growth, are to be example and stimulus for others; promote a mechanism for strengthening national parliaments that allows joint action to question and propose Union policies. European hope and the great dream of the founders will not be saved by continuing on the wrong path of recent years, traveled at greater or lesser speed. You can go more or less quickly but unfortunately the direction remains wrong. Instead, we need a change in the sense of flexibility, of more open and transparent rules, of institutional geometries that are adequate to recognize diversity rather than aimed at imposing a forced and unnatural homogeneity. These are our proposals that we will strongly support. The choice is clear: on the one hand a weak and rhetorical celebration; on the other, a strong and credible celebration. We will support this second option because a real future for Europe and for our children can be played on this.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Tusk on his reappointment. Fortunately a right of veto no longer exists on the matter of the nomination of the President of the European Council. President Tusk, I would like to thank you very much for your strong condemnation of the provocation by President Erdoğan towards our Dutch friends. It is quite cynical that the man who wants to install an authoritarian system in Turkey is at the same time pointing the finger and using the term ‘fascism’ in relation to a number of countries in the European Union. It is quite cynical. It is also quite cynical that he has asked for freedom of speech for his ministers in our countries, while in the meantime there are European journalists in prison in Turkey. We have to make the case that a German journalist from Die Welt newspaper, Deniz Yücel, is still in prison, and I think the first thing that we have to do with all the European leaders is to call again for his release as soon as possible before President Erdoğan can ask to have freedom of speech in another country. I think we have to be realistic and I am in full agreement with what Manfred Weber has said. It is good that we are condemning everything that is happening in Turkey, but at a certain point, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council, let us be honest, let us freeze the accession negotiations now. That is the only serious action that we can take to condemn what Mr Erdoğan is doing at the moment. That is the only serious way to do it. When he comes back to reason – I don’t know when – then we can return to the negotiation table, but to negotiate at the moment with somebody who is using that language towards our democratic societies in Europe is unacceptable. I would like to thank Mr Gentiloni for being here as President of the Italian Council of Ministers. I will be in Rome on 25 March, but not in the beautiful Palazzo dei Conservatori at Campidoglio. I will be in another beautiful place in Rome, the Piazza di Spagna, because with the European Movement, with my friend Elmar Brok, with Jo Leinen of the European Federalists, with the Spinelli Group, and with the Stand Up for Europe movement, we will be gathering there, in the Piazza di Spagna, which is perhaps as beautiful as Campidoglio, because we want to recall, not the Europe we have got and that we had in the past, but in fact we want to prepare the Europe we will need in the future. The question about what kind of Europe we will need in the future has been there for weeks, months, and I should say, already for years. Do we need more Europe or do we need less Europe? Do we need more or less? I think it is a stupid question. In some cases and in some fields we need less Europe. We need less bureaucracy, we need less regulation, for example in our internal market. Maybe we will need less Commissioners in the future and a small European government. We need no regulation on toilet bowls, vacuum cleaners, bananas or cucumbers. There we need less Europe.  But at the same time we are all aware of the fact that we need more Europe on a number of other issues. We need a European border and coast guard to manage our borders and not to outsource this task to Erdoğan. For example, we need a European government for our single currency and a Minister of Finance and a Treasury, because a state can maybe exist without a currency, but a currency cannot exist without a state. That is the reality that we have to see. I think we need a European investigation and an intelligence capacity to fight against terrorism, not only depending on coordination between national authorities, and finally I think we also need a European defence community and a European army to stabilise our neighbourhood and to be capable of doing something in our neighbourhood. So the question is not whether we need less or we need more. We need less in some fields and we certainly need more in other fields. I hope that in Rome we will not produce hot air again because, let us be honest, Mr Tusk, we have had Valletta, we have had Bratislava, and now we are going to Rome. It is now time to start a process. We are not going to rewrite the Treaties in Rome 60 years later. That is not possible, but what we could do is start a process, finally, and not just make declarations, like the new declaration we are now preparing. My proposal – the proposal of the European Parliament – is to start an interinstitutional exercise with the three institutions together based on what we did with Mario Monti’s report, where we created a new blueprint for the future budget of the European Union. We did this together – the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament – and my request to you, Mr Tusk, is that, together with Prime Minister Gentiloni, you launch such a process in Rome. We are not going to wait for the outcome of all these elections in 2017 because there are going to be new elections in 2018 and 2019 in other countries. So, if you can do something, it is to launch that process. We know that Rome was the first republic, we know it was the first empire, we know it was the birthplace, with Florence, of the Renaissance, and we know it was the start of the European Union. Well, I hope that on the 25th it can also be city of the rebirth of the European Union.  (Applause)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, gentlemen Presidents of all the EU institutions who have gathered here today! The first thing I have to say is that the state of the European Union is also reflected in the fact that there is not a single woman among you. Maybe we should think about it again. That could also be a corresponding approach to the question: How should the European Union actually reinvent itself so that it really reflects the wishes, the demands, the hopes and also the expectations in something that unites us together, what unites us, what does not let us fall back again into a Europe, into a patchwork of nations? Mr President Tajani, last week at the COP, in the Conference of Presidents, you asked us to give you the mandate to co-sign the Rome Declaration - at a time when we, with the exception of a few, are not in the hand could still say whether this Rome Declaration will really give the signal that is needed. And so far I have my doubts that this Rome Declaration will actually be a signal of departure. Because then she would have to - and I would like to say to Mr Juncker, whom I hate to contradict, but again and again on this issue: we need a signal in this declaration that points to a social Europe. I understand, yes, when you say: we need immediate action. I support that too! Immediate measures for a social Europe - there are whole programs. Catalogs of measures are available. Thankfully, Parliament also adopted a report on the social pillar and made it clear what is necessary. But what you could do, for example - and I turn to the Presidents, to everyone gathered here: advertise among the Member States! Make a statement in Rome that, for example, the European Union accedes to the enlarged European Social Charter. That would be something. That would be a signal, a very first signal. And say at the same time: We are working on a social pillar. Your declaration, your promise, Mr. Juncker, will have a half-life. It ends in April. At the end of April, when you will submit the proposal on the social pillar. You say we want to come to an agreement by November. Yes, I hope so, because there is no time to lose, because that is the question that many people keep asking. And especially in connection with the Brexit discussion, this will be all the more serious if we don't finally ask ourselves the question and answer the cause. The reason why a large number of unemployed people, including precarious workers in Great Britain, opted for Brexit was also because they had the feeling that they are not getting the answers they need from the European Union, not the support they need, which they need. I would therefore like to say again: It is nice when 27 heads of state have agreed on the election of Mr Tusk as President of the European Council at the summit. That made it clear: There are ways to come to an agreement, but it is not enough for the heads of state to agree, for a brief moment. What we need is that the people, the people who live in our member countries, are united. And in that sense I always have the feeling: Please don't celebrate so much on the 60th anniversary! Take the 60th anniversary as an occasion to fight, to fight for a European Union in which we can all find ourselves, in which we feel good, in which we want to defend, because the living conditions for everyone - for all people within the European Union - will improve. Make sure that the Brexit discussion does not subsequently lead to the rights in particular of people living in the UK are massively injured by EU citizens in the UK. Make sure that the rights of people in the north of Ireland are not violated, that they are not cut off from the Republic of Ireland, that we do not have a new external border there. Let us fight for this together, but always with the aspect that it must be about rights, about enforceable rights for all citizens, for all people who also come to the European Union. And please also reconsider the Dublin regulations, which are planned because this - especially for the Member States of the European Union at the external borders - entails burdens that cannot be dealt with in this way and that will exacerbate their situation. Let's discuss this together. Let's change that. Let us change the European Union into a social, democratic union that is peaceful, then you will have us on your side.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Mr Tusk, you are a lucky man, because indeed Jarosław Kaczyński - your sworn enemy - wanted your head so badly that he managed to unite the 27 other heads of state and government, none of which - I mean none - wanted to give him this gift. You are therefore renewed in your functions. However, I must say that your first mandate did not impress us, because one wonders, faced with the unprecedented crisis facing the European Union, if you are the man for the job, if you have the leadership and the vision that will bring Europe out of the rut. To judge, I refer to the letter you wrote to the heads of state and government before the summit in Bratislava on September 13th. You seem to take the measure of the disenchantment of many Europeans with regard to European construction, citizens who - to quote you - want to know whether the political elites are capable of regaining control of events and processes that go beyond them, disorient and, at times, terrify them. As the first challenge, you cite the challenge of migration and you are right. There is cause for concern when we see that the causes of migration - whether tyrannies, wars, resource depletion or climate change - are not going to go away. And your answer is Fortress Europe, or how to hold off and push back those fleeing hell. On top of that, in your letter you call those who oppose this concept of Fortress Europe as "politically correct". Is it politically correct, Mr Tusk, to consider that it is not normal that Turkey, which is six times less populated than the European Union, twenty times less rich than the European Union, receives twice as many refugees than the European Union? Is it politically correct to denounce the imprisonment of asylum seekers by your friend Orbán's Hungary, without Europe saying anything, in defiance of international law? Is it politically correct to refuse that 2017 sees once again more people die in the Mediterranean after the 2016 record? Where are you, Mr Tusk, when the Member States have to be reminded of their humanitarian responsibility and respect for the law? The second challenge you face is terrorism, and again you are right. I find what you are saying very correct. When you say 'Member States need to cooperate much more, especially in the collection and use of intelligence', you are right. But you cannot ignore that a number of countries see widespread surveillance of our citizens as the one and only response to terrorism. You know that in a democracy there are at least two basic principles. The first is the separation of powers. It is the fact, in particular, that the judiciary must be able to control the executive. The second basic principle is the proportionality between the restrictions applied to the liberty of people and the objective pursued. However, these two principles are increasingly undermined in a number of our Member States, and this time I am going to quote France and Belgium, not always to quote the same ones. Where are you, Mr Tusk, to denounce these abuses in the Member States? The third challenge that you take up is that of globalization and, again, you are right, but I do not understand you anymore. Your speech is incomprehensible, because, once again - to quote you - you reaffirm that free trade and competition serve the interests of Europeans. When this free trade and competition weakens public services and our social security systems, when they level wages and working conditions down, when they destroy tax justice, tell me in whose interests this neoliberal globalization works. I'm telling you, the only Europeans to benefit from this are the owners of capital. The others foot the bill. Where are you, Mr Tusk, when, instead of encouraging this insane logic, you should remind heads of state and government that the ambition of the European Union is shared prosperity? Next week you will be in Rome to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the treaty. This meeting could legitimately be the celebration of 70 years of peace on this continent, with the exception of the former Yugoslavia. I think it’s something to remember and it’s a success. My grandparents went through two world wars, and I am fortunate not to have known those heartbreaks. But if you want this meeting to be the new starting point of European enthusiasm, the meeting in Rome must be the one where a change of course is initiated. We need a fairer Europe, which sets social minimums in all Member States and which organizes, not tax and social competition, but upward fiscal and social convergence. We need a Europe that puts the energy transition at the heart of its investment. Why? Of course, this is a climate imperative, everyone knows that, but we also know that it responds to social needs, to energy poverty, to health needs. More and more people are sick on our continent because of fossil fuels. This meets the economic imperative, because every year we pay hundreds of billions of euros outside of Europe to buy things that we burn, fossil fuels. It is, finally, a strategic imperative, because to whom do we pay these fossil fuels? First and foremost to Vladimir Putin, who is our third-party supplier. We finally need of a Europe which knows how to orient globalization towards social, fiscal, environmental and democratic convergence upwards.Mr. Tusk, I have just one question for you: will you be the man for this situation?Will you be the man who will rise to these challenges?

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Gentiloni, it is quite impressive to me to note that the guiding star of Europe today is the Prime Minister of yet another Italian government which does not arise from the electoral consultation of citizens. The legitimacy crisis that has hit Italy in recent years concerns the whole of Europe and we have seen it with Brexit; crisis that you have caused, the same ones who spoke at the summit last week of priorities for the new Europe and who are now frightened by the advance of populisms. There is talk of structural reforms but the reality is that they are devices to subject European countries to the diktats of those who do not have the faintest idea of ​​what it means to survive the crisis. There is talk of reforms to modernize European economies: but in reality there are Member States that are the lion's share and States that are their prey. We are ready to whip up any state that tries to breathe in the suffocating grip of the fiscal compact, but don't move a finger if the multinationals evade the tax authorities within Europe itself. And on the social side? With austerity we have left our citizens without work, the sick without drugs, the poor without social assistance. What will the recipe be for employment? Will you replicate the precarious and unprotected formulas that were used in Italy with the jobs act? What happened to the Commission's intentions on European citizenship income? But we also talk about immigration. It is no longer possible for one or two countries to become the refugee camp of Europe, but it is a duty that each one takes on its own responsibility. You say that it is necessary to prevent the phenomenon of landings: well, what does that mean? That we will once and for all stop participating in the wars that cause the surge in migratory flows? What kind of economic development do you have in mind, then? With what impact on the environment, health and climate? With what tools intends to achieve it?With the EFSI?The plan that winks at the banks, with financial engineering products that will create yet another speculative bubble, which has financed projects related to fossil fuels and finances industries such as Ilva that cause death?The truth is that a two-speed Europe already exists, President: we have it under our eyes in Greece and Portugal.There is a Europe of banks, multinationals, lobbies, and a Europe of citizens, of those who have lost their jobs and those who have no rights.In Rome we will propose to the citizens the "five-star book", the latest attempt to create a home that is the Europe of citizens.Are you going to give answers to the people out there, their problems and their needs?Stop building armored fortresses, similar to prisons, because otherwise we will either find ourselves having to face ghosts of the past or we will end up overwhelmed by the rubble of the mistakes made so far.

name: Matteo Salvini
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking to those outside this building, to those in the House, to those who follow us from home, not to those who govern this European Union because they are complicit, hypocritical, false, incapable or naive. You mumble about the threats of the Turkish leader Erdogan: at the moment we are giving him EUR ten and a half billion. If you have any pride and dignity, stop paying these billions of EUR to the Turkish regime. It is not possible to finance people who come to give us lessons in democracy in Europe, who say that there are entire countries in the hands of fascists and racists. But does it seem normal to you? Between one coffee and another, between one aperitif and another, can you suspend this river of public money that goes from the pockets of Italians and Europeans to finance the Turkish regime, yes or no? If you have time, you should also suspend the accession negotiations, which should never have started, because Turkey is not, will not be and will never be Europe, unless someone agrees to do business there. You can't do anything about immigration: record of deaths, record of landings. The euro is a disastrous currency: in fifteen years it has brought four million poor people to Italy, record unemployment and a public debt that has increased by € 800 billion. Someone is raving about removing the duties that protect Italian and European goods from unfair Chinese competition: either you are paid by others or you are crazy! You have renewed the economic sanctions against Russia, the only one that has had the courage to go and set foot in Syria to fight Islamic terrorism. If we had to wait for the European governments or the European Commission to fight ISIS, we would have sat here today, with burqa and machine gun, to give us lessons in democracy. But obviously that's okay with you. As for agriculture, not a word, not a word! You are flooding the market and the European tables and the stomachs of European children, Tunisian oil, Moroccan oranges, tomatoes that come from who knows where, kegs that come from China without any kind of control, rice from Cambodia, milk powder from Ukraine. I demand that the food, the sea and the land that the good Lord left to the European peoples before the arrival of this Commission that is devastating everything arrived. At the moment there are thousands of Italian workers in the streets in Rome against the Bolkestein directive, one of the directives that helps multinationals on workers' skin, such as the directive on banks, such as the directives on finance and trade. You are the bane of the European dream: you should be ashamed to go to Rome next week; you should shut yourself up at home and ask for forgiveness, because the European dream which is my dream, which is the dream I want to leave to my children, has been ruined by people like you. You have the dream of bankers, financiers, lobbyists, Freemasons and multinationals: take your hands off this Europe and leave it to European citizens. Good grappa, President Juncker!

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, as the European Union reaches another important milestone with the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, I want also to acknowledge another significant event in the United Kingdom. This week in our national Parliament legislation was finalised, paving the way for Brexit negotiations. Those who wish to delay and distract have been defeated. I am happy to align myself with the remarks made by our Prime Minister in the House of Commons, acknowledging that the triggering of Article 50 will be a defining moment for our nation as we work to forge a new relationship with Europe and embrace the challenges of a new role in the wider world.  As the European Union discusses its own future in Rome, it is clear that Brexit will be a reality. It is in the interests of all of us, in the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe, that we set aside our differences and work to make it a new and successful relationship, one of cooperation and partnership, in making our people more prosperous and secure.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Tusk on his renewed appointment. Dear Mr Tusk, I wish you the best of luck in your official business! And then I would also like to say thank you very much in your direction and in the direction of our honorable Commission President for his statements on Turkey. I do believe that our citizens expect a clear statement on Turkey. I can only say that a country like Turkey, which accuses Germany of Nazi methods, which describes the Dutch as fascists, which suspends or imprisons hundreds of thousands of police officers, civil servants, teachers, scientists, journalists, cannot please any country in the European Union. We have to position ourselves clearly there. A few months ago, the European Parliament demanded that the negotiations be frozen. It was also raised by my colleague: we clearly have to talk again about whether we can end the negotiations after all. We also need a bit more honesty in the debate. I come to the future of the European Union. I thank the President of the Commission for his presentation, for the White Paper on the future of the European Union. It is now our turn, and above all the Member States. And I would ask you too, Mr Tusk, to point out again what the initial reactions from the capitals were. You stated that you want to preserve political unity. Well, that's a matter of course for me now. So it might make sense to get more information from you. I don't want a superstate Europe. I don't want a Europe that is purely an economic region. I want a Europe that focuses on the tasks that we only have together in Europe to be able to solve.We have many of them - colleagues have mentioned it: common foreign and defense policy, common solution to the refugee situation, fight against terrorism, concluding international trade agreements, looking after Africa together - that is also an important concern.We have to take care of that, but otherwise also give the Member States the freedom to govern and shape the country politically as the countries and regions need it.That is my idea of Europe.I look forward to further discussions.I hope that on March 25th we will have a worthy memory of what many committed Europeans have built together over many decades for the future of their children and grandchildren.

name: Presidente. –
text: A large number of parliamentarians are registered to speak, which is why I will not be able to grant "blue card" questions during today's debate.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, beyond scenarios the European Union needs a clear choice. The clear choice should be to do much better together on the relevant priorities. Therefore, I believe that the real debate to be developed is on whether – and how – we should deliver on these relevant priorities, first of all providing our citizens with better working and living conditions. All working people in Europe should count on a clear contract with fundamental rights and full access to social protection. This is a central piece of the social pillar which must be included in the Rome Declaration. We also need to make sure that more investment and better jobs will be delivered with stronger means. That is why the Rome Declaration must include a full reform of the eurozone with the banking union and the fiscal capacity. We need to make sure that Europe remains a central pillar of the multilateral system and for international cooperation, but we also need to make sure that the next trade agreements will enforce our social and environmental standards. Most of all, the Rome Declaration needs to assert, 60 years later, the European Union as a powerful, political, economic, social and cultural entity, but most of all a democratic entity. That is why we need to fully involve European citizens and the European Parliament in defining this Rome Declaration. (Applause)

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: - Mister President! I am referring to a sentence in the communiqué, which Mr Tusk and Commission President Juncker also referred to, that unemployment in the euro zone is bad, but that it has improved because unemployment was lower in 2016 than in 2009. That is a blockage of reality. If you take Germany out of the numbers, it looks very different. Unemployment in Germany fell from 7.6% to 4.1%, and in the euro zone it rose from 10.2% to 12.2% between 2009 and 2012. That's the reality. And if we imagine what the European Central Bank's projections are for growth - 1.8% this year, 1.7% next year, 1.6% in 2019 - and if we then factor out the autonomous productivity gains, nothing changes unemployment in the distressed southern states. That's the reality. Why has unemployment decreased in our country? Quite simply: the foreign trade surplus of our country has increased from 1% to 9%. Our euro is undervalued, so exports are subsidized. In all other states, in the distressed southern states, the euro is overvalued. That is why the export is cut. Politics - I always hear it, Mr President - begins with looking at reality. I urge the House and also the presidents to open their eyes to reality!

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I will start with a very theoretical question. I think you can say in logical terms that if you are not able to solve the general problems then you are bound to bump into all the specific problems during the ride. I think this is what is going on in Europe at the moment. National law in Europe is usually structured in Kelsenian terms, meaning that when Hans Kelsen wrote about national law, he spoke about Stufenordnung : you have certain levels of law in every country. This level of law is actually then turned slightly upside down by the Treaty, because the Treaty follows a different logic, and this is the problem we are running into with every question and every discussion in this House. We need to be able to find compromises between the Kelsenian structure and the structure of the Treaty, and this is the challenge we actually have in front of us. I was the shadow rapporteur of the Berès and Böge report, and I can say that this problem was the problem we ran into every single day. It is the problem you are running into every single day in the Commission and in the Council. We have a tendency, which is even worse, to push the real questions over to the neighbour’s table and ask him to solve the problems, instead of dealing with it ourselves. We need to solve this problem in order to build a future Europe which functions and keeps itself together.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, war is a terrible thing, and my generation went to war over discrimination, inequality, lack of civil rights and the denial of human rights. The disastrous partition of Ireland divided people and communities, and there can be no going back to this. Hard or soft borders, the people living in border communities in Ireland will not stand for it, so frictionless or electronic borders do not reassure anyone. The damage that will be done to the peace process in Ireland is immeasurable. Any sort of border that will damage the Good Friday Agreement will tell people that the political process failed. My generation will do everything it can to make sure that the next generation never has to endure what we had to.  The EU has a political, legal, and moral duty to help us ensure that the next generation is not faced with hard borders or hardship. Therefore, the Council and the Commission, in their Brexit negotiations, must protect the people of Ireland – north, south, east and west – from this English Brexit madness.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I represent Scotland within this House, and the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome is somewhat bittersweet from our perspective. It is right that we should celebrate our common values, solidarity, cooperation, multilateralism, the acknowledgement that any problem that we face is bigger than any one country, however big, however small. But it is also right that we should reflect on just how fragile those values and that progress truly are. Trust me: the ingredients of Brexit exist in every one of our European countries. We cannot be complacent. I will also be in Rome next weekend, in my kilt, marching alongside you, working with you, to celebrate and defend our European values, because Scotland shares those European values – and those values must be defended. And Scotland faces the prospect of being removed from our family of nations, against our clearly-expressed democratic will. It is not fair, and if the EU is not a community of justice, law and democracy, what are we for? You will be aware, of course, that this week the government of Scotland has put the question of independence back on the table. We do that out of complete frustration at the intransigence of the UK Government. President Tusk, when you say that the EU will not be intimidated by threats from the London Government, I assure you, neither will Scotland. We will not be intimidated. We will not be silent within this process. We are citizens, not subjects. We will not be passive bystanders. Independence is one of many possible futures. I believe solutions can be found. We will look to our friends and our allies.

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by agreeing with virtually every other President in this Chamber – everyone seems to be a President – on the issue of Turkey. Turkey, under Erdoğan, is moving towards a theocracy akin to the Middle East. It has nothing in common with the democracies of Europe and therefore Turkey should never ever be allowed to join the European Union. I am also going to agree, for the first time, with Ms Merkel, when she spoke about a two-speed Europe coming down the line. It is true, there is going to be a two-speed Europe. There is going to be Britain with Brexit in the fast lane and all you guys going in reverse. I am going to speak quickly about the Treaty of Rome. Even though Britain was not an original signatory, it would be churlish of me not to accept that it was a noble and grand plan put together by men and women who had witnessed a Holocaust, who had witnessed Nazi occupation and the horrors of war. But they were men and women of their time, as it is a treaty of its time. Because to paraphrase the Scottish poet Robbie Burns, the best-laid plans of mice and men often go awry, and boy has this gone awry! Because what began as a noble economic plan has morphed into a political monster, egged on by successive Eurocrats, who are hungry for ever more power and determined to destroy the nation state.  What continues to amaze me is that you never learn. You talk about an existential crisis but you say what is needed is even more EU. You are fiddling whilst the Treaty of Rome burns. So what I will say is simply this: I urge caution when you are celebrating next week, because Brexit could trigger a floodgate whereby other countries leave that same Treaty you are celebrating next week.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: -  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! When we debate the current development of the European Union, and that in the light of the Treaty of Rome, it must be said that it was good to want to secure peace, freedom and prosperity in the long term. Only, at one point or another, it began to take a completely wrong turn. That was with Maastricht, that was with a wrong concept of the euro, that was with Lisbon and goes right up to current developments, where one tries to establish a banking union, an energy union and more and more centralism. It was the time when banks, as multinational corporations, as international companies, began here to take control of our continent at the expense of the citizens of Europe. Now we finally have various concept proposals for the future. One of them is to carry on as before - certainly a wrong concept. Just as it is wrong to go deeper into the mistakes of the past now. We have the concepts of an internal market, we have the concepts of different speeds and the deepening of cooperation in certain segments, where people want it and where it is democratically supported by the majority. I expect you to start the process of debating this as soon as possible. You are in default!

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, before the Treaty of Rome, as everyone knows, there was the Treaty of the European Coal and Steel Community, which is one of the three constitutive treaties of today's European Union . The result in my country is clear: there is no more coal, there is no more steel. Then there were the two Treaties of Rome, the Treaty providing for the European Atomic Energy Community, known as the “Euratom Treaty”.
