The result is clear today, there is no more atomic cooperation since Germany has decided to give up atomic energy. This treaty is therefore in practice obsolete. Then there was the famous treaty, the great Treaty of Rome, the common market, the agricultural common market in particular, which was to guarantee, with reasonable protection all around the Union, prices above the market and world prices for our farmers. The result is clear, in my country four out of five farms have disappeared and farmers are killing themselves every day. So, in the presence of such a failure, one would obviously have to think about it. Mr. Juncker has made an interesting thought process, with the five scenarios he offers. I would personally lean towards the fourth, that is to say to do less things, to make precise, quantified programs, on which citizens can put a cost / benefit balance. Unfortunately, Mr Juncker's scenarios are inserted into a framework of treaties which will not, in reality, really allow this development.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! I will not be surprised when I say that the last summit of the European Union will be remembered - with all due respect to all conclusions - primarily because the mandate of Donald Tusk as head of the European Council was extended. For this reason, it was also watched with great interest in many countries, and the decision was greeted with great relief. Not only because he was a Pole and it took place in special, completely special circumstances, but because stabilization, continuity, and the possibility of using the experience already gained in managing the European Council won, and these are the values ​​in today's European Union among many unknowns, many question marks . The Netherlands is answering one of these question marks today. I am pleased to announce that when I landed in Poland after the Brussels summit, I saw really happy Poles, and some of the symptoms of joy in Tusk's hometown, Gdańsk, were reminiscent of those moments when Robert Lewandowski scores for the Polish national team, because he does not only shoot always for Bayern Munich. What does that mean? This means that Donald Tusk as the head of the European Council has the support of not only twenty-seven countries, but the vast majority of Poles, which is reflected in the polls. Poland remains a normal country. As for the conclusions of the European Council, they obviously reflect today's challenges, but we all know that the future of the future of the European Union is determined by the nearest future, i.e. the 2017 election calendar, and these will be more important decisions than some documents of the Council or the European Commission. National elections, but with Europe in the background; a shared responsibility to convince Europeans that the response to fears, to the need for security, must be European.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, 60 years after the Treaty of Rome we have a European Union which is much larger, has made huge progress in integration, and has ensured peace, stability and growth on the European continent. Sixty years later, we must celebrate the incredible results we have managed to achieve, but we must knowledge that there is still a lot of work to be done. Ambition must be our driving force. Vision is what we need today in our Member States, and at European Union level. We need to know that without vision and commitment, without unity and solidarity, we give space to those who try to divide us, to promote nationalism and to endanger the European project. Unity and solidarity must always come first. I said that ambition must be our driving force, and it is true that this may result in some wanting to do more in some fields, as, in fact, is already the case, but our solidarity and unity [must] never be jeopardised. Any form of enhanced cooperation must guarantee that openness and transparency remain open to others who want to join, without obstacles of any kind. The entry criteria must remain unchanged, with no moving targets for those Member States who want to join at a later stage. Only with this in mind can we ensure the successful future of our Union. I hope that in Rome we will choose unity over division, and this should be our major project over the next years.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: - Honorable Presidents! If we think that with these scenarios for the future, we have found new strength in the vision of the future of the European Union and given citizens a great deal of confidence in the future and their neighbors worried that the European Union will be a global player. 1, then we politicians are wrong. Imagine, in the case of the 'Scenario for Europe' scenario chosen by the President of the European Commission, how many different nuclei of the European Union can be formed! The fathers of the founder plus Spain, the Nordic and Baltic countries, possibly the Balkans, Visegrad, no doubt. And what will determine the formation of these blocks? The formation of these blocs will be determined by the geopolitical interests of countries, which in turn can divide the existing European Union, even its cornerstone: the single market. About speeds. A great example is cycling. If the peleton or the whole group rides together and works with a change of leadership to keep up the pace, it will catch and overtake any small group. However, if the pellet is torn to pieces, then the result is unclear and the speed is generally much slower.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, three remarks: first of all, loudly and clearly, President Tusk, I congratulate you on the reappointment, I need to underline that this was not a dictate of Berlin, you had and have a strong majority support in Centre and Eastern Europe among others. I think you are doing a very good job in mending the fences that we have in Europe. Secondly, on Turkey: honestly I think the time has come to say we cannot pursue the negotiations – we should not be freezing them, we should stop the negotiations and come with a new partnership kind of agreement for Turkey. It will not fly immediately, but I think we have no other option, and I say that as a person that in 2004 was one of the very few Commissioners that supported opening the negotiations with Turkey. Thirdly, on the scenarios. I think that we should exclude immediately three: Europe as it stands today; secondly, internal market that is disintegration; and thirdly, federation, because the time is not right. We have two scenarios, but we do not have to discuss them, we should put on the table the concrete political issues on which we are to have a coherent approach, and then we will see what will fly with eventually a complete unity with multi-speed.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as I do not feel like celebrating, I can only say what I would like to see done on this anniversary.I would like the Union to recognize the mistakes made since the crisis began, to give top priority to social justice and a large new deal.Only in this way will it convince citizens who are increasingly disgusted by our institutions.I would like him to stop calling "populists" all those who feel disgust and fear by not getting real gear changes.I would like the Union to start thinking of itself as a land of immigration and to stop dumping issues on Africa that we are unable to resolve except with walls and prisons for refugees.It will seem a utopia: but let us not forget that the Union too was, in the middle of the war, a utopia of the few.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, dear Presidents, dear colleagues! First of all, I would like to congratulate the Commission on the White Paper that has been presented. The White Paper will help us move the debate on the future of Europe forward. It is correct that a path was not given there, but a space for discussion was opened. I would be delighted if the role of the citizens came even more to the fore in these options. In the context of the demonstrations for the Pulse of Europe, we see in how many cities there is European enthusiasm and how many people do not want to be ruined and ruined this Europe. We must strengthen their role in Europe, the participation of the citizens and their codecision, and that also belongs in these plans for the future. I would have liked a little more of that in the White Paper. I still have one specific matter to address that concerns the further deepening of Europe: while we are talking about various options, the German Federal Government is planning to set up a European Monetary Fund around the ESM as an intergovernmental form, so to speak, of closer cooperation between some of the countries. The stated goal is clear: this is to leave the European Commission, but also the European Parliament, out of the picture in the next steps towards deepening the eurozone, which we urgently need. I would therefore ask you, Mr Juncker: if you now present the further plans for realizing the Five Presidents 'Paper, please go beyond this Five Presidents' Paper and make your own proposal for a European Monetary Fund, the European one Democracy protects and does not leave more space for intergovernmentalism in Europe.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - I have 60 seconds to speak, one second for each year of the Treaty of Rome.So very briefly.Mr. J.-C.Juncker, Mr Tusk, it was certainly not a bad thing, it alone proves that we are 60 years old.True, if we don’t change anything, I’m not sure we’ll turn seventy.But still accept my congratulations.And, if you can, answer the citizens of the Union, I think, to the main and most important question today: how did it happen that politicians of that time, six decades ago, were able to solve really serious problems in Europe, and in the last few yearswhich have given rise to great social exclusion, terrorism, economic and demographic crises, unemployment and many, many more problems in Europe?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, do you actually ever feel like you are in a bit of a groundhog era – bit of a time warp – because every month I come in here, I certainly feel I do. Mr Juncker, you talk about Mrs Mogherini being a bit of a schizophrenic. I would agree, I think she is a schizophrenic because she is totally out of her depth. On trade: you talk about talking to civil society and trade unions. Let us just read lobbyists into that. If you do a deal in the City of London, you do a deal in Wall Street, it actually takes weeks and months, and that is where you are failing, because you have put a former sociology lecturer in charge of trade. So therefore, that is why TTIP and the other big deals have not happened. Mr Gentiloni, please do not delude the voters about peace in Europe: it was NATO that has kept peace in Europe and will continue to do so. This week, my Group proposed a debate on surveillance, and it was only actually Mr Lamberts that mentioned it. We asked for the CIA hacking to be on the agenda, but you had political ideologies – you actually voted against us having that on the agenda. What is more important than keeping our citizens safe? You failed to do that, and that is why this place will fail.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: - Mr President, in view of the 60 years of the European Union, today's debate on its leadership, in addition to monotonous jokes, signals one thing: Let the people expect worse. The Union is not and cannot be made of the peoples. Whoever claims it is cheating. It's capital, with convergence in exploitation, poverty, militarization, repression, wars, redrawing borders, refugees; . Either with a single deepening or with many speeds, with the states running towards the narrow core, a new anti-popular barbarism is imminent. In Greece, the Prime Minister of the SYRIZA-ANEL government, preparing a fourth memorandum, calls for new sacrifices, in order to find the Greek capital and not the people in the first gear. The popular discontent should not be trapped in one that in the other unpopular recipe. To pave the way for development for the benefit of the people, shaking off the shackles of the European Union and capitalist barbarism.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr Tusk, allow me first of all, on behalf of the French delegation of the PPE Group, to congratulate you and to greet your election as head of the Council. Some have tried to oppose it by using Europe as an adjustment variable for national political egoism, and that is precisely what the citizens no longer want. On the eve of the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, our European project is at a crossroads. The Council must fulfill the role which must be its own, that of harmonizing the position of the Member States in the service of a strong Europe and, above all, respected in the world. But this strong political will must be coherent. Yes, multi-speed Europe is a realistic project, unlike the à la carte Europe which, for example, the UK would have liked. Far from excluding or dividing, it is - I am convinced - the only solution so that the Member States which so wish can finally move forward in priority areas: security, border control, immigration, defense, union economic and monetary. Make no mistake, a lot of time has passed without political action from the Member States in favor of a Europe that protects and, above all, that wins. For my country, it is not Mr. Hollande who will bring this start. In 2012, to become president, he wanted to reorient Europe. For what result? No. He is now playing pro-European wise man, a few days before the end of a catastrophic mandate. Among the priorities defined by the Council last week, I will focus here on the fight against unfair competition. Defending the competitiveness of our companies is a fundamental issue and, faced with this challenge, a half-hearted response is not acceptable and will not be accepted by companies and their employees, who are the backbone of our economy. Dream merchants promise businesses and their employees a tomorrow that sing, thanks to the withdrawal into oneself.In the United States, Donald Trump favors unconscious protectionism.In China, a massive industrial development plan for 2025 is in preparation.No one will wait for our jump.It is up to us to act, to implement intelligent trade defense and to promote fair trade in our trade and international relations.Yes, the Union will be able to regain the confidence of citizens if courageous and realistic political will guides its action once again.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, Prime Minister, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, representatives of the European Commission! One would almost like to say to you: Yes, you made nice speeches, but please don't be so despondent. It's 2017, it's not the end of the century. Don't let the anti-Europeans talk you into timidity. Don't be fooled into thinking we have fin de siècle. Have a little more courage and look where colleagues have already spoken about it. Look at where thousands and thousands of people are demonstrating every weekend for this Europe and for their expectations of Europe. And let's take this seriously. We would like to say to Mr Juncker that, in his youthful career as Commission President, things have turned out a bit bad, but Europe has seen more Member States acting against the interests of their own people. None of this is new. But let's get involved with the boys. You have to say to them: You are not a lost generation - but not only say, also act. We need a youth guarantee that says to the people in Eastern Europe, in Southern Europe: We need you, we want your workforce, we want to see you in professional life. You have to tell the families: Yes, you can take a break, you can have children and then mother and father can go back to work. Make these legislative proposals and Europe will follow you! But it needs political leadership, no multiple choice and no excuses.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: - Mr President of Parliament,Mr President of the Commission!Mr. Chairman of the Council!I think today we need reflection without emotions.If the president of one of the countries that is an MEP a moment ago said that the EU may not live to its 70th anniversary, he is probably not the only one who thinks so.It would be wrong.However, the question arises whether the current structure of decision-making in the European Union is correct.Because if in strategic matters - such as energy policy, climate policy, immigration policy, also personnel issues - we will not return to what has been, which has guaranteed the success of European structures for years, to act by consensus, and we will vote each other for a moment.a majority, a temporary minority, then I think that we will not achieve success as a Union.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: - Mister President! In Rome we celebrate 60 years of the Treaty of Rome and look to the successes of the European Union. These successes are of course yesterday, but they are great successes: freedom, security and prosperity. The question is: what successes will Europe have tomorrow? I believe the central feature is the safeguarding of our freedom on our continent in a difficult international environment. We must be vigilant for this. We need a strong Europol - to be designed like a European FBI. We need a strong Frontex - really European, no longer intergovernmental. We need a common security and defense policy worthy of the name, and we need prosperity, economic growth. Economic growth so that young people in the southern countries have a future again. I would also like to say that to the five-digit people: The fact that there has been no productivity growth in Italy for 20 years is not the fault of the European Union, nor is it the fault of the euro. It has to do with the fact that the service markets, the labor markets, have not been liberalized. But we need economic growth, we need liberalized markets so that young people get a perspective and social cohesion can be ensured in aging societies. That is exactly what we need. And we have popular support, Pulse of Europe shows us this impressively. And if we also do Free Interrail, we get more support from the young people.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to begin my speech by reading some passages from the Ventotene Manifesto, which has been mentioned several times in our discussions here in Parliament on the future of the Union. "The European revolution, in order to respond to our needs, must be socialist, that is, it must aim at the emancipation of the working classes and the creation for them of more humane conditions of life". Here, this is the exact opposite of what will be celebrated in Rome. Today I also heard President Juncker talk about strengthening the social pillar of the Union. I would like to know what is meant by the "social pillar of the Union"? Certainly not, I hope, what the socialist governments of the European Union - the Italian government or the French government - have done with their labor reforms. I would like to know what is meant by a Europe founded on human rights, when agreements are made, such as the one with Turkey or the one with Libya. I would like to invite you, Mr President of the Council, to visit a CARA and to listen to the women talking about rape, illegal detention and torture at the levels of Libya. Finally, I would like to tell you that I think that in 2017 we cannot do, as you did, an all-male intervention, with a quote that ends entirely in the male. We criticize Trump but perhaps we should explain that the Italian government does not have an equal opportunities department. I will be in the streets on March 25 with those who want another possible Europe.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Mr President! Yes, at New Year's, President Juncker staggers on unsteady legs and gives one of his usual ineffective speeches. The best I can say to President Juncker is: You have a great sense of humor, and you are a decent person. But you are not a good leader or role model. To the newly elected chairman, Tusk, I would like to say: It was a better speech, but I mostly wonder what you are doing here. Not even your own Polish government wants to see you sitting on this post, so how can we have any confidence in you? The only reason you stay on this post is because you surround yourself with the right friends, who hold you by the back. It's not the elite in here that you should be friends with. You must be friends with the European people, because they are the ones you get paid to work for. Now you have a new period with an imaginary salary and benefits that an ordinary worker can only dream of. The non-existent contact with reality that is constantly displayed in this house will also mean that this whole project will fall to the ground.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: - The Treaty of Rome was a form of European cooperation that was acceptable.It was little institutionalized and the participants remained free member states, which, on a voluntary basis and without hindrance for the optimization of their own interest and national interest, established a link on very clearly defined bases and areas of cooperation: an added value.Since 1957, however, European cooperation has been systematically expanded and eventually completely got out of hand in terms of content and institution, roughly from the 1992 Maastricht Treaty onwards.the peoples of Europe under tutelage.The federal, "always-more-EU" logic must be broken.If the entire European Union is to be prevented from ending up in a collective exit scenario, new and sensible founding fathers will have to return to an intergovernmental system.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Europe today borders on the north with populism and on the south with refugees drowned in the sea, to the east with Putin's tanks, to the west with Trump's wall, in the past with war, in the future with brexit. Europe is today more alone than ever, but the citizens do not know it. Europe, however, is therefore the best solution, and we do not know how to explain it to the citizens. Globalization teaches us that Europe today is inevitable, the only alternative. But Brexit also teaches us that Europe is reversible, that you can walk back in history. Although outside of Europe it is very cold. Brexit is the most selfish decision that has been made since Winston Churchill saved Europe with the blood, sweat and tears of the English. Saying Brexit is the most unsupportive way to say goodbye. Europe is not a market, it is the will to live together. Leaving Europe is not leaving a market, it is leaving shared dreams. You can have a common market but, if you don't have common dreams, we have nothing. Europe is the peace that came after the disaster of war. Europe is forgiveness between the French and the Germans. Europe is the return to freedom of Greece, Spain and Portugal. Europe is the fall of the Berlin Wall. Europe is the end of communism. Europe is the welfare state, it is democracy. Europe is fundamental rights. Can we live without all that? Can we give up all that? Are we going to leave all that behind for a market? I hope that the next summit in Rome will speak less of what Europe owes us and will speak more of what we owe it after everything it has given us. The European Union is the only spring that our continent has experienced in its entire history. I am one of those, Mr Tusk, who, the day Prime Minister May announces Brexit, will begin to dream of the morning when the English return home.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - We can only discuss the common future of Europe with a clear position on what we want. We can reassure citizens with a strong message about a united Europe, for which we are ready to work together and which is ready for change. All discussions of laps and speeds lead away from this. Different directions of development have aroused fear in Slovenia, doubts as to where our small country will land. What does Poland's tactics against Council President Tusk tell us, or does the selective policy of some countries when it comes to solidarity with migrants? That we do not all want integration to the same extent. However, to divide Europe into East and West would be a fatal mistake for our future, for peace and stability, even for the tense situation in the Western Balkans. No insulation, no wall will solve the problems. We need solidarity, unity to create jobs, to fight crime more, to fight terrorism, to manage migration, and our long-term goal must be to reduce social inequality. My Europe is a common Europe, colleagues, this is our Europe, and this is the only way we must lead our thinking, work this way and give back security to the citizens, and I ask that you take this into account.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - Mr Tusk, thank you very much for your support for the Netherlands which you have just expressed in this sitting.Erdogan has had a number of ministers campaign abroad for his referendum, although Article 94 of the Turkish electoral law prohibits it.When my government banned two Turkish ministers from conducting a public campaign in Rotterdam, Erdogan scolded the Netherlands for fascists and Nazis, in Rotterdam, a city that was bombed by the Nazis in May 1940.I ask Mr Tusk and the Council to officially end accession negotiations with Turkey.Dictators do not belong in the European Union.And above all, stop pre-accession aid.They have already received more than 4 billion from the European Union.Madness!Stop the negotiations.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. president. Ladies and gentlemen, the Council is committed to continuity, not only because of the election of Donald Tusk, who is sadly known for the phrase "do not come to Europe", a phrase symbolizing the institutional xenophobic policies of a fortress Europe which, by the way, are electoral gasoline for the rise of the extreme right in Europe. Continuity by influencing cuts, even regressing towards a Europe at different speeds, widening the inequalities between the center and the periphery. In a few days it will be the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, an anniversary that finds a European Union in a deep crisis, where neoliberal and austerity policies are the main sabotage of the European project. Faced with the crisis, the European Union's commitment is to militarization with the European Defense Fund, which will only benefit the arms companies and their lobbies in Brussels. If we want to rescue the European project, we must radically change our policies. We can start, as the historian Perry Anderson said, by burning the Maastricht Treaty.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rooster did not crow twice after the White Paper on the future of the Union was published, and Europe has seen three times as many speeds. We first had four leaders who stole the start - the press called them "the big ones" and hurried to exemplify through a symbolic meeting that important decisions should be made in a small circle. The blockade between the Council and Poland followed. Finally, it was the decision to set up the European Public Prosecutor's Office, leaving out the countries that have reservations about this project. It is obvious that for the big ones the Union has become a mess. Citizens see the fence painted on the outside, but inside the law is done only by some. The so-called "big ones" turn the Union into a personal business and then point the finger at Eurosceptics. At this point, I note that the Europe of Nations and Freedom Group is the only one that has looked and takes seriously the project of a Europe, of equal nations in rights, which cooperates in terms of mutual respect for prosperity and peace. It is clear that, as of Friday, the stars on the Union flag are no longer placed in a circle.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a few days we will be celebrating sixty years since the signing of the Treaties of Rome and we are here to say that these celebrations must be the occasion to relaunch the European project. But if we want a strong Europe, if we want a great European project, we must equip ourselves with the tools that can give substance to all this. Europe was born to ensure well-being and solidarity for its citizens and today, in a world that has become smaller and smaller with globalization, we would need Europe more than ever to ensure well-being, growth and work. If we do not reduce unemployment, the Prime Minister Gentiloni said just now, there will be no confidence in the future. I say that if we do not reduce youth unemployment, we will have no future. The debate on the future of the European Union should be the debate of young people who today feel excluded, who are excluded today. The European average of youth unemployment is around 22%; in my country it reaches 40% but there are countries where it reaches 46 and 48%. It is certainly the greatest concern of our fellow citizens, a concern that in European families becomes anxiety, anguish. And immigration is also at the top of the list of European concerns. Today the Italian media are sounding the alarm: it is estimated that 250,000 migrants will land on the Italian coasts in 2017, 70,000 more than last year, which was a record year. So, dear President Tusk, your quote "if you want to go fast, go alone, if you want to go far, go together" is nice. But the anger that is felt growing in our communities can give way to hope only if the European Union manages to accelerate and give concrete answers. As the representative of the Council said, the Union is among its 500 million citizens. They must be at the center of our action and above all we must make them feel good center;then we could get back on the road, substitute anger for hope and build our future together.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr President Tusk, you have been reinforced in rather exceptional conditions as President of the European Council. This obliges you and must make you a driving force for the European Union, looking to the past, inspiring us from the founding fathers. Of course, your agenda is no longer that of the Founding Fathers, but all the same, let's learn from the mistakes of the past and look at how far we've come since the Founding Fathers delivered the talisman of the European Union to us. There is one thing that has hardly been discussed this morning and which surprises me, and that is the question of European sovereignty, political union, democracy, rights and values. This is what you are the guarantor of, along with President Juncker, and which must be strongly reaffirmed on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Rome. But beyond that, we will have to go into a little bit of detail to orient the debate, to help ensure that in the capitals where elections are going to be held, arbitrations are made to say what we want, how we want to respond to the white paper proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker and that cannot be the internal market, just the internal market. No one has ever dreamed of simply having an internal market. Likewise, in order to keep the euro alive, I no longer believe in the coordination of economic policies alone. It has been skating for fifteen years. It is time to move on to more integration in the service of citizens and the common project. So, Mr President Tusk, you are here as President of the European Council, in front of the European Parliament, do not forget that when you speak of the citizens that also supposes that this Parliament is at your side, perhaps, to draft this declaration from Rome.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: - The conclusions of the European Council are clear: jobs, security and migration, that is what Europe must focus on.But citizens are tired of hearing words and not seeing actions.If that's the focus, why are we spending less than 10 percent of our 2017 budget on security and migration?That is also what we see in the debate on the future of Europe.The plans are aimed at 2025, but we cannot wait that long.There, too, citizens expect action now and we can do that too: not replacing the 73 British MPs, a leaner budget now that the United Kingdom will no longer contribute and continue to work on closing our external borders.We are facing major challenges and they require action now.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, dear Commission! First of all, congratulations to Mr. Tusk! Everyone else did that too, but I want to do it too. This is a confirmation of the good work. Second: Many have said here how important Europe is to them, what principles we have and how valuable Europe is - everything is true. I'm just afraid that it won't be enough if we explain this out loud and often and constantly. We will have to prove that this Europe works, and that it works for the benefit of the citizens. I recommend just taking a look back. When we talk about the successes of the last 60 years, it means peace, freedom, prosperity. That has been said several times. But then we can please think about whether we are doing our job well enough when it comes to the question of “securing prosperity”. I don't think the answers have to be: more social services or assuming responsibilities where one is not responsible at all. I don't think the answer is unemployment insurance either. The answer has to be: design the conditions so that jobs are created. And that is the homework for the Commission, but also for us. What are we actually doing to secure jobs in Europe? What are we doing to secure industry in Europe? It is a pity that the President of the Commission is gone and so is the Commissioner responsible for Industry. I would like to know: What suggestions are there actually? How should the share of industry be expanded in Europe? I know an industrial commissioner from previous years. He once suggested that 20% should come from the industrial sector, and we decided that. Does anyone actually care? Are we making the conditions so favorable? Because when industry works, when growth works, jobs are created. If there are jobs, people are good, and you will credit the European project with that.That was a strong qualifier for us in the past.People also thought Europe was great because people are doing well here.And when they are doing well, when they have income, the state has income.If the state has income, one can also pay social benefits.The calculation is that simple.Why are people doing better in countries with strong economic power?Well, to cut a long story short: the Commission should now deliver something, not just on social union, but also on industrial policy.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Council, the Commission and others here who have mentioned the importance of celebrating the 60 years of the Treaty of Rome and the fact that we have had peace in Europe for a long time now. I do not think we should take that for granted. It is very important to understand and value freedom, democracy, human rights and our way of cooperating in Europe, where the rule of law is based on our cooperation with big and small states. But we also have to understand that many citizens, not only in Europe but also in the western world, now feel under pressure. We see it in the US where they elected Trump and we see it in Europe where our societies are challenged. We need to understand the root causes of this. The root cause is that the social contract in many of our societies is endangered. It is endangered by rising inequality, job insecurity and the fact that many of the ordinary people in the labour market are under pressure and there is a race to the bottom on working conditions. So we need a social Europe. We need to attack the root causes of the uncertainty we have in our societies. If we want to save Europe and our democracies, we need to understand that. I think that we also need to cooperate to stop the race to the bottom on tax evasion and tax dodging by big multinational corporations:  rich people, Panama papers, LuxLeaks, Swiss Leaks. We have all of these examples. We need to fight for our values, we need to fight to protect our welfare state, and we need Europe to master globalisation in the name of the people now, and we need that message too.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the leaders of the European Union are invited to Rome on 25 March to celebrate the EEC's 60th anniversary. They are called to a phase of crisis of legitimacy of the European Union itself, which instead of strengthening European solidarity has led to the economic gap between European North and European South. It has led to the division between Union Member States which are supposedly lenders and so-called debtors. Thus the Europe of states and peoples, the Europe of homelands, has now become a European Union of Lenders, a union in which states have lost their parity, a Union where so-called debtor states have been transformed into modern colonies. So this economic and political inequality in the context of German Europe is being institutionalized by the multi-speed Europe, which the leaders of the European Union want to ratify on March 25 in Rome. But the Greek people are not going to accept the transformation of Greece into a European colony, and in fact on March 25, that is, on the day of the national anniversary of the Greek Revolution of 1821.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: - Sur President, iva qegħdin niċċelebraw sittin sena ta ‘storja ta’ suċċess. Kellna sfidi, uħud minnhom ippreparati għalihom, oħrajn li ma konniex ippreparati għalihom. If the European Union is to be considered as an important, the valiant of human rights, the Union, the United Kingdom, the United States, the United States, the United States, the United States and the United States. Kellna Ewropa mibnija allura fuq dawn il-valuri illi l-poplu tagħna, issa Ewropew, qed jgħidilna hemm bżonn li intom tiggarantixxu dawn il-valuri, u huwa d-dover tagħna, kif qalet Berès, illi nagħmlu ħiliet mument biex nassiguraw illi ċ-ċittadini tagħna jkunu jistgħu jkollhom dawn id-drittijiet mingħajr ebda xkiel ta 'ħadd. The Government or the Government of the Republic of Latvia may, in the case of a Member State or a Member State of the Republic of Latvia, grant the Minister of State and the Government of the Republic of Latvia to the Republic of Latvia, -rule of law. I would like to say, I am the Minister, and I would like to say that I would like to see the people who were killed. Allura, jekk nagħmel u ngħid dak li qal il-President tal-Kummissjoni, li rridu Ewropa tan-nies, ejjew allura nisimgħu min-nies, u n-nies iriduna, iċ-ċittadini , the Kummissjoni biex nassiguraw li dawn il-valuri ma jiġux imċaħħda lill-poplu Ewropew stess.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Italian Council, we do not expect miracles or immediate rebirths from Rome but something, yes, something we expect. And as representatives of the peoples of Europe, we also think we deserve it. We want to hear from the Council, from the twenty-seven Member States, a leap of pride, a responsibility, because the future of Europeans is also in the hands of those who, starting from Rome, will have to decide whether to stop or move forward in the direction and not just of speed, which was evoked here, but above all of the ability to give effective answers, even with different formats, but always safeguarding the value of the political unity of the European Union. Then more democracy - the Spitzenkandidat - but also social and fiscal equity. We explicitly want a social union, not just a monetary one. But what sense of belonging do you think a monetary or banking union can generate among citizens? Social union is something more than a generic social dimension: it means that the citizenship of Europeans, their problems and their rights, are not only at the heart of the Union but are its very substance.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - In the debate on the future of the European Union, it is as if we are talking little about further enlargement. However, this issue is also of paramount importance for the stability of the Western Balkans. We cannot pretend to have forgotten our promises to these countries simply because some say it is not timely to talk about it now. We must maintain a realistic opportunity for enlargement, otherwise we will lose our credibility in these societies. Europe needs a success story and the integration of the Western Balkans can be one such success story. At the same time, it is important for the Union to offer a solution to reduce inter-ethnic tensions, and this is only possible if the violation of the rights of national minorities in the Member States is not left unsaid. In many European countries - EU Member States and candidate countries - it is important that the coexistence of different nationalities is an issue that affects the daily lives of citizens; 8% of the Union's population belongs to a traditional national minority. We can help integration in the Western Balkans if the EU sets an example in the field of minority protection. Today, March 15, we celebrate the 169th anniversary of the Hungarian Revolution and War of Independence of 1848–49. Once upon a time, young people gave their lives for freedom, equality and brotherhood. Europe has no other task today: to create freedom and not to ensure slavery, equality and not second and third citizenship. And solidarity, fraternity, means that the Western Balkans and national minorities are included. I am sorry, Mr President, I have not been any longer, but I have been constantly disturbed by speech here.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: - Chair, President Tusk, Viċi Prim Ministru Grech, iva għandna bżonn Ewropa tan-nies, Ewropa tan-nies politiċi li verament iħossu l-polz tan-nies. Politiċi li mhux ibiddlu l-prinċipji li jgħidu li jemmnu fihom skont kif jaqblilhom. Għaliex din l-Unjoni Ewropea għandha bżonn politika li verament tagħmel id-difference u tdirects l-isfidi li jiltaqgħu magħhom iċ-ċittadini fl-ibliet u l-villaġġi tagħna madwar l-Istati Members kollha kemm huma. U stat żgħir bħal Malta, li llum għandu l-Presidency, dan jifhmu tajjeb ħafna. Il-ħtieġa li l-Unjoni Ewropea titkellem il-lingwa tan-nies. Il-ħtieġa li nimbuttaw 'il quddiem l-aġenda soċjali, li ntellqu r-reformi soċjali li verament jagħmlu bidla fil-ħajja tal-familji tagħna, tal-ħaddiema tagħna, tal-anzjani, iż-żgħażagħna tag. Il-bżonn li naċċertaw futur ta ’paċi, ta’ prosperity, ta ’sustainability, ta’ kwalità ta ’ħajja aħjar għaċ-ċittadini tagħna. Neħtieġu initjattivi konkreti li jistgħu joffru soluzzjonijiet Ewropej għall-isfidi li għandhom iċ-ċittadini tagħna. U din hija l-Ewropa li rrid nara jiena. Ewropa li ma tinsiex lill-aktar vulnerabbli. Ewropa li taċċerta ruħha li żżid il-fiduċja li jħossu ċ-ċittadini meta jħarsu lejn l-Unjoni Ewropea li wara kollox mhijiex xi entizzjoni 'l bogħod minnhom imma huma l-pajjiżenta li jirrappreżenta.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr Prime Minister, Mr President of the Commission, first of all, I would naturally like to congratulate the President of Donald Tusk on his re-election, which I think is also a great sign for Europe, because it represents, precisely, this idea of ​​a more integrated, more united Europe, in which all members, from the north and the south, from the east and from the west, are committed to the European project. Secondly, I would essentially like to draw your attention to a point that has been dealt with in the Council and that is the point in the Western Balkans. I think that, at this moment, it is essential that the European Union reinforces its presence with the Balkan States, Bosnia and Herzegovina, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro, Albania and Kosovo, because, in fact, the situation it is extremely difficult, extremely harsh, where we are, in short, I would say, in an atmosphere of tension, that in some way anticipates conflicts, wars and major differences between the various states and within each state. Therefore, it is essential that the European Council and the Council, as a whole, the Commission, namely through the High Representative, but also through the President, and the European Parliament itself, reinforce their interaction with all these States and give a signal and a prospect that they may join the European Union in the near future.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr President Tusk, Mr President Gentiloni! The biggest enemy of the European Union is its half-heartedness and lack of clarity about the European idea. Almost no one explains to people what the added value of the European Union is and what we need the European Union for in the coming years. The EU is disappearing into the fog and people are losing interest and turning away. The founding fathers were indeed much more courageous. Well, Rome could be the point of a new departure. Parliament has done its homework, we have developed very clear ideas. The commission is already softer with five multiple choice scenarios. I hope that the Council in Rome does not become even more vague, but that it really indicates a direction in which we must go in the next few years. We created peace and freedom, but now we need to organize prosperity and security. Rome may not be the birth of a new European Union, but it is certainly the birth of a new European citizens' movement. All civil society will come and the March for Europe in Rome is bigger than it has ever been. The citizens are courageous - we now also need courageous politicians.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: - First of all, congratulations to President Tusk on his re-election. You have stated that you will strongly stand for solidarity, and it is our core value. I will highlight two aspects in the latest Council conclusions. First of all, the neighborhood policy. Security, stability and peace in neighboring countries are closely linked to our security and stability in Europe. That is why it is important, as the European Union, to maintain a leading active role. Two examples: the agreement with Algeria will allow us to deepen our strategic cooperation in order to overcome our common challenges and provide concrete answers. The Western Balkans are very important. We now need to show unity and consolidate unequivocal support for the region's European perspective. We need to increase the visibility of our actions through concrete initiatives and projects, not just through political declarations. The second aspect is related to migration. Reaching an agreement on the proposal for an entry and exit system by June 2017 is an essential element, but it is important not to allow security fragmentation by excluding from the scope of countries such as Bulgaria, which, although not part of Schengen, have a key important for safeguarding the security of the Union's external borders. Finally, the debate on the future of Europe has begun. Let's attract as many citizens as possible whose opinion is heard. An open and honest dialogue is the direction for counteracting populism and preserving our European project.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Mr President, yes, we talked about the future of Europe and we talked about a series of scenarios that the Commission presented to us. I want to start by saying that some of those scenarios shouldn't have even come up. They are an unacceptable reversal of the European project. There is talk, in Versailles, of a Europe of various speeds. I believe that we should speak of a flexible Europe, but I accept that there must be flexibility to build Europe. The problem is which Europe, as Mr Pittella said this morning, which Europe we want. And I want to emphasize that also among those of us who want to make a more integrated Europe we have a gap, an important difference in economic and social policy. There is a southern Europe that is suffering from the economic policy of recent years: a policy of excessive austerity and a policy without a social soul. And this policy that we have to carry out together has to respond to the demand from all of southern Europe for a European economic policy for jobs, for growth and for social justice. If not, there will be no common Europe.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: - Mr President!The Member States stated in the Council's conclusions last week that Europe's economic development must benefit everyone and that the November Social Summit in Gothenburg is welcomed.It is a step in the right direction, but then, as President, you must show that the European Parliament also demands a stronger social dimension for Europe's future.Therefore, I urge you not to sign the Rome Declaration unless it contains sufficient writings that prioritize fair working conditions, sustainable climate and energy policies and respect for human rights.It is these priorities that lead right - to security, justice and peace.A common defense union, on the other hand, cannot be the answer to all our challenges, just as the construction of high towers here in Brussels cannot be interpreted as meaning that we are close to our constituents and our citizens.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: - Mr President, no, the European dream of 1957 is not dead. Europe is emerging today, both as a necessity and as a challenge. Let’s build a European defense first. Next, let us continue to build an effective policy to fight terrorism, against cyberterrorism, a real scourge for us Europeans, but also for the Arab world. Finally, let us live up to the human dignity that must prevail in matters of migration. Our European dream, in 2017, is called "change of economic paradigm for new growth, fair exchange in our international agreements, tax fairness, social progress, fight against climate change through the development of a circular economy and energy. renewable ”. This is our challenge. This is our path. This is our dream. Rome was a start. On March 25, Rome will mark a new founding stage of the new Europe. It is up to us to fight the nationalists by renewing the hope of our founding fathers, Jean Monnet yesterday, Jacques Delors today.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: - The commemoration of 60 years in Rome is all about renewal.Which Europe do we want?We have to ask that question because the mutual divisions paralyze Europe.It can no longer be done like this.Europe is more than a market and a currency.It stands for freedom of democracy, equality for the rule of law and brotherhood of the welfare state.That is unique in the world and we can be proud of it.The EU, on the other hand, is not a country.It offers unprecedented opportunities, precisely to empower countries and citizens, for example by tackling tax avoidance and combating climate change.But the EU is not a country and it must also indicate and know its limitations.Several roads lead to Rome and the combination of more and less is interesting.With the current divisions, further cooperation between some countries is also interesting, precisely if they point the way to a new Europe.In any case, it is good to discuss which Europe we want.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, let me begin by congratulating Donald Tusk on his election. It is certainly an appreciation of his work at the helm of the Council, but it is also a signal. A strong signal at this time, which we need to make it clear that the Member States can agree, have been able to agree on his re-election, and I believe that they can also agree on the adoption of the declaration that the President presented to the Council. These are four objectives that I think meet the expectations of EU citizens well. I appreciate that this declaration is designed to unite the Member States and also to unite the citizens. The goal is a safe and reliable Europe, a prosperous Europe, a social Europe and a strong Europe in the world. These are general goals, but they are essential to preserve the legacy we have received here. Sixty years of peaceful Europe, recalled by Prime Minister Gentiloni, is indeed a great heritage and a great commitment. And thank you for working on it.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr President, President of the Council, last week thousands of Europeans demonstrated in European capitals under the slogan 'Pulse of Europe'. Ahead of the institutions, showing courage and commitment, with the will to rescue Europe. They do not want a decadent, or paralyzed Europe, much less a Europe that regresses. They want a Europe with more integration and less veto. And for that, political agreements are needed, such as that of Versailles, but reforms are also needed, and above all the will for a more social Europe with fiscal capacity, and with a clear message. We have a challenge for the immediate future, it is Brexit. It is necessary to say clearly what it means and what it costs to leave the common project. And put an end, too, with the hypocrisy of enlargement, which is a message not only for Turkey, but for all other candidates. It is essential to make the anniversary, the 60th anniversary of European construction, an occasion to say that we are responsible for rescuing Europe and standing up to the citizens who bring out our colors by demonstrating for it.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the European Council has recognized that stability in the Western Balkans has been called into question and that more attention needs to be paid to the region so that it does not once again be the scene of conflict and unwanted policies. I welcome such an approach, , if we are dishonest with the countries of the region, we will achieve the exact opposite effect. A similar thing happened with Turkey, to which we have long promised membership on which no consensus has ever been reached within the European Union. If we want to be honest and thorough relations with this region on solid foundations, we must not ignore that in one, now a member state of the Union, a defensive war was fought, and the aggressor was a country aspiring to membership in the European Union. I hope that the Commission and the Council will not turn a blind eye to the fact that this country has not fulfilled any of its promises, which makes it more than obvious that it does not want to adopt European values, does not want to carry out the necessary reforms and cannot become a member of the European Union. .

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. president.60 years of the European Union: nothing to celebrate.As long as the small and medium-sized farms continue to disappear;while artisanal and inshore fishing continue to be attacked;while thousands of people continue to lose their jobs;while thousands and thousands of young people cannot find a job and those who do have fewer rights than our generation;as long as there are still working poor;As long as our rights, which we have won over many years of struggle, continue to decline;as long as it is not capable of forcefully attacking sexist terrorism;as long as the public debt remains a business or the euro a blackmail to the people;as long as austerity policies continue to attack our public pensions, our education and our healthcare;There is nothing to celebrate.Change European policies if you really want the public to trust Europe.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - The European Union is both a political and an economic project, but it has burst in two directions.North-south during the economic crisis and east-west during the refugee crisis.The Schengen regime, foreign policy and, above all, the solidarity system and social Europe are at risk.Not just a white paper, five scenarios will be enough, but we need a new agreement, a new agreement on possible cooperation between European countries.A Europe of more speed or a Europe of more scenarios will, of course, not comply with the founding acts, the European Constitution.That is why we need a new European agreement, in the framework of which we must also listen to our citizens, the Europeans, if we think that they will trust us at all and if they will trust this joint project at all.We have been leaving them aside for too long, of course, so we also need their voice and, of course, their opinion and position.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how many beautiful speeches on a social, supportive and integrated Europe! How to make it, always a mystery. The EU today is a completely sclerotic system: the only form of economic coordination applied so far is called austerity; it has exacerbated the disparities and inequalities between the regions of Europe, adding its effects to those of the economic crisis. What have you done over the years? Did I just miss the social compact or maybe a Juncker plan to fight unemployment? But in reality a social clause already exists in the treaties, it already exists as a legal basis: what is missing, as always, is precisely the political will. President Juncker said earlier that when he talks about social policy, he notices the timidity of the House: of course! It is the shyness of shame, because everyone knows they are just words. In fact, not even one. And the President of the Council Gentiloni, who is no longer here - and it is not as if the difference is too much known - was previously concerned about citizens' confidence in the future of the EU. I think the question is wrong because, if you continue to leave the weakest behind, as you have done so far, there will be no future or even an EU to defend.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the debate on the White Paper is an acknowledgment of the complete failure of the European Union leadership to deal with the serious issues that concern the European citizen. Really, who would have expected, sixty years after the creation of the European Union, that Europe would have been divided, that instead of nationally independent and equal states, there would have been a German-occupied Europe? Who would have expected that a new Europe of two or more speeds would have been imposed and that European citizens would have been divided into first and second class citizens? Who would have thought that all the countries of Europe, and especially Greece and Italy, would have been flooded with millions of illegal immigrants threatening their existence? Finally, who would expect that, instead of the much-publicized solidarity, the Greek people for 7 consecutive years and who knows how many more would suffer for the sake of serving German policy? You have turned the European Union into a huge Titanic and in a few days you are getting ready to celebrate on it, ignoring the shipwreck that is happening with mathematical precision.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of President Juncker I would like to thank everyone for their remarks, and I will present my conclusions.  Firstly, the President and you mentioned the White Paper on the Future of Europe. The starting point for each scenario is that the 27 Member States move forward together as a union. If a Member State wants to integrate itself more with others it can already do so today, but nobody who has a willingness to go ahead will be left behind. Building a stronger Europe has been, and will be, an inclusive process.  Secondly, concerning the Western Balkans, the European perspective and enlargement of the European Union: when we prepared our country for EU membership, our people knew that everything we were doing we did for ourselves. All the reforms we made in Estonia were for ourselves, not for Brussels or anybody else, and this is my message also to candidate countries. Enlargement of the European Union is a question of conditionality. If candidate countries fulfil all the criteria, they will be welcome to the Union; if not, they have to try harder.  Thirdly, I would like to stress the economic dimension of the conclusions. In line with the joint declaration of the leaders of the institutions, the European Council stressed the importance of advancing all files related to the single market strategies by 2018. A digital single market will bring tangible benefits to citizens, such as the end of roaming surcharges and unjustified geo-blocking, allowing cross-border portability.  It is only with concrete action that we will create the EU of the future. I thank you all for your continued work and efforts, which will make this happen. I would also, of course, like to congratulate Donald Tusk on his re—election.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, firstly, thank you for your words of congratulations and support. It gives me the greatest satisfaction to hear them here in the European Parliament.  Secondly, I share the views of those who want us not to celebrate in Rome, but to set a clear course for the future. Rome will be one of the stages, not the grand finale, of this discussion. If this discussion is to be effective, there must be cooperation between States and between the institutions. I am declaring this unequivocally and with the deepest conviction.  Thirdly, the White Paper – and especially the multi-speed scenario as one of the forecasts – has sparked a lot of controversy, not only here in Parliament. But, at the same time, it has a sobering affect as a warning to those who have the weakening of the EU in mind. It is my hope that Rome will be a turning point in the reintegration of the Union. I am aware that not all politicians will be our allies, but, as paradoxical as it may sound, the majority of citizens of the countries governed by the Eurosceptics will be on our side.  Fourthly and lastly, Mr Lamberts has said that I owe my re-election mainly to the fact that Mr Kaczyński was against it and that his attack on me helped me. I can only say that I find it quite natural that in critical moments we can always count on our compatriots.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - The situation that the European project is going through is too critical for the European Commission, the European government, to limit itself to proposing in its long-awaited White Paper on the future of the EU a series of scenarios, some of which should not have been presented because they are an unacceptable reversal. Europe cannot once again be a single market and nothing more, without European citizenship, without common policies and without the territorial cohesion programs that have led countries like ours to the path of modernity, well-being and economic progress. It is essential to develop a social pillar in the EU that responds to the most urgent needs of citizens hit by the crisis - especially in southern Europe - that establishes a European minimum wage and a common ground for decent working conditions. We want to deepen the economic and monetary union, launch an expansionary policy and strengthen our fight against fraud and tax evasion. Perhaps, in the current context, the best solution to achieve our objectives is the one proposed a few days ago in Versailles, that of Europe at different speeds. A flexible Europe, yes, but with a social soul.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. - With my statement, I want to raise a point in this debate on the preparation of the Rome Declaration, which has been neglected and which, in my view, deserves more emphasis on the part of the European Union. As seen in the recent negotiation of the trade agreement with Canada (CETA), international trade, although not consensual among all European political families, has a majority acceptance by the countries of the European Union. It is even foreseen that the Rome Declaration includes a section that defends the European Union's affirmation in the world through an active policy to promote free and fair trade, building new partnerships that promote global stability and prosperity. The problem is that Latin America is ignored in the text of that declaration. We must seek to strengthen relations with Latin America, especially at a time when the region is undergoing transformations that make it not only more willing to establish partnership relations, but also more vulnerable to attempts by other actors to control it globally.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The celebrations for the sixty years of the Treaty of Rome are an important occasion to revive the European project and to focus on the priorities of the Europe we want, a united and strong Europe in foreign policy, a Europe with a defense common and capable of ensuring internal security; a Europe which promotes economic growth, investment and competitiveness, which strengthens economic and monetary union by developing the single market and which has a single fiscal policy; a Europe without internal borders that achieves an all-encompassing migration policy; a Europe with a social dimension that invests in young people, the only ones able to give back strength to the original project; an innovative Europe that invests in digital infrastructures, start-ups, collaborative economy and job growth I hope that European leaders do not miss this opportunity by sending a strong signal especially to young people. By investing in young people, we invest in the future of Europe, and Europe deserves the future that our founding fathers envisioned for us sixty years ago.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The most pressing problem of the European Union is the impoverishment of a large part of the citizens of its Member States, in some of them more violent and in others slower, but still noticeable. Many affected by this development blame the fall of barriers between nation-states and seek a "solution" to going back in time, turning to reactionary political choices and nationalist political forces. The Union can reduce Euroscepticism and Europhobia only if and as long as it strengthens its social face, with policies of redistribution from the rich to the poor and not the other way around, as is largely the case today in practice. To this end, the Union budget must be drastically increased and actions for sustainable development and equitable employment must be financed through it on a much larger scale than is currently the case. If the complacency and inaction of the various European leaders continue, then in the medium term the European edifice is in danger of collapsing, which will have dramatic consequences for all European societies.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: written.- I welcome the discussion in the individual Member States and civil society that the White Paper presented by Commission President Juncker has set in motion.We need an intense and focused debate on how we imagine Europe in the future.The White Paper provides the right basis here. We must use the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome as an opportunity to reintegrate people more into the EU and to continue working to respond to people's needs.I think “PulseOfEurope” is a great initiative and hopefully more people will participate in the next few months.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - In the particular historical moment we are experiencing, our Europe seems to be at the mercy of a profound identity crisis, reluctant to seize the opportunity for greater cohesion to face the countless global challenges, as well as oblivious to the extraordinary political, economic and which, sixty years after the foundation of its first foundations, it has managed to achieve and which we are preparing to celebrate. The sixtieth anniversary of the Treaties of Rome, therefore, must constitute the springboard for "relaunching" the tiring process of building our common home and, in this context, I believe that the "two speeds" tool or, to define it more correctly and above all more positive, than "enhanced cooperation", may be an effective solution for an enlarged Europe. Nonetheless, all this is true to the extent that, as President Gentiloni rightly reminded the MEPs gathered in plenary session, this instrument does not turn into the breakdown of Europe into "Serie A and Serie B" member states. The persistence of terrorism, the spread of Euroscepticism and populism, the emergence of new regional conflicts and the increase in migratory flows are in fact problems that Europe can solve effectively only by remaining united.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - This year we celebrate the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome. This occasion gives us another opportunity to reflect on the state of the EU and its future. We definitely need serious reforms. In the last few years, we have witnessed an unprecedented wave of migrants in the history of the EU, threatening our security. Europe has been the victim of brutal terrorist attacks in Paris, Brussels, Nice and Berlin. We must be able to protect our citizens. However, I do not see how this will happen with cumbersome and ineffective legislative proposals. Another such example is the Arms Acquisition Control Directive. Restricting the rights of our citizens to legally possess weapons will not stop terrorism, because the perpetrators of these horrific acts have not legally acquired these weapons. The last few cases have shown us that these people have managed to turn vehicles into their weapons and are becoming more and more inventive. We must be able to take action. Effective measures. The EU's approach so far has proved that it does not work. The liberal model of integration has failed. The EU and its leaders must stop closing their eyes. Urgent reforms are needed before it is too late.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - A sentence can sum up the conclusions of the European Council: little or nothing new, and, in what is new, more of the same or even worse. A clear bet on security and militaristic drift. They do not even bother to disguise the defense of the race against military spending. The discussion on growth and jobs, however, is postponed until November. The insistence on the battery of blackmail and imposition that we are well aware of, regarding the economic policy lines of the euro area and the associated recommendations. Fastidious repetition of the litany of the need for structural reforms, the deepening of the single market and the completion of the Banking Union. Old recipes that will not bring new results. The usual profession of faith in free trade treaties and the usual disregard for democracy and national sovereignty, when allowing CETA to enter into force before its ratification by the Member States. Not a word about the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework, whose sneaky approval is being prepared, in line with their interests as always. There is no propaganda that can hide the enormous and growing contradictions that the European Union is carrying around. The solution to overcome these contradictions, of course, lies beyond the scenarios envisaged in the European Commission's White Paper.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: written. - The situation that the European project is going through is too critical for the European Commission, the European government, to limit itself to proposing in its long-awaited White Paper on the future of the EU a series of scenarios, some of which should not have been presented because they are an unacceptable reversal. name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing.- Let's look at a date, that of March 25, which will rewind the film of a beautiful story: that of a united Europe, a Europe as guarantor of peace, of the Union dreamed of by the founders as a sharing of intentions, objectives, guarantees.But let it not be just a celebration, today is no longer the time.That Union is under attack, disheartened by the citizens and disavowed by some of its own states that favor nationalisms for electoral purposes.So, let 25 March and this declaration of Rome in which Parliament was unfortunately not called to participate, may be the real restart of the Union with a Europe that is more in keeping with the needs of citizens and the States themselves.The Europe of concreteness and no longer of dreams, a Union of welfare and cooperation that lives and does not survive, a social Union that guarantees each of its 500 million inhabitants rights, development, employment, stability.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: signed up.- Mr Presidents, Commissioner, I have taken part in the debate on the future of Europe in order to listen to the Presidents of the European institutions and to understand their vision.Unfortunately, the debates did not result in a clear and unified position for the Rome Declaration.I prefer many of what Mr. Tusk said.Mr. Juncker disappointed me again.Ladies and gentlemen of Europe, the EU is going through difficult times.Think of the approximately 500 million people when you make decisions!Do not divide Europe!I am pro-European, but I want a fair Europe.If we want the EU to stand still, we need unity.We need a single European space.Romanians, Poles, Bulgarians are European citizens as well as Germans, French, Italians.Think that you will go down in history as those who will strengthen a strong EU or as demolishers of the EU, depending on the decisions you make!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- All topics about the future of Europe must start from one simple fact: what is our goal, really?When we agree on the goal and what the future EU really should be, then it is much easier to determine the path to that goal!So, first we decide if we really want military, energy, digital, fiscal and other components of the future Union, and then we decide on the way to achieve it.The question of a multi-speed Europe is then an unnecessary question because we know where we are going.Until we know where we want to go, there will always be a diversion.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - At the last meeting of the European Council, it was finally decided that, partly due to the resistance of the Hungarian government, there will be no European Public Prosecutor's Office covering all Member States, and instead the Public Prosecutor's Office will be established only in cooperation with some Member States. By joining the EU, Hungary undertook to protect the EU's financial interests in the same way as its own. This has not been the case so far, but with the absence of the government, he has now made it clear that instead of detecting crimes, he is interested in committing them safely. This is a huge profit for the oligarchs around Fidesz, the companies that trick them into VAT fraud, because in this way they can still pursue their state-subsidized practices without more serious control. Although most Member States are listening to common sense, unfortunately, a prosecutor's office set up with enhanced cooperation is just as cancerous as tax competition: countries that do not cooperate with others are creating a loophole for circumventing the system. After that, European VAT fraud will be carried out through Hungary or Poland to a greater extent than before, instead of Germany and France. Step by step, Hungary is becoming a black hole in EU taxation. It is essential that, in the next long-term budget of the EU, subsidies be the borderline of the EPPO, as this is the only way to ensure that the commitment made in the Treaty is met. The Hungarian government will also submit to the EPPO's powers if it can only access European funds.
