name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - As an EU, our common future and interests include the common defense of our external borders and the convergence of our economies. But at the core of our interests are the basic rules of law based on the principles and values ​​of our culture. Starting with the Treaty of Rome 60 years ago, we have come a long way with achievements of which we are proud. But there were times when the EU did not live up to the circumstances. Indicatively, the recent UN Human Rights Report from July 2015 to December 2016 in the Kurdish provinces of Turkey records 30 cities affected by 2,000 deaths (some burned alive), while 350-500 thousand were displaced, 1,800 were displaced , in the city of Jisre, entire neighborhoods were destroyed and state terrorism was carried out under the guise of emergency, with torture and deprivation of children to the elderly. A crime against humanity was committed by the Erdogan regime without anyone being punished. When crime was on the rise, few MEPs informed with conferences, videos and photos against the official silence of the EU leadership. Today, with the ongoing crime of illegal occupation of European territory in Cyprus, with the siege of 18 Kurdish villages, the Customs Union with Turkey.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Recently, Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission, presented a five-course menu on how to proceed. From the disintegration of the EU into a free trade area, through a two-speed Europe to the image of a progressive federal Europe. DK supports the fifth solution, the creation of the United States of Europe. Viktor Orbán, Brexit and other disasters are good for Europe to be constantly renewed, integration deepened. The next stop is the United States of Europe, with a common foreign and economic policy, a common army. This is happening now, right here before our eyes. We can decide whether to join it. The United States of Europe would make us stronger, put us back on the world map, exploit the potential within us. We would live better and more secure in a united Europe. If we have a united Europe, we can overcome the by-product of globalization: social inequality. We will have the strength to put the market economy in the interests of everyone, not just the select few, to start growth. A united Europe means unity, not uniformity. This is not a danger to us, on the contrary. I believe that a united Europe best serves Hungary's interests.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. –  The future of Europe is today at stake. Council meetings are good if the Member States’ representatives understand the importance of their actions and of those meetings. European citizens and the media expect the Declaration of Rome to bring major change, to restore their trust in the European Union, and to produce a proposal that will improve the functioning of the EU system. A lot of people are unhappy about how Europe is working today. I am telling them that this is due to the people now running the EU, namely right wing parties together with  populists. We saw that in the votes for the European Parliament president. We need to democratise the European Union and we need a new plan and maybe a new concept. I am seeking a Europe closer to citizens, in which the European Commission is directly accountable for its actions to the people. Therefore I believe that the biggest and most important change we can make for the 2019 elections is to directly elect the Commission president.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written.- The celebration of the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome, is an opportunity to discuss how to shape the EU in the 21st century - the most important project in European history.The five possible scenarios recently presented in the EP by Commission President Juncker do not close the number of possible options, but represent a broad framework for future agreements.The atmosphere and direction of the debate will certainly be influenced by two important events that will also take place this March: the results of the parliamentary elections in the Netherlands and the expected activation of Article 50 TEU on the UK's exit from the EU.Croatia, as the youngest member, is least suited to the concept of "Europe of concentric circles", which would limit the benefits of membership.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: written. - In the last 20 years Europe has become the richest continent in the world. European integration has led to economic growth, stability and peace. Nonetheless, the Greece crisis, Brexit and the way we deal with refugees have shown that we in Europe are facing completely new challenges. People have lost their trust in the European Union and we urgently need to regain that trust. We agree: the EU is not flawless, but it is the best instrument that we currently have for overcoming the current challenges. Something has to change anyway. With the White Paper on the different scenarios for the future of the EU, the Commission has initiated a necessary debate. But now it is also time to tackle and find solutions: In the future, the EU must guarantee fair taxation and social justice. The workers' movement has always been an international movement. The opportunities that the EU gives us at international level to represent the interests of workers and employees are unique in history. It is important to preserve these possibilities! The companies have been operating internationally for a long time, and they will do the same without the EU. But precisely we need the European Union as a means of fighting for the interests of workers and employees.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - The situation that the European project is going through is too critical for the European Commission, the European government, to limit itself to proposing in its long-awaited White Paper on the future of the EU a series of scenarios, some of which should not have been presented because they are an unacceptable reversal. We want to deepen the economic and monetary union, launch an expansionary policy and strengthen our fight against fraud and tax evasion. Perhaps, in the current context, the best solution to achieve our objectives is the one proposed a few days ago in Versailles, that of Europe at different speeds. A flexible Europe, yes, but with a social soul.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. –  In the first 30 years of its existence, the EU achieved most of its aims, especially that of securing peace in Western Europe through economic integration. In its second 30 years, the EU went for enlargement and deepening. This has led to stagnation and semi-paralysis. The new structures of unity and control that were created have proven unable to cope with political, economic and demographic turmoil. Now, millions of people in the EU feel completely disconnected with – or hostile to – the European project. Their expectations of ever increasing security and wellbeing were undermined by austerity and by policies that fail to respond to their life priorities. Meanwhile, economic and social divergences within the Union have grown. The Rome declaration should recognise this reality, not simply recast the rhetoric that made sense in the first half of the Union’s existence to Europe’s present and future challenges. Internally, the European project has become a transfer union that follows the pulls and pushes of neoliberal guidelines. A new, huge political effort of consolidation must first be undertaken to correct the existing regional and national imbalances. Only then would the EU be able to regain the momentum of its first 30 years.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - Europe is at a crossroads and we must decide what to do next. Reform of the functioning of the European Union is not possible without the involvement of the general public, and I therefore welcome the fact that the European Commission has offered five possible scenarios for what our common future should look like. When deciding on its final form, we must always think first and foremost about the citizens and the common good. From the point of view of the interests of Slovakia and the entire Central European area, it would not be good if the scenario of a two-speed Europe prevailed. This model would exacerbate existing disparities and introduce new barriers in the internal market. A scenario which envisages de facto federalization would, in turn, bring joint decision-making to areas which fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States. For example, family policy, culture and education. We need an arrangement that allows us to focus on topics that bring concrete results to our people and companies. It is mainly digitization, energy and security. We have to deal with digitization in particular, because other parts of the world are gradually catching up with us. If we don't catch this train, the second one won't go. I see all five scenarios as stimuli for a discussion about where we want to see Slovakia and Europe in five or forty years during the celebrations of the centenary of the Treaties of Rome. Whatever or a combination of them comes true, Europe will only be strong if it is cohesive.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The approaching 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome (March 25, 1957) is the right time to reflect on the future of Europe. The European Union and its Member States are currently witnessing unprecedented challenges: Brexit, the refugee problem, the slowdown after the financial crisis, the demographic crisis, the lack of a competitive and well-functioning internal market, and above all the rapid growth of nationalist movements and the power of political parties that question the continued existence of European Union. Both the conclusions of the European Council and the Rome Declaration, which are currently under development, aim to show a way to resolve some of these problems. These documents clearly indicate the possibility of differentiating the pace of integration and establishing more intensive cooperation by groups of countries in some areas. However, it is important that some flexibility is only possible within the framework of the Treaties in force. At the same time, the so-called A two-speed union cannot exclude any country willing to join such cooperation later. I am concerned that a multi-speed union may result in the complete marginalization of some countries with little positive effect on the community as a whole. The Union of divisions and segregation of states into better and worse has never brought positive results, so I believe that instead of a multi-speed Union, the Union will develop with the support and participation of all its member states.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The crisis of the European capitalist integration process is inextricably linked, on the one hand, to the more general crisis of capitalism and, on the other hand, to the matrix characteristics and objectives of the process itself. At a time when sixty years have passed since the signing of the Treaty of Rome, the constitutive treaty of the European Economic Community (EEC) and the European Atomic Energy Community, the EEC / EU is today experiencing the most serious crisis of its existence. Due to its depth and persistence, this crisis means that, for the first time, the possibility of integration openly giving way to a disintegration is openly admitted - that the departure from the United Kingdom, called Brexit, will already be an expression. Contrary to what some strive to make believe, this crisis is not the result of cyclical factors. The deep roots of the crisis plunge into the (capitalist) nature of the integration process. Any leaps forward, without changing this matrix, will only deepen the crisis. What Europe and its people demand is no longer the same, it is rather a project of rupture with this EU, aiming at the construction of another model of development, a Europe of peoples of cooperation and development that respects the sovereignty of each State.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to warmly congratulate Donald Tusk on extending the mandate of the President of the European Council for a second term of two and a half years. The support he has been given shows a clearly positive assessment of his performance so far, despite some bizarre attempts to undermine this output. However, now it is necessary to focus on the problems that lie ahead. The Council welcomed the findings of the Foreign Affairs Council of 6 March as a positive step towards enhancing defense cooperation. A concept note on the creation of the EU Military Operations Command Staff was adopted, which will help to better coordinate the actions of EU countries under the CSDP. It also called for the creation of PESCO, i.e. permanent structured cooperation, which would be a platform for joint planning and military action by EU countries. Work has also started on the creation of a coordinated annual review of defense capabilities, which will help to better define gaps in the capabilities of the EU countries' armed forces and plan their closing. These actions are almost milestones compared to the state of defense cooperation a few years ago. We finally have something to talk about in this area. It is also important that the economic and commercial values ​​of the defense industry have finally been appreciated. I would also like to express my concern about the situation in the Western Balkans. I hope that the effort to integrate the Balkans closer to the EU will not be wasted.

name: President. –
text: In relation to the decision by several committees to enter into interinstitutional negotiations, pursuant to Rule 69c, paragraph 1, announced at the opening of the sitting on Monday, 13 March, I have received no request for a vote in Parliament. The committees may therefore start negotiations.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I have just returned from London, following an earlier meeting with the Somali Ambassador to the UK, who has highlighted the tragedy that is emerging across the Horn of Africa, all the way down to Kenya and through to Angola with this drought. Over two million animals have died, people are losing their lives, and I would urge colleagues from across the Groups in this Parliament to do what they can to highlight the tragedy which is growing across the Horn of Africa and encourage Member States to do all they can to support them.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - (The beginning of the intervention without a microphone.) ... and scandals related to false labels that do not reflect the content of the food we eat. So we don't know what we are eating or we are lying about what we are eating. This regulation, which we voted on, introduces inspections throughout the supply chain, from producer to consumer, including all intermediaries. These controls will take place at the Union's external borders when we import goods from third countries of the Union. In my opinion, we also need to go one step further and respond to cases where food produced or packaged even in the Member States contains false information on the labels on it and what is inside does not fit the description. We know very well that such things also happen between Member States: meat is imported from one country and the label is put in another country, as if it were produced there and so on. So, we need to regulate this situation in the future, in order to protect people's health.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, I voted in favor of this regulation because it is the proper completion of the work done on animal health standards.In that regulation we established a series of very important rules to avoid the recurrence of cases such as swine fever or avian flu and to intervene immediately on the outbreaks of diseases that affect both animals and humans.But the rules and without controls risk being useless.This is why the regulation we approve today closes the circle, completing a truly cutting-edge European standard system, ranging from breeding to marketing, passing through production and the food business is one of the richest and also the one that records the most fraud., frauds that are increasingly frequent and increasingly refined.The new rules approved today will give Member States more tools for effective inspections and controls, based on ex ante risk assessment.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - European citizens and their health and the right to make informed choices must be at the heart of European Union policies. This includes both food quality and food safety, as well as considerations related to the cultivation and distribution of GMOs, which the majority of Bulgarians and Europeans strongly oppose. In this context, I consider it humiliating the behavior of food producers who send food with poorer performance to consumers in Central and Eastern Europe. The European Union is a single market with the same obligations for all producers. Bad foods are reflected in poor public health. I strongly believe that Bulgaria should not wait, which is why I call on the BFSA to complete the analyzes as soon as possible so that it becomes clear who in Europe treats us as second-hand Europeans. A second quality food for Eastern Europeans is corporate racism. He must stop. That is why I supported this report. Bulgarians and Bulgaria deserve more.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, I too voted in favor of this dossier to give an organic arrangement to the fragmentary European legislation in force, to ensure the application of food and feed legislation, rules on animal health and welfare, of plants, as well as on plant protection products. After more than three years of parliamentary work, in first and second reading, and over ten trilogues, the European institutions deliver a broad and rigorous European legislation, capable of responding to the food safety demands of European consumers. Among the main innovations introduced, the risk-based approach to controls, the coverage of the entire food chain, the flexibility of controls, which will finally be able to adapt to new production models, new technologies and new risks, a better fight against fraudulent or deceptive practices and the protection of whistleblowers. The new framework will allow the European Union to have legislation in step with the times, allowing a better fight against the most sophisticated frauds.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - Europeans can already be proud today to enjoy very high quality and also the safest food in the whole world.However, I am glad that today we have adopted legislation that will ensure this quality and safety in the future and also improve.We need to be aware that today there is a whole range of diseases that threaten animals and humans, so this concern for safe food is constantly needed.On the other hand, there are also all sorts of frauds that need to be suppressed in the seedlings and prevented from happening with sufficient controls.Furthermore, clear food control is needed, because food is becoming increasingly mobile, that is, circulating within Europe, and more and more food is also being imported from other parts of the world.Another aspect that is very important lately is that in some Eastern European countries we are wondering whether we eat the same quality food as our colleagues in Western Europe.Therefore, it is necessary to make order in this area as well.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, in a digital age, the demand for wireless connectivity, modern technology, smartphones and future 5G devices is constantly growing.By 2020, we will have eight times more mobile internet traffic than today.This connectivity depends on radio spectrum, which is an essential but limited resource for wireless communication.Therefore, I support this report which practically increases the radio spectrum band, so that we have a harmonized and coordinated spectrum globally that can meet this wireless requirement.Its use will help broadband mobile communications and encourage innovative digital services in rural or peripheral areas, such as electronic and mobile health services, based on mobile phones, patient monitoring devices and other radio devices, such asand smart energy grids.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, I would like to underline that I voted in favor of this report which was very well prepared by my colleague Toia and which created the conditions for an absolutely balanced approach, an approach in a system, that of digital terrestrial, which gives the possibilityto 250 million people to be able to use and have information through a mass dissemination tool, such as television, but above all it created the conditions to be able to better defend the European audiovisual sector, which represent an extraordinary cultural heritage thatI believe, especially at a time when new media is spreading, it needs to be protected for what it represents for our Europe and for what it represents for our cultural roots, which must be safeguarded in an increasingly globalized world.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, today I voted in favor of the decision on the use of the 700 MHz frequency band in Europe, which obliges Member States to make spectrum usage rights for electronic communications services marketable. The availability of a broad radio spectrum will allow the development of new innovative digital services in urban and rural or isolated areas, substantially contributing to reducing the gap in the quality of digital infrastructures. I am thinking of the importance of e-health services, such as supporting cell phones and patient monitoring devices, as well as smart energy grids and the Internet of Things revolution. The so-called industry 4.0 linked to fast networks and the reduction of the digital literacy gap is the field in which Europe must invest its best energies, responding to the ambitions of young Europeans and directing technological progress to spreading its economic advantages. and social.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, today I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution to underline a basic requirement for non-discriminatory road tolls, which is that all users pay the same rate to use the same roads. I think that any national road toll system that discriminates directly on the basis of nationality or that is combined with national tax measures for the exclusive benefit of the citizens of a country, for example a deduction of the national car tax, thereby pursuing the goal of charging the main burden on foreign users constitutes a violation of the principle of non-discrimination enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore think it is right to open an infringement procedure by the European Commission against Germany for discrimination against foreign users. I urge the Commission to review the Eurovignette legislation and reiterate the need to harmonize the sector through the European electronic toll service, which would make it possible to pay tolls across the Union with a single system.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - This year we are celebrating the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome and we are talking about an equal Europe in which we all have equal rights, including a united Europe.Motorways are certainly something very important, that we are more mobile and I as a Slovene have always been surprised that we can drive on German motorways for free, that is, without paying tolls.I was also surprised by the proposal made by the German government, which would be discriminatory towards those who come from elsewhere through Germany, as, after all, only foreigners would pay tolls in Germany.That is why I support this resolution, which was adopted, because it prevents this discrimination.Similar discrimination also occurs with our hauliers when traveling through Austria.The same is happening with the services they provide abroad, so we will have to be very careful in the future not to discriminate against Europeans.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. President. I voted against the guidelines for the budget of the European Union because its neoliberal line is the cause of the crisis of the current European project. Take, for example, agricultural policies. For years, the objective of the CAP was to guarantee a fair remuneration to farmers, a sustainable development of the countryside and the food sovereignty of Europeans. With the new CAP, farmers are forced to abandon their professions because the aid is insufficient and inadequate and they force them to produce for a volatile market, at the mercy of the large distributors and marketers. Market orientation perverts the use of public funds. We need a greater role for public administrations and representatives of workers and peasants in the definition of investment programs, and we need a budget that matches its ambitions, capable of redistributing resources between the center and the periphery of Europe.

name: Die Präsidentin.
text: - That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on a topical issue relating to the EU's security agenda a year after the attacks in Brussels (2017/2605 (RSP)).Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues!Historic hour is perhaps too much said, but for the first time we have a new format after the amendment of the Rules of Procedure, namely this debate on a topical subject.The political groups have agreed on a list of speakers and have also agreed that there will be no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that no blue cards will be accepted.We start with Mrs Metsola, speaking for the Group of the European People's Party, which requested this debate.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I was at a meeting in the European Parliament in my colleague Alain Lamassoure’s office when the bombs went off in Brussels almost one year ago. Anyone who, like many of us here, thinks of Brussels as a home from home, will never forget the moments of panic, of anger, of helplessness and of grief for the victims of those attacks. But since the horrific events of last year, our shock has given way to a grim resolve to counter this terrorist threat and to address both the immediate danger of more attacks and the causes of radicalisation that plague our societies. Nothing is more important to our citizens than the basic right for them to feel safe doing the things that they have always done and living the lives that they choose. Freedom and security are not simple buzzwords that look good on our Twitter feed or in press releases. They are the very core concepts that underpin our way of life, because without them, there can be nothing else. We must do everything we can to keep Europe safe. We can look to the citizens we represent and we can be proud of the work we have done so far to boost the fight against terrorism. But it must continue. And that is why it is so important for the EPP that we are having this debate today. Keeping Europe safer is at the top of our agenda and will remain there. Now in this Parliament we have worked hard to speed up efforts on common EU rules on better information about passengers travelling from and to the EU with our PNR system. We have introduced systematic checks at our external borders. We have pushed forward strategies against radicalisation, against those who preach hate and incite terror. We have gone after the money and tackled terrorism financing and, crucially, we have moved forward towards better support for the victims of terrorism. Terrorism leaves so many hidden victims that its mark stains for generations. We have to give those people a voice, support to return to life, and we have to remember those we have lost. We have done a lot, but there is much, much more that needs to be done if we are to continue to address people’s security concerns in Europe. We will not cease in our efforts until we secure a Europe that is safer. Information-sharing between Member States must be improved and we have to ensure that our law enforcement agencies have all the tools and the resources that they need to respond and to remain one step ahead of the terrorists and their networks. Our IT systems must be able to operate in tandem with each other, and we need to look at what law enforcement controls need improving.  Prevention and prosecution of criminal behaviour must be made more efficient by having a fully-functioning EU criminal record system in place, and at the same time it is essential that we have a coordinated approach to stop the trafficking of illegal arms so often used by terrorists during terrorist attacks in Europe. We need to improve our use of biometric data. The loopholes that were exposed by the Berlin attacker, for example, who had 14 different identities, must be closed.  The EU is not alone in its fight, because terrorism is a global threat that requires a global response. Cooperation with third countries in listing and implementing anti-terror measures needs to remain on the EU’s agenda, and I am convinced that we will get there. But it is true that apprehension remains. My children still get scared when they realise that we still need soldiers outside many public events, and it is true that every time we hear a police siren, a part of us goes back to that fateful day a year ago. But the people of Europe will not cower. Our way of life will go on despite the fear that we must all sometimes feel.   I shall conclude. When our continent came under attack we did not shy away from the challenge. We identified where we need to do more. We stood up and we gave a European response. Our fear did not define us: determination did, and it will continue to do so. (Applause)

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, in a week’s time we will be commemorating the first anniversary of the Brussels attacks – on 22 March – which are still so vivid in our memories. Let me start by saying that I agree with you that it is time to take stock of where we are one year after these attacks in terms of security, and I welcome this debate. We have made major progress in the last two years, but we continue to face unprecedented challenges. The European Day of Remembrance of Victims of Terrorism on 11 March – last Saturday – was an important reminder of why it matters so much to continue our efforts. All citizens have the right to live free from fear, whatever their opinions or beliefs. Putting in place measures to prevent and fight terrorism whilst maintaining an open and free society is a delicate balance. While stepping up our counter—terrorism tools, we should preserve our values and fundamental rights. Looking back at where we were before 2015, I think we can safely say that we have come a long way. Together we have adopted a number of legislative instruments and other measures to prevent and fight terrorism. In 2016 together we successfully concluded the negotiations on the Directive on Combating Terrorism within a very tight schedule so that it could be signed today. One of the keys to ensuring the security of our union is better information exchange and better information management. We are therefore working hard to implement the 2016 roadmap on information exchange and information management containing 50 actions for improving information exchange. The high—level expert group on information systems and interoperability set up by the Commission last year is equally important. We are confident that these efforts contribute to enhancing trust amongst Member States and Europol and to increasing information exchange. The figures are quite promising, for example regarding Europol’s databases. The content of the Europol information system increased by 34% between 2016 and 2017 and the number of data on foreign fighters increased by 11%. A record number of 1.4 million searches were performed in the Europol information system in 2016, an increase of 127%. The use of Secure Information Exchange Network Application (SIENA) messaging, which was upgraded to the level ‘EU Confidential’ in 2016 and now better suits the needs of intelligence services, has also increased by 19%. As regards information-sharing by security services, Europol has created the possibility for counter—terrorism units to communicate bilaterally using the Secure Information Exchange Network. The European Counter—Terrorism Centre, operational since January last year, is more and more fulfilling its role as an information and cooperation hub in support of Member States. The Firearms Directive is another important achievement in the fight against terror. Yesterday you approved the compromise text, and this will allow the Council to vote and successfully close the legislative procedure at first reading. The new directive will enhance the traceability of firearms. It will provide more stringent rules in terms of deactivation of firearms. This is particularly important since it was precisely poorly-deactivated and reactivated firearms that were used in some of the recent terrorist attacks. Finally, the new directive also prohibits some dangerous semi-automatic firearms. Radicalisation is something that obviously must be addressed, primarily by Member States but also by a coordinated and broad approach at EU level. We have started updating the set of guidelines agreed in December 2014 to complement the revised EU Strategy for Combating Radicalisation and Recruitment to Terrorism to bring it into line with the current developments. This complements the efforts undertaken by the Commission in relation to the recently-launched network of national prevention coordinators. Focusing on online initiatives, the work of the Internet Referral Unit at Europol is crucial. Cooperation with service providers has proved successful, and approximately 90% of the content considered illegal is taken down by service providers. At the EU Internet Forum Ministerial meeting in December last year, the internet companies involved announced the creation of a new shared database to facilitate identification of potential terrorist content on their platforms. Another important part of our joint endeavours concerns the rights of victims of terrorism, which have been significantly strengthened by last week’s adoption of the Directive on Combating Terrorism. This directive includes a catalogue of specific measures and services for the victims of terrorism. It also introduces a coordination mechanism in case of a terrorist attack. In relation to external borders, an additional safeguard will be provided as of next month, when the amendment to the Schengen Borders Code to reinforce checks against relevant databases at external borders in light of the increased terrorist threats will enter into force. Member States will have to carry out systematic checks on all persons – also those enjoying the right of free movement under EU law – when they cross the external border, both at entry and exit, against databases and in order to verify that those persons do not represent a threat to public order and internal security. Allow me to say a few words on the external security and defence aspects. In the present international environment, Europe must do more to protect its citizens and contribute to peace and stability in its neighbourhood and beyond, including by committing sufficient additional resources. After the endorsement of the EU Global Strategy by the Council in December 2016, the European Council addressed this topic at its meeting last week. It welcomed the real progress made in a number of key areas. Building on that momentum, work will be taken further and the European Council will revert to this issue in June to provide further strategic guidance. I use this opportunity to highlight the fact that last week the European Council reiterated the call it made last December for us, as co-legislators, to agree on the proposal for an entry and exit system by June of this year. We have also been called upon to speed up work on the proposal for the European Travel Information and Authorisation System. I hope that together we will be able to meet this call. Finally, I can assure you that we are continuously striving to improve, to close gaps and to enhance our security, including by assessing our structures and policy, which can contribute to ensuring the EU policies are fit for purpose. I thank you for this opportunity and look forward to hearing both the Commissioners and honourable Members in this debate.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Minister Borg, today we are commemorating a tragic anniversary. Almost one year to the day, terror struck Brussels. We are here, united, to pay our respects to the memory of the victims of terrorist attacks. We remember and honour those who died unnecessarily – innocent citizens. We remember and recognise the suffering of their families, and the survivors of the attacks. They have to live forever with the memory of the atrocities. We all know that terrorism is brutality, an act of inhumanity and of callousness. That is why today is also a day of resolve, of resilience, of determination, to do everything in our power to prevent such terrorist attacks from happening again. This is a duty we all share here in this room, and it is ultimately our duty towards our citizens, who increasingly look towards Europe to feel safe against terrorism. Almost one year ago, we said that the only way to fight terrorism decisively is together, through a genuine and effective Security Union in Europe, where the security of one Member State is the security of all. Starting from our external borders, where we put in place a European Border and Coast Guard, proposed an EU Entry-Exit System, and ETIAS, our Travel Information and Authorisation System for visa-free travellers. Ensuring systematic checks on everybody crossing our borders; working with our strategic partners like the United States of America, but also our neighbours – the Western Balkan countries, Lebanon, Jordan, Tunisia and Turkey; improving the way we exchange information: interconnecting our information systems to make sure we connect all the dots; establishing our European PNR system to track the movements of dangerous persons; criminalising all aspects of terrorism with our new Counter-Terrorism Directive; strengthening our agencies, starting from Europol, where we set up our Counter-Terrorism Centre to help Member States in their operations; cutting the access of terrorists to explosives and firearms (you actually voted on our new Firearms Directive this morning); going after the money of terrorists, with a series of proposals targeting money laundering, asset-freezing, cash movements and suspicious financial flows from third countries; strengthening the security of all modes of transport, which are often the main targets of terrorists. We do this through stepped-up intelligence-sharing, local risk assessments, innovative methods and technologies, and the key role of operators for a successful implementation of measures. And finally, working to counter radicalisation in our communities, schools, prisons, and especially on the internet. Now that Daesh is losing all its territory on the ground, the internet is where they will focus. I have just returned from Silicon Valley, where I went to meet the major internet companies working with us in the EU Internet Forum, an initiative we took two years ago, and it has proved itself very successful. What I confirmed in this visit is that we managed to build a solid relationship of trust and partnership with these companies. Our goals are shared. They want to clean up their platforms from all terrorist content. We want to keep our citizens – their users – safe. Concrete results from this partnership are already visible. The referral mechanism we set up with Europol last year resulted in almost 90% removal rate of the content we refer to the companies. I have seen in action their new project to eliminate terrorist propaganda – a shared database between them to ensure removed terrorist content stays offline. I heard how they want to work with us to bring the smaller, more vulnerable platforms into our partnership. And it is not just about removing terrorist content; it is also about creating content with positive narratives. Today, as I said, we launched the Civil Society Empowerment Programme, with a EUR 10-million financial envelope attached, to help NGOs pass positive counter-messages online. Things are moving forward, but we still have a lot of work ahead of us. We have put important proposals on the table that you need to adopt swiftly to make a difference for the security of our citizens: Entry-Exit; ETIAS; the Schengen Information System, on which work should be completed this year. What we agree should be fully and correctly implemented: PNR; the Counter-Terrorism Directive; our new rules on firearms have entered the crucial stage of implementation, and as you understand, we cannot afford to fail. Tragic anniversaries such as today’s underscore our responsibility to deliver without delay for the memory of the innocent victims, for the safety of our citizens, for our collective security.

name: Claude Rolin
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, in my country, March 22 has become a symbol of mourning. A year ago - as other countries have been before and unfortunately also after - Brussels was hit by terrorist violence. Our thoughts must go to the disappeared and their families, to all those who are still suffering in their flesh, in their lives, to the victims of March 22 but also to all the others, in Europe or elsewhere. Safety measures aside, today life is back on track. Brussels will always remain Brussels. "Brussels, my beauty" as Dick Annegarn sang, European Brussels, Brussels with its happy melting pot, symbol of openness and diversity. The terrorists force us to better design our protections, but they have failed and will always fail in their attempt to impose their totalitarian vision. Identities cannot exclude each other, they must add up: this is the condition of living together. Radicalization that leads to terrorism is a complex phenomenon that requires us to act on all fronts to guarantee security while preserving our humanism. With her father, a journalist on public radio, Lauriane shared the values ​​of democracy, justice, tolerance, she is one of the victims of this heinous act. After this tragedy, on the air, her dad, Michel Visart, courageously delivered a message of hope. I repeat his words: “Building walls of exclusion or cultivating hatred will not help. If we want a different world, we need this respect, this tolerance and this love ”. May these words help us to refuse to withdraw into identity, to strengthen our security, while preserving our freedoms and our living together.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the last years have not been easy for Europe. Several terrorist attacks have taken lives. What are the lessons we have learned from more than a decade of the fight against terrorism? It is a mistake to say all terrorism is inspired by religion. Terrorist acts are first and foremost criminal acts. Terrorism is difficult to predict, especially when it goes for lone wolf terrorism cases such as Breivik in Norway. We have taken actions. The S&D Group has been a constructive partner in adopting key security measures, but some do not work properly or are not implemented. Let me first stress the most important thing. There can be no freedom without security, but security without respect of fundamental rights is unacceptable. In the S&D Group today we call on the Commission and Member States for concrete actions. We need full analysis of all the measures currently in place at national and EU level. We need to know which are implemented and whether they are efficient, also why some are not working and what is still missing or can be improved. What is certainly missing is the lack of cooperation and information intelligence exchange between countries. We need to better address and tackle the root causes of terrorism around the world. We have to do more on bridging Europe’s social divide. Deradicalisation, social inclusion and education should be at the core of the counter-terrorism strategy. It is wrong to believe we do nothing. In the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs most of the legislation currently deals with security, but security means also human rights, and security also means less social inequalities in Europe. So colleagues, stronger European action is required to successfully counter terrorism. The best weapon over fear and hatred in Europe is human dignity and security.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: - Next Wednesday it will be exactly a year ago that IS carried out terrible attacks in the Belgian national airport of Zaventem and the metro station Maelbeek in the European district. Dozens of people died and hundreds were injured. I wish once again to express my support to the family and friends of the deceased and the injured whose pain and sorrow I can barely grasp. In the light of this horror, we have voted several very concrete European laws to prevent such attacks in the future. I am thinking of the PNR Directive, which allows intelligence agencies to thoroughly screen passenger data entered when booking an airline ticket. Suspicious travelers now come into their sights much faster. I am also thinking of the recent changes to the Schengen Border Code, which allow us to control all EU citizens at our external borders, including at our international airports. A returning European jihadist who fought in Syria or Iraq will now be caught. But our work is far from finished. We now need to implement the ETIAS system. With this we can subject all foreigners who want to visit the EU and do not need a visa for the EU, to a prior check as the Americans already do. This dossier will shortly be piloted through Parliament on behalf of my group. I sincerely hope that this file can be discussed in all serenity in the interests of our citizens and their safety.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, a year ago, almost to the day, a monstrous attack struck Brussels: 32 dead, 324 injured, 224 people hospitalized. This terrible toll comes on top of other attacks: Madrid, London, Paris, Nice, Berlin, and I forget some. In total, several hundred dead and nearly ten thousand injured. All of Europe was upset and stunned, bruised, but it immediately pulled itself together to face the threat. In the process, the European Union took a series of measures to prevent and combat the terrorist threat. The Minister and the Commissioner have made an exhaustive list, I will not come back to it. I would like to salute these initiatives, which we have supported, and those which still have to be taken and which we will support. But that is not the gist of my point today. I want to devote my time to the victims. I learned from the press that the last victim hospitalized following the attacks which hit Brussels was able to return to her home on February 15, 2017. The press does not say in what state she is. This press briefing leads me to question whether we have taken the exact measure of the suffering and needs of the victims, and whether our compassion goes beyond words of circumstance. I know that the affected Member States - including mine - have taken more or less rapid and comprehensive measures in favor of the victims. I also know, and the Minister reiterated this, that the European Union, in the new directive aimed at combating terrorist attacks, expressly provides in Article 24 that Member States must support and assist victims. But what about European solidarity? We all proclaim that terrorist attacks are a criminal aggression against the values ​​that we all share, that every attack perpetrated in a country is an aggression directed against all others and against all Europeans, but my question remains the same.We have created a device, the Solidarity Fund, to show our solidarity when one of our countries is the victim of a natural disaster.We are united in the face of nature's failures, but we are not, in the current state of affairs, in the face of the attacks that threaten us all.We intervene for destroyed goods, but we do not do so for bruised families or damaged people.This is a wonderful thing for us ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mister President! It is good that we have this debate today, we owe it to the victims too. Even their relatives, who cannot get over their grief. You still have our deepest condolences - what else? I think what the relatives really want to know is not only a complete explanation of these cruel attacks, but they also want an answer to the question of how something like this can be prevented in the future. And of course they also know that there is nowhere absolute security. But if you look at the Commission's long catalogs, they unfortunately contain everything. Everything that is somehow related to safety is activated according to the principle a lot helps a lot. But that is exactly what is wrong. They lump everything together, stir according to the motto: Let's see. It is similar with the data: you said 34% more data at Europol. Yes, but if all the data that is available to all police authorities is packed into a huge database or several, then the targeted investigation will not be any easier! And the grain of important information that is needed to prevent the next attack is lost in the mass of data. So what we have been asking for in the last few years, like a mantelpiece, is a factual discussion about which data we really need, which measures are suitable and which are not. Martial saber rattling at the borders, I'll tell you, it won't do anything. It fakes false facts - a security that does not exist for citizens in this way.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, at the outset I would like to express our solidarity with all the victims of the attacks of March 22, 2016 in Brussels, as well as their families. I believe that nothing can ever erase their suffering caused by acts that should never have happened. But since these attacks, what have we been doing? I note that the priority, almost everywhere in Europe, is the placing under general surveillance, by technological means, of the whole of society. However, to date, no one has ever been able to establish if and how this generalized surveillance - in place for a long time, especially in Anglo-Saxon countries - has prevented a single attack. At the same time, in Belgium and France, we are going so far as to criminalize, not acts, but intentions. All this seems to me to pose a double democratic problem. First of all in terms of the separation of powers, the laws adopted in many European states give police services powers without any oversight by the judiciary. In a democracy, however, judicial oversight of the executive is important. Then there is always this principle of proportionality: any restriction of liberty must be proportionate to the objective that can be achieved: who can consider reasonable the placing under general surveillance of society and the fact of considering any citizen as a suspect? potential? So what to do? I think the priority for Europeans is simple. Most of the perpetrators of the attacks were known, so it is necessary to collect information in a targeted manner, share this information between the services - we know that the sharing of information remains the weak link in the chain - and finally exploit the information. , and for that we need human resources. I see that in most Member States the police services are weakened, which are now exhausted.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the Brussels terrorist attacks in March 2016 saw 32 people dead and over 300 wounded. It was just one in a very long list of tragic and pointless acts of violence by religiously-motivated fanatics. They carry out their senseless violence in the name of Allah and Islam. More accurately, they act in the name of Mohammedanism – the cult of Mohammed – which has always fed on blood for the 1 400 years of its existence, and Mohammedans kill their fellow Muslims just as much, if not more, than they kill non-Muslims. If you want to address the problem, you first have to understand and confront its fundamental cause. A minority of Mohammedans take literally some passages in the Qur’an. They read the bits that say ‘make war on infidels, strike terror into the hearts of infidels, and kill infidels wherever you find them’, and they act accordingly. They take literally the passage in the Hadith that says: ‘Judgement day will not come until the Muslims fight the Jews’. It is true that most Muslims are law-abiding, decent people, but all Muslims are followers of the cult of Mohammed. That cult is an ideology of blood-soaked regressive nonsense. Only a tiny minority of Muslims are fundamentalists and fanatics and literalists, but it only takes a tiny minority to plunge our societies into endless terror. All Muslims are not fundamentalists and terrorists, but the more Muslims you have in a population, the more Islam you will get, and the more Islam you have, the more terrorism you will get. Our arrogant and illiberal political elites of Western countries have created the problem by their open-door immigration policies and the doctrine of multiculturalism. I very much look forward to hearing how the EU is going to solve that problem and address the fundamental issue. But somehow I doubt that you will.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: - A year after the two attacks in and around my Flemish capital Brussels, I unfortunately have to say that it did not stop after that. It does not stop by itself. Oh yes, we try to understand, we try to process, we are all just human. Oh yes, and we must all continue to show solidarity together. Oh yes, “tous ensemble” is painted large on the inner walls of the Maalbeek metro station, barely 200 to 300 meters from the European Parliament in Brussels. But this was not a natural disaster, this did not happen to us. This was done to us by fellow humans. This was not inevitable. This should have been and could have been avoided. All those many attacks in Europe are carried out almost exclusively in those countries that have incorporated large Muslim communities into their societies in the past. There is a fatality in that case of terrorism that makes one question whether there is a link between immigration and terror and whether that link is inevitable. We can only hope not. The perpetrators of Brussels were convicted and released criminals. They took advantage of Europe's open borders, our freedom to travel and transport goods. Those are all things that we are so proud of, but those used against us by terrorists. Our way of life that we are so proud of but that is seen as unacceptable by a growing group of Muslims. What we have called homegrown terrorism since the attacks in London is growing into a serious incompatibility with our culture in our territory. We must act. This naive mass immigration, this stupid migration of the population must stop and we must run our society in a way that makes it clear to everyone everywhere that we are not going to adapt to that way of life. We must make it clear: adapt to our way of life or move. It is urgent, because the lesson from March 22 last year is and remains: terrorism does not stop, does not by itself.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, a few days mark one year since the terrorist attacks in Brussels, and much has changed since then. Security measures have improved significantly, their number has increased, people have learned to live with the threat and accept the need for the presence of police and military forces in the city. Despite the economic impact of the terrorist attacks and the changes they have made to their daily lives, Brussels residents feel safe. But the risk of a recurrence of a new terrorist attack, despite being significantly reduced, cannot be eliminated. And this comes from the possible action of individual terrorists, who, precisely because they are not yet suspects, are taking advantage of the fact, have the initiative of the movements and in their favor the advantage of surprise. Finally, I will not stop repeating that, if we want to prevent the entry of imported terrorists from the countries of the Middle East, the control must be done by the security forces.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, if there is indeed a field of public action at European level which has a raison d'être today more than ever, it is that of security. Terrorism has no borders, we have seen it with the tragedies of Paris, Brussels, Nice and Berlin. With each attack, the whole of Europe is affected. It is under attack because our continent carries rules and values ​​that barbarians would like to see collapsed in favor of chaos, terror and above all horror. Faced with Islamist fundamentalists, among whom are hiding potential terrorists, we must provide clear answers. In 2016, this is what we did by strengthening the control of our external borders with a coast guard and border guard agency with reinforced resources, or by establishing the information system on air passengers, the PNR. . These measures are in the general interest and, yet, even Ms. Le Pen opposed this device, which she considered liberticidal. Once again, citizens will appreciate its inconsistencies. In 2017, our efforts must be accelerated. But above all, it is up to the Member States to act together. In 2015, our colleague Rachida Dati advocated, in her report on radicalization leading to terrorism, specific actions to combat this scourge. But have we really taken action? Finally, European states have a duty to unite their forces in foreign operations. A European defense alliance must emerge, because the Member States must all contribute to the effort that our armies are making on the ground. The European Commission therefore has the responsibility to stimulate a dynamic of cooperation and enhanced coordination of the European Union. It is by joining forces that we will more effectively protect citizens and our territories.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Mr President, solidarity with the victims is what occurs to me a year after the Brussels attacks; and then, criticism of European governments, which continue to deny reality. The Paris attacks should have already been the turning point for real and effective European cooperation in the area of ​​security, which involves sharing information and intelligence. Instead, we now have, not one, but 28 + 1 PNR. Presented as a magic bullet by the Council, this directive does not even make the sharing of collected data mandatory, nor does it require the control of private flights. Instead of cooperation, we see European governments chasing the xenophobic far-right, selling the idea that terrorism comes from outside, brought in by foreign fighters, infiltrated among refugees, and that by building walls and barbed wire, we will be safer. It is a lie, it is immoral and it is dangerous. The terrorists who hit us in Paris and Brussels and elsewhere were European-made, proving that we need to invest in programs to prevent radicalization and inclusive social policies. Where are? We need legal and safe avenues for refugees and migrants in order to stop feeding the business of the networks of traffickers and associated organized crime. Where are these legal and safe ways? Instead, we have gold visas and investors' programs, with greenways for foreigners with a lot of money, in a scheme that jeopardizes Schengen's integrity, imports criminality and invites money laundering and terrorist financing. We need a coherent foreign policy. We look at Libya, which is a great result ... (the President cut off the speaker).

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the attacks in Brussels touched many of us in this institution, and the subsequent attacks in France and Germany have shown that the threats we face today from terrorism are as grave as ever. Terrorists have shown that they are willing to attack indiscriminately and across Europe. We only tend to notice when terrorists succeed in carrying out their atrocities, but every day our security forces are preventing other attacks from taking place across the continent. Terrorists do not recognise borders and, with the free movement in the Schengen zone making cross—border terror attacks easier, our strongest tool remains cooperation and information sharing. We have made progress. In fact we have come a long way on improving databases and sharing information, but more needs to be done. The data we share is only as good as the data we put in, so it needs every country in Europe to fully commit to sharing valuable information in our common interests. We also need to ensure measures such as PNR are properly implemented without delay. Our external borders also need continuing reinforcement. Europe should not be a soft target for terrorists to just wander in. But our biggest challenge and focus remains stopping home—grown terrorism, stopping young Europeans from turning against their own society. A lot of good work has already been done on the prevention of radicalisation on our streets, in our prisons, in our schools and, most importantly, on our sports fields, but there is a lot more to be done. Learning from each other and sharing best practice is key. There is no single thing we can do to stop terrorism. This fight will be with us for a generation. But by sharing information, updating our databases and addressing radicalisation, we can make it harder for the terrorists to succeed.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, each victim, each family, demands justice and appropriate support from us. And, in this, we still have to move forward. Society asks us for counterterrorism efficiency. We have prevented attacks. The European Agenda on Security has undoubtedly moved forward willingly, and this Parliament has not hesitated to set aside differences to form broad consensus: in the PNR, in the counterterrorism Directive, on so many issues. Terrorism carried out by suicide bombers is undoubtedly very difficult to combat, but they have not done as much damage as they could in 2016. However, despite this, 133 people were murdered in the European Union, in that year, and 31 Europeans were murdered outside the European Union. The death of these innocent human beings has served as an instrument of propaganda and has advanced the perception of fear. We have improved the regulatory and operational framework and are more effective against threats, but we are still reactive, more reactive than proactive. And to anticipate, for intelligence to give us everything possible, we need stronger will from the States. The experts say it and this Parliament demands it: mandatory exchanges of information, European intelligence, anticipation and work on the prevention of violent radicalization. Because, no matter how effective we may be in stopping terrorists, if the legitimation of violence takes root among young people and in social circles, we will find ourselves in a much more dangerous phase. The operational agenda is not advancing at the same pace as the prevention agenda. We cannot settle. And if anyone wants proof of the need for a stronger and more integrated Europe, this is very clear: in the European Union we are more, and better, and stronger to defend freedom.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I was in Brussels airport on the day of the attack. I was in the arrivals hall waiting to go out through customs when we heard – and felt – the first explosion. Then the second explosion came, and some of us thought that the roof was coming down upon us. Others did not dare to run for the exit, because they thought people would stand there and shoot. My body remembers that fear, and it is in that feeling that I reject those who say that we have to learn to live with this. Terrorism is man—made, and we can undo it.  But I also get politically angry here, because I see a one—sided focus on militarised security and surveillance technology. I think this is short—sighted and inefficient. It will not stop the Breiviks, mentioned here earlier, or the Salah Abdeslams of this Europe. We need to shift focus and to create inclusive societies which are more equal. We need to speak about gender equality and we need to counteract racism, xenophobia and Islamophobia. No rifles or surveillance technology in the world can do that. I would just finish by saying that I think we need to change the institutional set—up. We need to call together ministers ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, a year ago Brussels was struck by horror. After the tributes, we were promised action, but too little was done to address the gaps revealed by these attacks, especially the loopholes in the exchange of relevant information between our countries. Most Member States still oppose compulsory and automatic exchange, which is essential. We were promised action. States have only been in reaction and political gesticulation, not hesitating to play the fear card to pass very intrusive surveillance laws. These are the words of the United Nations special rapporteur on the right to privacy who has just published a report denouncing the risks and ineffectiveness of surveillance laws in recent years. The real lessons have still not been learned. How much time, abuse and drama will it take for them to finally be so?

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - A year after the terrorist attacks in Brussels, just under a year and a half after the latest terrorist attack in Paris. July will be the year after the terrorist attacks in Nice. One can also recall previous terrorist attacks in Madrid, in the same Paris, in Brussels. It is possible to count all the victims of terrorist attacks across Europe, but should we have an answer if the relatives of those victims asked everyone in the Chamber here what you did specifically to prevent such acts of terrorism from happening again. We have adopted and approved a number of pieces of legislation. Which of these documents do you think will guide those who decide to launch another attack on European citizens? Maybe those dangerous hundreds of people, identified last year by counter-terrorism authorities as potential terrorists, were scared of these documents and left Europe? Not very likely. That’s not why they came here to leave. Equally credible is the belief that pigeons of peace will flock to Europe in the last warm months of spring and summer as the weather warms up and relations with Turkey cool down. The preparation to give them a fight today is insufficient. Society has not become safer than it was a year ago. It is possible to think that terrorists are weaker, but it is an unwise policy.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: Until his death, this seat was occupied by Professor Hans Jansen, known worldwide for his book The Neglected Duty, a scientific study of the influence of the Muslim Brotherhood on modern Muslim fundamentalism.The Muslim Brotherhood proclaims that the great jihad - which is the killing of infidels and the conquest of the world - is no longer the task of Islamic states, as it used to be, but of every individual Muslim, because the Islamic states have renounced their sacred duty to conquer.This doctrine is now widely accepted and is the cause of many attacks and killings in our society.As long as Muslims find, accept, support, even carry out jihad as correct, there will be no more peace and security in our countries.And no EU security agenda will help.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: - Mister President!Europe is full of holes at the external borders like Swiss cheese, and I think that is the main problem.Only countries like Poland, Hungary and Slovenia secure their external borders.Otherwise, not only will possible terrorists enter the country unhindered, but also the weapons.We discussed and passed new weapons guidelines yesterday, but none of them had any real effect, because they are now making difficulties for marksmen, collectors, hunters and museums, but none of the weapons that were used in assassinations come from this group of people.So far nothing has been decided to restrict the circulation of the many weapons of war on European soil, for example in Bosnia, where hundreds of thousands of weapons are in circulation, and to secure the borders in such a way that these weapons cannot come to Europe.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: - Mr. president. Me, with the victims, sir. Managing the safety of 500 million people with limited skills is a complicated but necessary task. Threats against the Union, terror, organized crime and cybercrime require a committed response with the Member States, based on criteria of trust, cooperation and coordination. Madrid, London, Copenhagen, Paris, Brussels, Nice and Berlin are episodes of pain for Europeans and constitute the lethal imprint of selective indiscriminate terror. The security agenda and the Commission Communication are tools for the Union to tailor the response to the threat. Legislative and operational developments produce results, but never enough. Terror kills, intimidates, extorts, kidnaps, without humane or compassionate criteria. The Union fights it with the law and with guarantees. The disproportion between attack and response is so exaggerated that we will never be able to produce instruments of total security. This reality must be assumed to improve it. From national security, we must advance towards the collective security of the Union; cooperate more and better in the police, judicial and criminal intelligence field; improve control of external borders; avoid radicalization by acting in communes, schools and prisons; neutralize opaque financing circuits; advance the interoperability of eighteen information exchange systems; improve the regulation of weapons, precursors and explosives - Europol and its CELT and its EU IRU and Eurojust are essential agencies for the safety of Europeans -; and greater visibility and protection for all victims.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: -  Mister President! My colleague Rolin said earlier, quite rightly: The point is that we can continue to live together in tolerance and love in the future. But for that we need freedom and security, and we must not allow them to be played off against one another. People have a right to both, and therefore we have a duty to contribute to both. We Social Democrats want the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the LIBE Committee to work with others to draw up a report on exactly what: What have we already decided? What is working now? Where is the problem with implementation? Where do you need to readjust and where are additional activities needed to ensure freedom and security internally and externally, both with regard to the causes and the effects? We have discussed enough ideas. We have decided a lot, and now we have to see how we can speed up the implementation and how what we implement works or sometimes, as we know, doesn't work either. It's not about one or the other. Neither are some guardians of security, nor are others solely responsible for freedom. We have a common duty to both.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! A year ago, on that tragic Holy Tuesday, many of us had the feeling that the war had started, and we were indeed right because it was a sign that there was a war going on in Europe. It wasn't an incident. But in order to ensure the safety of our citizens under these conditions, we must be aware of what is really happening. Meanwhile, we hear very often, also in our debate, euphemisms: 'radicalization'. What exactly is radicalization supposed to be? This is the transition of the convinced jihadist from intentions, from hatred of the West to terrorist actions. We really have to react very early. For people who are not our citizens, any manifestation of hatred against the society in which we live should be a reason not to let such people - or even those who support them - stay in our society. Only the creation of such a clear requirement will create isolation from these people and guarantee their communities the possibility of living in peace.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - Almost a year ago, Brussels was hit in the heart, the capital of Europe: 35 dead, 324 injured.Let us also pay tribute to those victims today.Today it has been exactly a month since the last victim left the hospital.None of them has already been able to claim compensation.That is why I strongly support the proposal of Mr Deprez, who is actually calling for a genuine solidarity fund to be set up for the victims of terrorism in Europe.Second, Europe must be strong together.Populists say: fall back on yourself, create boundaries.No, we will win the fight against terror if we do it together.A genuine European intelligence service, better protection of the external borders, tackling terrorist financing, fighting radicalization.Together we are strong.What are we waiting for?Let's do it together.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. president. First of all, a memory for the murdered and our condolences to the family. Brussels gives us clues about what was done wrong, even the contradictions when tackling this problem. The terrorists were Europeans radicalized in our ghettos, trained in Syria and known to the secret services. Information must be coordinated, always under the control of the rule of law. They trained in Syria, like more than five thousand Europeans who are fighting there today. In other words, we must speak openly with the Syrian Government on anti-terrorism matters, as our secret services already do in a hidden way; abandon the policies of destabilization, support for supposed moderate groups that are really terrorists; stifle funding; pressure our partners so that, for example, the border with Turkey is not the entry and exit of combatants or oil; arms embargo - it may not be that arms legally sold in terrorist hands appear -; prevention of Wahhabi and Takfirist radicalization and, above all, an economic and cultural plan for our ghettos, rich in inequality, unemployment and precariousness.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, a year after the Brussels attacks it is the right moment to discuss the EU’s security agenda. It is time to step back for a moment, to just pause and think through the implications of our actions until now. Are we taking the right measures to invest massively in better equipment, better cooperation between our police and security services, and effective deradicalisation, or are we still putting forward expensive, but ineffective and symbolic, measures of mass data collection or intrusive surveillance measures against completely innocent citizens, thereby weakening effective security and our freedoms together which we defend? Therefore, I am very happy that Commissioner King is starting to investigate the effectiveness of the hundreds of security measures which the European Union and its Member States have adopted through the years. We have to see what is working and what is not working.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: -  Mister President!We will all remember the day of the Islamic terrorist attacks in Brussels and we mourn 32 people who lost their lives.Over 300 were injured, some seriously.But I think the EU did not learn the right lessons from it.At least three of the perpetrators were born in Belgium, they were Belgian citizens.They radicalized themselves in Belgium, they formed a terrorist cell to attack the country they grew up in, to kill the people who were their neighbors.Some of the perpetrators were integrated in Belgium - in their parallel society.They were not integrated into the Belgian dominant culture.Multiculturalism failed.We Europeans have to reflect on our leading culture, and we have to defend this leading culture.Less multicultural and more Christian-occidental dominant culture.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, this Europe has done nothing against Islamic terrorism, neither after the attacks in Brussels, nor after the attacks in Nice, Berlin and Munich. We have been repeating this for years: we have the enemy at home; unfortunately the enemy is already inside our house and this enemy is called Islamic fundamentalism. Islam has declared war on us and in war we have the duty to fight to defend our land and our children. Other than opening the doors to all illegal illegal refugees who are invading Italy and Europe. The secret services of half the world said it: we have always denounced it and now the facts confirm it. Among the illegal immigrants who arrive with the boats, terrorists are hiding ready to strike. Without internal border controls, due to Schengen, terrorists roam free from one country to another, all over Europe, ready to hit our cities. Enough with the false goodness! Enough with the false myth of hospitality! Strong and urgent measures are needed to be implemented immediately: close the borders, defend borders, stop the invasion of illegal immigrants. Zero tolerance and an iron fist. Here is what it takes to truly combat the danger of Islamic terrorism.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President!I would ask you to check the statements made by your honorable colleague in the Presidium.I find it impossible for immigrants to the European Union to be accused here as criminals and offenders per se.It is impossible and unworthy of this house.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - We'll investigate.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: - No, it is simply Europol that says that among the false refugees arriving in Europe there are terrorists;I don't say it.Perhaps it is the case that you also read this dossier, which is very clear.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: As I said, we'll look into it.We cannot continue this debate now.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, dear Presidency, Minister! I would be very happy if the ENF would finally stop making flat rates. Not all refugees are terrorists, and not every terrorist is a refugee. And if one were to just argue differently, then we would do much easier in this House. In concrete terms, I would first like to compliment the Member States, because I have the impression that there is an increasing tendency to exchange information better, to work together better, and step by step some national borders that were proudly preserved in the area of ​​security in the past, to slowly transform into a cooperation now. However, I believe that we need to expand and improve the steps we have now taken. We must not be satisfied; we must not let up because there may not be an assassination attempt at the moment, but we must continue to strive.
