But I think it is just as wrong when the Greens suddenly speak of the total surveillance state. We do not have a total surveillance state and all the tools we use are used in a balanced state. If they are not applied in a balanced way or if they are not applied against the rule of law, then appropriate action must be taken. But I think it is wrong to always speak of a surveillance state in general terms as soon as one tries to reconcile security and freedom. And finally, on behalf of Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio, I should like to once again ask the Member States to help the victims of terrorism more quickly and more consistently than has been the case up to now.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President! Attacks like the one in Brussels a year ago have changed Europe. Fear and insecurity determine the political climate, and calls for restrictions on important freedoms are growing louder. In this respect, the terrorists must feel confirmed. But it is all the more important that our reactions are calm. We have improved our border controls, we have put in place measures to register passenger data, we have improved the conditions of Europol and we passed a weapons directive yesterday. There is still no effective exchange of the information available. There is still a lack of proactive measures. We need more attention to the radicalization measures in the respective vulnerable milieus - in prisons, on the Internet and in the regions of origin. If we want to achieve something in the long term, then we have to tackle the problem at its roots. It will be a protracted, difficult struggle that will keep confronting us with new challenges, as it is now when we follow the situation in Mosul, where the city is being successfully liberated. Now we have to do everything we can to ensure that the Da'esh fighters do not seep into Europe, as is easily possible, and to compensate for their defeat, as has happened again and again, with proxy wars here in Europe. For this we need tailor-made concepts as well as decisive and quick action. Above all, we shouldn't look the other way and feel like we are safe. We owe that to the victims of Brussels.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, thirty-four lives were lost and two hundred were injured a year ago in Brussels. Among those guilty are ISIS militants, but also European citizens who have chosen to side with ISIS. Nothing can replace a lost life and time does not forgive, let's not forget this. What have we been doing for a year? We have adopted an anti-terrorism directive, which also provides for the protection of victims and common crimes for Member States with regard to terrorism, we have strengthened - we have adopted at least - we have amended the Schengen Regulation to strengthen the Union's external borders and some other legislation. It is also true that cooperation between Member States has been strengthened: more data is now transmitted to databases by Member States. Yes, we are responsible, we are all responsible and with the Member States if human lives are lost because of us. We don't have to waste time anymore. The implementation of these measures is essential. Databases need to work, talk to each other and be full of accurate, complete data from the Member States.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we need to remember all the victims of the terrorist attacks and we have to counteract. The key dimension of the security strategy is prevention. We can prevent only by working together and exchanging information on time. For this, the will of the Member States and law enforcement officers is crucial, the will to share information on demand, but also on their own initiative, information that might be needed somewhere else. It requires technological common capacity and interoperability – not fragmentation related to the different countries’ systems. A model of obligatory sharing of information among law enforcement [bodies] in real time, with coordination at the European level, is necessary. More sharing of data is useful. Maybe we should think of a single holistic framework that would make it possible to share information more efficiently and much faster. A new architecture for data exchange systems is necessary. It is key to find financial resources, European and national, for this purpose. We do not need to collect more data, but to make sure that the data are used more efficiently, that the police officer in the field will get the information when it is necessary and will be able to use it.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner of the Security Union, Julian King. We all remember perfectly where we were a year ago, when the bombs exploded in Brussels, at the airport and in the subway, and since then they have not accompanied the pain and the commitment to infinite solidarity with the victims and with their families. The terrorist threat is a real problem, but that does not mean that the answers given since then have always gone in the right direction, nor that they have been sufficient. In the wrong direction was the first response: suspend the free movement of people, reestablish internal borders and even suspend Schengen. Because those terrorists who hit us so hard did not come from outside. And the specialized protection for the victims of terrorism continues to be insufficient and, of course, the interoperability of the available information is insufficient. We have made progress on the Schengen Information System, not enough to build a true European intelligence and information community. Nor have we made enough progress in preventing the radicalization of jihadism in prisons and in the networks, nor, of course, in identifying sources of funding. Because we want to toughen the directive on money laundering in order to trace the financing channels of the terrorist threat and of the weapons available to terrorists, which are certainly not weapons of legal possession in the European Union. But above all, we must recover the fight against inequality and exclusion, the ghettoization of jihadism, which is at the deep roots of the terrorist threat, and bet on peace in our tormented neighborhood. All of this has been a consequence of austerity… (The president withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Sir. Chairman! It is now a year ago with the terrible attacks in Brussels, but they were not unique. Unfortunately, in the last year we have seen a whole series of attacks, both here in Europe and elsewhere, from radicalized Muslims who have attacked the values ​​on which our society - free societies - are based. And that is why it is also regrettable that the EU - and in particular the European Parliament - has been an obstacle rather than a facilitator to launch effective cooperation on various counter-terrorism measures. It was a disgrace that it took so long to get the PNR proposal through this Parliament, through the LIBE Committee. It is not good enough that there has been no control of the external borders since the creation of Schengen until today, and therefore it is also regrettable that the Commission and Parliament have said no thanks to Denmark's offer to participate in both PNR register as in Eurojust cooperation. If we mean the anti-terrorism effort seriously, then we should always say yes when people voluntarily come and ask to join the cooperation, not say no thank you!

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - It has been almost a year since we were startled by the horror of the attacks in Brussels and those images will never disappear from our retina. Our thoughts today therefore go first and foremost to the victims and their families, friends and loved ones. Much has happened in the past year, Commissioner Avramopoulos rightly pointed out. We have the PNR Directive, the Anti-Terrorism Directive, we have strengthened external border controls and so on. But it's not just about adopting guidelines. It is especially important that those guidelines provide added value in practice. In that regard, I am concerned about the pace at which these guidelines are being implemented. When I see that only six Member States have implemented the PNR Directive, then I worry about that. We cannot sign a law and sit back. We will have to take active action, including in the Member States, to put this into practice. Finally, we have talked about external borders, but I would also like to draw your attention to internal borders. I come from a beautiful border province. In my province of Limburg, we have more borders with Germany and Belgium than with the Netherlands and I am a fan of keeping those borders open like no other, but we must not be naive. We have abolished those internal borders, but criminal organizations, human traffickers and terrorists still know how to find and use those borders. We will have to find a way to remain vigilant and carry out checks at those internal borders in Europe with technological innovations, with cameras, with scans. I would like to hear from you, Commissioner King, how you feel about improving the possibilities of controls, including at internal borders, through digital means.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - President! When we think of the attacks in Paris, Brussels or Berlin, we are thinking first and foremost of the victims. Their senseless death obliges us to take stock of what we need to do to ensure the safety of European citizens. Above all, we need to realize that terrorism cannot be stopped by fences, walls, increasingly stringent laws, more and more committees. We need a different kind of thinking, a different kind of approach. We need to ask the question of why the adult descendants of former immigrants here in Europe are facing Europe, why European values ​​are being radicalized. But we also need to answer how, seventy years after World War II, neo-Nazi groups can flourish in Europe and how some of the hopeless working-class youth can become believers in violent racism. Today, we have no more important task than stopping radicalization. And this can only be done through a common European program. A program that effectively helps social integration, offers future, perspective, prosperity, social security for everyone. If we want to stop radicalization, if we want to prevent further terrorist attacks, we need to create programs that can bring back, win over young people who have turned to radical ideas on the margins of society. If we are not able to do this, then there is no reason to talk about security and the fight against terrorism.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, next week will mark the first anniversary of the Brussels terrorist bombings. 32 innocent civilians were killed on the streets of Brussels, and around Parliament we are all too familiar now with the army’s presence and regular patrols of the police that followed those attacks. It is a reminder to us all in Europe of the challenges that our societies face as we seek to prevent radicalisation of our young people. Of the five terrorists, four were Belgians and a fifth was a Swede. These attacks illustrate the importance of intelligence—sharing mechanisms to fight cross—border crime and terrorism that develops within the EU. Whether this is the Passenger Name Records, the Prüm Convention, the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS), the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) or the Schengen Information System. These are all vital to providing security and protecting our citizens. As my country seeks to leave the European Union, I believe it is of utmost importance that the UK stays as plugged—in as possible to all of these programmes, and that security cannot be a bargaining chip but instead be settled as a top priority early on in the Brexit negotiations.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner King, barbarism touched Brussels a year ago. Before it had been Paris and Copenhagen and then it would become Nice, Munich and Berlin. Nothing justifies terrorism and what is important is to prevent it, because no sanction against criminals diminishes the suffering of the victims. I repeat what I have said several times here: we have always combined freedom of movement with the security of our citizens. These are two fundamental rights that we have a duty to protect. In the last year, we have reacted hotly, we have had advances and setbacks by the Member States, but we have certainly taken some important steps. We strengthened Europol, guaranteed victims' rights, increased controls at external borders and attacked radicalization. However, as Roberta Metsola said, we can do more and better. I have always defended the best use of the instruments we already have on the ground, instead of multiplying the announcements of new measures. The Schengen Information system is a paradigmatic example. The system most used by the police remains with its potential yet to be fulfilled. But, soon, the revision of its legal basis will make better information available to the competent authorities. This is the message I want to underline today, here. In the fight against terrorism, mutual trust, more cooperation and better information are essential. This should be our focus on the work ahead of us.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the terrorist attacks on Brussels have left serious security, political and psychological consequences. Last year's attacks not only caused mass casualties and destruction, but were also a political message because Brussels is the capital of the European Union, NATO headquarters, but at the same time recognized in terms of security as Europe's soft belly. The attacks, unfortunately, did not stop. They were repeated in Nice and Berlin. We read almost daily about last-minute attacks prevented. Terrorism is still at work in Europe, which we cannot and must not ignore. Apart from the security crisis, Europe is also facing problems of a military-security as well as a political-social nature. We need to finally tackle the deteriorating general security situation inside and outside our borders. Primarily by helping member states to better cooperate and exchange information, but also by stabilizing conflicting political communities in the neighborhood. The circumstances today are such that we have to agree on much more serious cooperation in the field of defense. Security and defense must not remain the weakest links in European integration, because the failure to provide security to citizens will cause us to move further away from the European project. A year ago, Brussels was a completely closed city. Since then, there has been a growing dilemma as to whether the European Union will be able to maintain openness as one of its core values ​​or will gradually slide into the state of a "fortress of Europe". I am afraid that many of today's European politicians would give hasty answers to this question.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is hard to believe that we are one year on from that terrorist attack in Brussels that morning, when it came to the heart of Europe. These attacks were carried out at a time of the day when they were designed to cause maximum harm, damage and mayhem. The thing that we always have to consider on occasions like this is what the families of the victims and those who have survived are probably going through as they relive that memory.  I certainly welcome what the Commissioner is going to do on money laundering, drugs and areas like that because this is, to a large extent, what many terrorists use to actively fund their programmes. Certainly, violence and terror can never be justified nor used as an argument to achieve anything. I listen to a lot of comments, but I will leave you with one thought and that is that the victims are more important than the victim-makers.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome the progress made over the past year in the area of ​​security and the fight against terrorism. These are essential questions: harmonization of European legislation, strengthening of external border controls, exchange of information or even the fight against terrorist propaganda. Of course, there is still a long way to go. The new Terrorism Directive, which we adopted last month, is an important step. We are in the process of creating a common legal framework, but also and above all a common culture. Building trust between our various intelligence services will not happen overnight, but the idea that a European struggle represents real added value is taking hold. In this sense, I would like to support the establishment of a parliamentary committee on terrorism, as it would be an extremely useful platform for dialogue. Our practices are not always similar, but our objective remains the same: the protection of European citizens. The top priority is file interoperability, as we can no longer afford to let known intelligence terrorists slip through the cracks. Finally, we must not neglect the link between internal and external security. An internal counter-terrorism system, no matter how perfect, will only be truly effective if our neighborhood is stable. A strong EU engagement in conflict management in our neighborhood is therefore an integral part of the fight against terrorism.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: - Madam President, today we are thinking in particular of the victims in Brussels and elsewhere. These tragic attacks have shown us the need for closer cooperation, more Europe, more solidarity. The European security agenda is a necessary step towards the creation of a European area of ​​internal security and all actors must play their part to ensure that the Union does everything in its power to guarantee the citizen security. And, it is clear that the commitments made by the Member States have yet to be translated into concrete actions. Parliament invests heavily in the fight against terrorism and ensures that the fragile balance between security and respect for freedoms is respected. One does not go without the other. This is why, for us, the idea of ​​setting up a commission to investigate terrorism is not acceptable. Strengthening security should not come at the expense of freedoms. I would like to conclude with the words of Jens Stoltenberg, Norwegian Prime Minister during the attacks on the island of Utøya in 2011: "We will respond to terror with more democracy, more openness and tolerance".

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, after the recent terrorist attacks in Belgium, Germany and France and a series of last-minute attacks by the intelligence community and law enforcement, I think it is more than obvious that there is a problem that is much more than the occasional manifestation of individual madness. . In our territory, fanatical soldiers of an unrecognized criminal entity known as the Islamic State are fighting against us. Whether we want to admit it or not, Europe is at war on its own soil, and this requires certain measures to guarantee the security of our citizens. Member States' security services, police and armies need to cooperate and exchange information even more intensively, especially on returnees from Middle Eastern battlefields who pose a particular threat. Although they are citizens of the Union, they have consciously and without coercion chosen the criminal side and fought against everything that this Community represents, so they should be treated accordingly.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I of course join in the tribute paid to the victims of the attacks in Brussels, whose anniversary we will be commemorating in a few days, and I welcome the actions taken by the European Commission in one area - security internal and anti-terrorism - in which its powers are, it should be remembered, limited compared to those of the Member States. Allow me to talk about two other attacks which also took place in March: March 2004, in Madrid, an attack which remains to this day the deadliest Islamist attack on European soil, and March 2012, in Montauban and in Toulouse, where Mohamed Merah murdered French soldiers and Jewish children. It turns out that these actions have historically marked the return of jihadist terrorism on European soil, and it turns out that at each of these historical stages, the phenomenon had not been anticipated and had even been underestimated. So there has been a lot of talk today and, during our last plenary debate on the directive, about concrete anti-terrorism measures and I would like to stress the dimension of anticipation and strategic analysis, because it is a fundamental data to prevent the plasticity of terrorism, which will strike places which, until then, had been spared and which will reactivate networks which have not yet been identified.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: - Madam President!Most of the citizens of the European Union define security as one of the most important attributes of this organization.The sense of security was seriously shaken after the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels.The commissioner responsible for the security agenda argued last year that terrorists are not targeting a specific Member State, but that their attacks target our way of life.This is half true, as the attacks in Brussels also targeted the Belgian state whose officers were involved in combating terrorism.Any country undertaking the fight against terrorism must take this risk into account.In my opinion, the Regulations on Passenger Name Records are going in the right direction.However, the Firearms Directive is questionable, as it turns out to be targeting gun collectors and sport shooters, not terrorists.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, terrorism is a global phenomenon that tries to destroy our societies. For this reason, the area of ​​freedom, security and justice that we want to establish cannot become a marque certificate for terrorism to enter freely. I think it is important to underline that four thousand citizens of the European Union have integrated terrorist organizations in countries like Syria and Iraq. And I believe, Commissioner, that we must take advantage of the fact that 82% of the citizens of the European Union call for a greater involvement of the European Union in the fight against terrorism in two aspects: in the internal dimension, that is, to through the European Agenda on Security, and also seeking cooperation between Member States and third countries in the field of preventing young Europeans from becoming radicalized on the internet, in the field of financing and money laundering and in the field of prevention and control, Commissioner, and with regard to all communication campaigns, putting the accent - and I will finish, Madam President - on what is essential, which is the human factor, man. And, above all, I want to remember the victims, who ask for memory, dignity and justice.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I thank you for this very rich debate. The last two years in particular have been marked by too many attacks and by too many victims. Our thoughts go out to them and to their loved ones. As Minister Borg said, last weekend we were with some of those victims, including some of the victims of the Brussels attacks, I was struck again – as I am each time I have the privilege of meeting victims – by their bravery and by the power of their testimony. However, on this occasion I was also struck by the welcome that they gave to the just-adopted Counter-Terrorism Directive, and, in particular, to the elements – not least those introduced by this House and reinforced by this House – on the rights of victims. They welcomed the fact that we were requiring Member States to make sure that victims have access to the support they need not only immediately after an attack, but also for as long as necessary thereafter. That was an important piece of work that we did together. These attacks across Europe display a common factor: many aspects of their preparation and execution are transnational. As a number of you have said, that is why it is so important that we work together to ensure the most appropriate response and increase our collective resilience. I would like to salute the commitment that this House has shown on security dossiers over the recent discussions. It is crucial that we maintain this momentum and continue to work for their rapid and effective implementation. As many of you have said, we have done a lot, but there is still a lot to do.  Many of you have mentioned the importance of information-sharing. As we discussed in plenary last month, I believe we are moving in the right direction; there is a clear increase in the use by Member States of the Schengen Information System and the Europol information system, but there is still a long way to go. I hope that this House will move quickly now to support the proposals that we have brought forward for the reform of the Schengen Information System, including, for the first time, a provision to oblige Member States to share information on terrorism. Step by step, we need to continue our work to build trust. Improving information exchange is also at the heart of our work on interoperability that a number of you have mentioned. Overcoming the current shortcomings in information management is a key priority for the Commission. The process we initiated last year, with the strategy presented in April and the High Level Working Group, will allow us to address these shortcomings in an inclusive and transparent way with you here and with the Council. The Group will present a final report in early May, and that will be a basis for further discussions with Parliament and the Council to look at how best to take this work forward. A number of you have also underlined the importance of operational police cooperation. The Commission has encouraged Member States to make use of the possibility of carrying out police checks in internal border areas. At the same time, and in answer to one of your colleagues, we are considering practical steps to strengthen police cooperation across internal borders. Our objective is to enhance security within the Schengen area, including internal border areas, as part of the work that we are doing to use Schengen to get back to the normal functioning of Schengen. But we will not defeat terrorism with databases and legal frameworks alone.  We also need to continue our work, as many of you underlined, on implementation. We need to tackle radicalisation online and in our communities and prevent the hatemongers from inciting people, often young people, to go down the route of violence. We also need to continue to build our collective resilience and starve the terrorists, and others who seek to do us harm, of the means they use, whether that is arms, explosives or funding. As has been mentioned, while we are focusing on the threats related to terrorism today, quite properly we should not lose sight of the continuing work that we are doing to reinforce our security against serious and organised crime and the threats that come from cyber criminals and others who operate in cyberspace. In all of these challenges, there are no quick fixes. We need to continue to work to ensure the security of European citizens, recognising that this is a long-term challenge requiring the engagement of all of us. For our part, the Commission will continue our efforts to build an effective and sustainable Security Union, and I sincerely hope that we can continue to count on your support in this work.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: written. - Since March 22, 2016, the black day on which thirty-two people in Zaventem and Maelbeek were cowardly murdered, crucial steps have been taken to tackle and prevent terrorism. That is the best way in which we can show our respect for the victims and the next of kin. The Counter Terrorism Directive, adopted last month, is a crucial step in stepping up the joint approach to Syria fighters, the terror networks and draining their money flows. Crucial is the much closer cooperation and exchange of information between national intelligence and police services, which are now obliged to automatically exchange information among themselves when detecting terrorist activities and to share information on suspected and convicted terrorists with Europol. A comprehensive external border control is also essential to enhance internal security. Together with the roll-out of the European Border and Coast Guard, all Member States must now carry out systematic checks at the European external borders and exchange passenger data of flights within the Union, the so-called PNR. It is clear that the most effective approach is one of enhanced European cooperation in tackling and, in particular, preventing terrorism. That is a main task for Europe.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The events in Brussels a year ago shocked us all that such atrocities could happen to any of us at any time. They have made it clear that we cannot enjoy our freedom without security. Although these events have made our EU counter-terrorism policy tougher and more coordinated, recent events (see Germany) have repeatedly warned. The policy of open gates is being exploited by radicalized groups, infiltrating Europe, abusing the loopholes in the asylum system, and waiting for applications to be processed. Therefore, it is necessary to separate those who are really entitled to refugee status at the Schengen borders, which the Hungarian government targeted with its new law. According to a report by Europol last week, there are still more than 5,000 international organized crime groups in the EU, which is not only a decrease but also a significant increase compared to 2013 figures. These international criminal groups are increasingly intertwined with handgun smuggling and migration-related crimes such as human trafficking and forgery. There is only one way to guarantee the security of our continent and to put an end to human traffickers, if we separate economic migrants from the real refugees outside the territory of the European Union and do not allow anyone to enter Europe uncontrolled. We need to know who enters the territory of our countries, with what intent they do so, and this is the only way to avoid another misfortune. We must put the security of our own citizens first!

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written. - One year after the attacks in Brussels, it is convenient to take stock of the progress of the European Agenda on Security. As the EP points out, our priorities must be to improve the exchange of information, to fight the financing of terrorism, to avoid radicalization, also in prisons and online, and to strengthen the external borders of the EU. In the last twelve months, the EU has approved the Directive on the use of passenger data registration (PNR), new rules against terrorism and mandatory controls for all those who cross the external borders of the Union. Other initiatives are in the pipeline, such as the revision of the Schengen Information System and the Information System on criminal data, as well as the launch of a new authorization mechanism for travelers entering the EU without a visa. Furthermore, we Socialists insist on issues that are not talked about so much, such as the need to attack the root causes of terrorism, prioritizing integration, education and the fight against money laundering that contributes to financing terrorism.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 22 March, we will be commemorating the first anniversary of the Brussels attacks, which are still so vivid in our memories. We remember and honour those who died unnecessarily – innocent citizens. We remember and recognise the suffering of their families, and the survivors of the attacks. The world is facing extremely aggressive terrorist organisations dedicated to killing people, disseminating fear, undermining democratic modern societies and threatening peoples’ lives, liberty, equality and fraternity.  Terrorist organisations are becoming more trans-national, logistically well organised and well-funded, designed to instil fear and disrupt the normal functioning of our society. And I have to say that to a certain degree they have succeeded. After last year’s terrorist attacks in different European countries, people are petrified and no longer able to feel safe in their own country.  Therefore, it came as no surprise to me that more than 80% of European citizens have chosen the fight against terrorism and radicalisation as Europe’s number one top priority, believing that more common EU action is required in the fight against terrorism. We need to reinforce actions and measures at European and national levels to cover every aspect of this hideous crime, from prevention to protection and prosecution.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- Almost a year ago, the Brussels airport and metro were hit by a terrible terrorist attack.In response to the situation, the EPP set 10 priorities.This package of measures includes all the tools we need to be able to curb similar attacks in the future.We have already achieved six of the priorities, such as the launch of passenger name records and the protection of the EU's external borders, the introduction of measures to prevent the financing of terrorism, a new strategy against radicalization and support for victims of terrorism.The work will continue, and the goal is the security of Europe, where citizens can live freely and without fear.I am confident that we will be able to adopt the other four priorities with similar speed and agreement.

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Evaluating the state of security in Europe is welcome, but reduced levels of illegal migration and a temporary reduction of the fighting intensity in Syria do not represent a definite improvement. On top of the attention we pay to common threats like terrorism, illegal migration, cyber, etc., we should also address a longer and deeper time to threats posed by, for instance, the deepening of social polarisation, enlarging the gap between Brussels and the EU peoples, which is aggressively exploited by populists internally, and adversaries eternally. After Brexit, what the EU needs is more unity, not disunity.  Still, it is precisely now that the concept of a ‘multi-speed Europe’ has been launched, adding to the divisions already existing in Europe. The current troubles, which western European leaders complain about, were not generated by enlargement, as further integration has not been prevented by the new members; still, these leaders indicate that dividing Europe between ‘core’ and ‘periphery’ would be the absolute panacea for all current challenges. Has anybody asked what would be the signal sent by such internal divisions to the adversaries of the EU, or what would be the impact on the credibility of the ENP and the EP in the eyes of those outside the ‘periphery’?

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - A year ago, just a few months after the Paris bombings, the bloodiest terrorist attacks in the country's history took place in Belgium. Then came Nice and Berlin, all of which were hard blows for a Europe built on the idea of ​​peace. The new reality we face is one marked by geopolitical volatility and the radicalization of political currents hostile to the values ​​promoted by Europe, which translates into more serious consequences than we can estimate at first sight. In this context, we need a European Defense and Security Strategy that helps to resolve conflicts in the immediate vicinity of the Union and that gives our citizens a sense of security without restricting their rights. EU countries need to step up cooperation in the fight against terrorism, violence and radicalization, with a view to creating European bodies with decision-making powers in these matters, as well as a European army capable of defending our citizens in the event of further aggression. The proposal made by the Juncker Commission a year ago is welcome, but we need to be even more ambitious, especially where action at Union level can add value.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE), in writing. - One year after the bloody terrorist attacks in Brussels and in the shadow of the growing terrorist threat in Europe, security is one of the main concerns of European citizens. Given the cross-border nature of modern terrorism, the phenomenon can only be tackled individually with good cooperation between the Member States and the EU with its international partners and neighboring countries. The progress made in the renewed European security strategy is significant: tightening the rules against the financial resources of terrorism, establishing a European Border Guard to better guard our external borders, strengthening European security services (Europol, Eurojust) and the establishment, following intense negotiations, of the European Passenger Name List (EU-PNR). However, there is still a long way to go before we can achieve Security Union, as announced by President Junker. Cyber-terrorism remains unchecked because we are still lagging behind in a legislative framework that ensures improved database interoperability at European level, and we need additional measures to prevent the radicalization and recruitment of citizens by terrorist organizations. Building an open and secure Europe is what is needed and must be achieved as soon as possible with the cooperation of all of us.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. - The attacks in Brussels a year ago unfortunately confirmed the fact that terrorists are effective and increasingly ruthless. They also confirmed that Belgium is a country from which many terrorists in Europe come from, who return to it and have a logistic base here. The Belgian authorities, as well as the European Union, have taken a number of initiatives in this situation to counter the terrorist threat. It is worth recalling that EU citizens are currently checked against databases each time they cross the EU border. For several months now, the European Counter-Terrorism Center has also been operating, which is located in The Hague - at the Europol headquarters. The provisions on terrorist financing have also been tightened. Services in the Member States are more effective in dismantling various publications, including webpages inciting attacks. These are just a few examples from a wide range of anti-terrorist activities. In my opinion, the key issue today is to assess the effectiveness of actions taken in the last year to counter terrorist threats. If new instruments are not effective enough, new ones must be considered. Terrorists need to be clear that the EU and individual countries will fight them decisively.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Iuliu Winkler, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European self-certification mechanism, as part of the due diligenceon supply chains, for responsible importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten, their ores and gold originating in conflict or high risk areas (COM (2014) 0111 - C7-0092 / 2014 -2014/0059 (COD)) (A8-0141 / 2015).

name: Iuliu Winkler
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, looking back at our common endeavour to get an efficient and workable Conflict Minerals Regulation fulfilling the European Parliament mandate as it was adopted in this House, we have been quite successful. First, we have been able to speak with one voice and, second, we have been able to achieve the majority of Parliament’s objectives. The vicious circle has now been broken. The importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold will have to carry out mandatory due diligence in order to check their suppliers and prevent armed rebels or human rights violations being financed by illegal revenue. The interests of communities and people caught in wars and conflict were our priority. The new regulation has the power to improve reality on the ground in conflict areas. We followed two principles in our work: first to help the people affected by illegal mining and trade conducted by armed groups and, second, to increase the responsibility of all stakeholders, including European industry, in a common effort towards transparency.  The recognition of due diligence schemes proposed by industry associations and responsible sourcing partnerships has become the central element of the regulation. All industry initiatives have to fully comply with the international OECD due diligence guidelines elaborated to help companies respect human rights and avoid contributing to conflict financing. It is important that all companies, including those from downstream in the supply chain whose products contain 3TG, will be encouraged to monitor their sources. Compulsory checks for the importers will ensure that minerals or metals sold on the European market are not used to illegally finance conflicts, particularly in mineral-rich countries affected by conflicts or war.  Educating the stakeholders and achieving long-term sustainable effects is only possible through an approach based on shared responsibility. The regulation proposed to you today will be very important in creating good premises for more prosperity in the conflict areas, and this will lead to more stability. Stability in Africa and all other conflict areas means fewer migration flows to the European Union. To protect SMEs and to minimise bureaucracy and red tape, the regulation offers an exemption for the smallest importers, based on a threshold system designed to cover at least 95% of all imports to the European Union. Through delegated acts Parliament will be able to keep control of the implementation. Parliament also ensured that the Commission will regularly report on the accompanying measures meant to make the regulation more effective. Our aim was to create an efficient and workable regulation and we fully succeeded. Now we will carefully monitor the update by the European companies and, if necessary, we will adjust the system, making use of the powerful review clause included in the provisions of the regulation.  Finally I wish to express my sincerest thanks to all the shadow rapporteurs, the negotiating team members, and all the experts, advisers and staff members involved in this highly technical and very complicated process. I would like to highlight the special support of Commissioner Cecilia Malmström, who personally attended all the negotiating sessions.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Winkler, and all the members and shadow rapporteurs of the Committee on International Trade and everybody involved in this. It has been a long work. We passed many hours together in trilogues, etc., but it has been worth it. Today we have a proposal that I hope you will endorse with a big majority tomorrow morning. We have an ambitious and a workable instrument to eliminate conflict minerals from supply chains. It will contribute to addressing the challenges of conflict linked to natural resources, hardship of entire communities and human rights abuses that have for too long accompanied this kind of trade. I am convinced that trade must be based on values, and the conflict mineral regulation is a key element in that approach. The global market-based trade in raw materials can provide a vital source of a stable income to the people and countries who need it the most, but that development needs to be sustainable. Therefore, transparent and responsible supply chains means revenues would not go into the hands of rebel groups but to investment in schools, in hospitals, supporting a well governed state underpinned by the rule of law. It can mean improving people’s lives from conflict and terror to opportunity and hope. It means encouraging the economic growth that helps the poorest regions grow sustainably. In short, this means doing what trade does best – not contributing to war and instability but delivering sustainable jobs and real opportunities. The most obvious example of the conflict linked to minerals is around the great lakes of Africa. Millions have been killed, millions more injured since the first Congo war broke out some 20 years ago, but it is certainly not the only example, so that is why this regulation takes a global approach. The United Nations, the G-8, honourable Members of this House have called for an integrated approach combining trade, development and other policies. That is good. We need to use all the tools we have. And we have responded to your call. We have worked across the Commission services with the External Action Service, basing ourselves on the work done by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) as the main actor in this field, and the regulation you will vote on tomorrow is just one of the components of our action, and I would like to remind you of some of the others. We are fully on track with the EUR 20 million development aid package announced in 2015, and this will include financial support via the OECD Secretariat, helping the responsible production of gold, peace-building and stabilisation in Central and West Africa. It will help assistance and training for those on the ground; it will help vulnerable women and children affected by the conflict; it will be a support for the International Conference for the great lakes region and a Dutch-led private-public European partnership for responsible minerals. It will help EU small and medium-sized and micro-enterprises to understand their due diligence on conflict minerals and, picking up on the very important suggestion by this House, we will also have the OECD due diligence guidance translated into all the EU official languages. We are also reaching out to other governments to encourage them to source responsibly – this month to China and India, last month to the United Arab Emirates and many African countries including Burkina Faso, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana, Guinea, Ivory Coast, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, Zambia and the African Union. This is what I mean by shaping globalisation. Unfortunately, some of the vibes we are picking up from Washington on this matter are not encouraging. We do not know yet for certain the approach by the new US administration, but this should certainly not alter our results. On the contrary, it underlines all the more the importance of European leadership here. So thank you very much Madam President, thank you again Mr Winkler for your leadership on this, and thank you for your attention.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Development. - Madam President! Commissioner! I, too, would like to congratulate the entire team that negotiated this agreement on behalf of the European Parliament, and especially the rapporteur, Mr Winkler. After long and difficult discussions, we have managed to reach an agreement which is a great success for all three EU institutions. As rapporteur for the opinion in the Committee on Development, I believe that this regulation is the cornerstone of an effective tool to break the link between conflict, human rights violations and our use of everyday goods. The interests of the community, people for whom wars and conflicts are destroying their lives, must be our priority. Under the regulation, due diligence checks in line with the OECD guidelines will be mandatory for importers of tin, tungsten, tantalum, gold and their ores from conflict and high risk areas. The rapporteur has already talked about solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises, but I think that supporting measures (or accompanying measures) for small and medium-sized enterprises and political dialogue with the countries where extraction takes place, as well as raw materials diplomacy are also important. and their management.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! If you take the example of the Congo and look at how bad the situation is in countries where raw materials are exploited, you will see that we definitely need regulation in the European Union too. With this regulation we want to ensure that as far as possible no more raw materials enter the European Union which, on the one hand, help to finance armed conflicts and, on the other hand, where workers are in really intolerable conditions - and that is what happens to us Example in the Congo instead - the raw materials have to be exposed accordingly. That is why it is good that we are making this regulation. But we should always consider: Do we have a good intention, or how do we make sure that we put a good answer after a good intention and respond with a good prescription? For example, what the Americans achieved with the Dodd Frank Act was well intended, but the result is not particularly great. Many companies in America are currently avoiding the Congo, for example, and no longer purchase any raw materials from there. This also means that the many mines that work properly and cleanly, some of the family businesses that work properly and cleanly, no longer have any prospects for the future and had to submit orders. That was a de facto embargo against the Congo. That is why it was very important to us that we make the regulation in such a way that the companies there have a perspective, that the young people can find jobs there, that we do not impose an embargo, but that we enable companies in Europe to do so to be able to buy raw materials in this country in the future with a clear conscience. That is why my appeal to European companies is: Please take part in these certification procedures! Please continue to take raw materials from the conflict regions! You can be sure now that these raw materials are not stained with blood, but that they are clean.With this in mind, congratulations to our colleague Iuliu Winkler, who, in cooperation with the rapporteurs and with the Commission and the Council, delivered a very good result.We really have created something to help our consumers, but especially those affected in the states where they work.

name: Maria Arena
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, tomorrow we will finally vote on a regulation which will make it possible to exclude so-called "blood minerals" from the European Union market. It’s true that we tend to talk about these 3 TGs in our jargon. What is it about? Tungsten, tin, tantalum and gold. All these minerals are currently used in our daily lives: in our mobile phones, in our tablets, in our refrigerators, in our cars, etc. The vast majority of them come from regions that are in conflict, but also from regions that do not respect human rights in the exploitation of these minerals. We have talked a lot about the Great Lakes region, but I think that this regulation also aims - and this is what is interesting - not to target regions in particular, but to target all the regions in which these rights humans are not respected today. Women, children exploited, raped, murdered at the altar for the simple profit of certain companies. The initial Commission proposal, - you will agree - was based on a voluntary approach, which seemed to us, here in the European Parliament, not very ambitious. Thanks to the vote of this assembly, we were able to move these lines, the lines for a regulation which passed in a compulsory process, and I must also admit that even here, in this Parliament, not everyone shared the idea of ​​passing to a mandatory procedure at the level of this regulation. Unfortunately this compulsory approach was not fully shared by the Council either and during the trilogue most of the Council's demands were to effectively reduce this compulsory approach and therefore we find ourselves today with, it is true, a regulation which allows for a mandatory process, but only on part of the supply chain. We have accepted this compromise, because we believe that we have to move forward, but I think we will have to be careful about the implementation of this rule.We do not want it to allow companies to continue doing what they are doing today, which is killing people in conflict areas.You can count on us to be attentive to the application of this regulation.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we all have a common goal: to break the link between mining and armed conflicts. This legislation provides an ambitious framework in this regard, but it is also proportionate as it is targeted to the key actors. Alone, it cannot solve the causes of those conflicts, but it will help to fight against exploitation of minerals for the financing of armed groups. It will also increase international companies’ awareness of human rights issues in relation to their activities.  This legislation is an important step forward in the field of corporate social responsibility. It will increase traceability on the supply chain. In addition, the text ensures that the system is workable for European companies; guidelines will be drafted to help companies identify where conflicts or high-risk areas are and explain how the situation on the ground is evolving. In addition, assistance is foreseen for SMEs. Finally, importers of very small volumes, such as small jewellers, will be exempted.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! Thank you, Mr Rapporteur, for the constructive cooperation. But let's remember why we are here today. War conflicts are often about enrichment. Warlords lead armed gangs with whom they want to gain or defend control over raw material areas and mines. To gain access to gold, coltan, tungsten or tin, people are murdered. A large part of the find is extorted as protection money from small mines, in which children often toil. The raw materials are turned into money. The money is used to buy weapons. More fighters can be equipped with more weapons. Whoever has more fighters has more power. Whoever has more power can control a larger area and steal more raw materials and regain more wealth. The spiral turns and is far too often an endless military loop. But, colleagues, this business model works because, in the interests of the value chain, some unscrupulous companies have been buying raw materials from the warlords for a long time. Such companies also operate in Europe. With this new European law, we are now thwarting them. So today is a good day! For the first time, companies are required to exercise due diligence for the supply chains of their raw materials. Companies at the beginning of the supply chain - these are metal smelters and refineries - have to prove the origin of their raw materials. But unfortunately only in three years! How many more victims will there be during this time? Commissioner, you should take a proactive approach to companies now and urge them to introduce supply chain controls quickly. I ask you to take action early on with the accompanying measures and to go beyond the ongoing projects in an innovative way. Then we are on the right track with this legislation. I thank I also appreciate the consistent and supportive measures and activities of the many non-governmental organizations that have been on our toes and that have brought this law into motion with us.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Madam President, all too often trade policy in the EU undermines citizens’ power and plays into the hands of transnational corporations. So I am delighted that tomorrow we will vote on a regulation which will do the opposite, and for the first time introduce binding rules on the imports of conflict minerals. Those who deal in the four metals – tin, tanatalum, tungsten and gold – will need to check that their supply chain has no links to human rights abuses or armed conflicts. It should also be noted that, although Parliament does not have formal powers to initiate legislation, this process began with the work of my colleague Judith Sargentini here in Parliament, with the Commission following up her own-initiative report with its own proposal. Parliament refused to accept the Commission and Council’s preference for a voluntary code, which is why we now have these important binding rules for the imports of conflict minerals. We are disappointed that the final deal includes some important loopholes, particularly the fact that while Parliament’s proposal included mandatory due diligence for manufacturers of products such as computers, mobile phones or laptops, this was watered down during the trilogues so that imported goods using the metals identified will not now be subject to the same binding rules. But overall, we are pleased with these binding rules on conflict minerals. This sort of restraint on the worst abuses of corporations that are so powerful in the global economy is the sort of action that citizens wish to see, and can help to build ongoing support and confidence in the European Union.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our well-being is based on the exploitation of the poorest. We are all guilty of it and if you think you are strangers to it, take your smartphone and change your mind. Telephones, cars, airplanes and computers are stained with blood, because all, without exception, contain rare minerals mined in war-torn countries, in conflict zones or in conditions that violate the most fundamental human rights, including freedom and freedom. life. Three years ago we said enough and we started working on a law that would stem this phenomenon. Thus, after long negotiations, hundreds of amendments and thousands of hours of work, the first European regulation that puts an end to the supply of conflict minerals is about to come to light. Those who want to import them now must first verify their origin and carry out all the necessary checks to prevent the minerals from being stained with blood. The multinationals of technology, automobile and aviation have strongly opposed, but have not been able to stop us, while we, to protect SMEs, have exempted small importers from the regulation, such as goldsmiths or dentists, to avoid them excessive bureaucratic burden. Our goal was to prevent trade from financing conflict, destruction and death and I believe we have succeeded. Unfortunately, not everything went as we wanted: our initial proposal was much more complex and extensive and included far fewer exceptions. But undoubtedly this is a first step and I hope that, in a few years, it will be possible to return to this regulation and make it even more effective. There is a Europe of multinationals and powerful people, which uses trade to exploit poor countries, steal their resources and destroy their rights. But there is also a Europe of citizens, just, fair and supportive, which uses its weight for justice and to promote a better world. This is the Europe I chose to represent when I decided three years ago that I would be involved in trade in the European Parliament and I hope, colleagues, that you too can do the same.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! Basically, it is welcome to pay attention to the political and social conditions under which the said conflict minerals are mined. Certification - that is clear - creates transparency. Certification also costs a lot of money, and third countries, such as China, largely forego certification and of course have an enormous competitive advantage here. Approx. 87% of the global market capital in raw materials and mining products are not certified. It would therefore also be desirable for existing industrial programs that focus on responsible purchasing - such as in Austria for example - to be recognized accordingly in the EU. That would of course also be advantageous because on the one hand we could defuse competitive disadvantages and continue to use existing structures sensibly. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, you said, among other things, that certifications cost and that it would be an impediment to costs in terms of import certification.But do you think that the cost of these certifications is more important than people's lives?Because we are talking about people's lives here and we know very well what happened and I want to welcome the report.Do you think the cost of the certificate or people's lives is more important?

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.-  Thanks for the question.It shows that obviously not paying very much attention.But I like to make it clear: Of course human lives count, of course social conditions count.As is already known from some countries, of course this counts a lot more.However, I would like to point out again - and this is also important - that competitiveness should also be a component for us in Europe.That is why one should also be wise enough to think about existing structures when they have proven themselves and to continue using them.That would be and was the essential content of my statements.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). - Madam President, we have referred many times to the international trade in minerals from volatile regions of the world and to the exploitation of the wealth-producing resources of developing countries by European companies. Unfortunately, despite our discussions here, there is no substantial change, as the financial benefit from these activities is so great, so great that some are finding ways to legitimize the illegality in favor of companies operating in their countries. Metallurgy and refining facilities are an important point in the global mineral supply chains and are the last stage in which the verification of information on the origin of minerals and the surveillance chain can be effectively ensured. After this stage of change it is often considered impossible to trace the origin of the minerals. However, this does not guarantee anyone that a mine of origin can be declared different from the real one, in order to comply with the conditions set by the self-certification. As is well known, all labor and human rights are violated during mining. The only solution is a complete ban on imports from war zones controlled by paramilitary groups that use the profits from mining and trade to continue their criminal activities. We must ban the activity of European companies in these areas. When it comes to self-certification, we all know very well that it is not going to work. In my opinion, self-certification will be a pardon for the European Union to these companies in the name of competitiveness with third countries.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: - Madam President! With this regulation, there was finally an attempt to look at trade policy, development cooperation and respect for human rights together. Yesterday evening we discussed here that millions of people in the countries of the sub-Saharan zone are at risk of acute starvation and that the reasons for this are largely political because corrupt rulers and terror groups there are fighting for power, money and influence. Many of Africa's treasures do not benefit the working people, but are the cause of violence and oppression. If the causes of the misery are political, then political action must also be taken, as our Sakharov Prize winner Doctor Mukwege has called for here. It is therefore to be welcomed that, after three years of tough negotiations, this regulation is finally on the table. I see a beginning in the fact that we finally want to turn words into deeds. And my appeal to you, Commissioner: help enforce this regulation too!

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, at the outset of this process ‘conflict minerals’ had the potential to live up to their name in our legislative scheme, but thanks to the good work of the rapporteur and the Commissioner, and indeed the flexibility of some of the Council Presidencies, the potential for conflict in the legislative process turned into cooperation. While not diminishing the work of others in this, I want to pay particular tribute to the work of the S&D shadow in this process, Maria Arena, who dug in right from the very beginning to make it clear that a voluntary scheme would not be effective, and that the only acceptable option for Parliament would be a mandatory approach. I am convinced we would not be here today if it was not for her determination. We also managed to take the Council proposal and broaden it to have a wider coverage of the supply chain and move it upstream. It is good that from now on citizens will know that, when they pick up their mobile phones, they are not indirectly financing conflict in places like the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is also good that at this time, given the lack of leadership coming from the United States on such issues, Europe is demonstrating that we are still a community of values and that we are prepared to export our values to elsewhere in the world. As the Commissioner herself said, and as other speakers have said, this part of a process now. This is not the end of the story. This is a beginning of the story of Europe making sure that our goods are traded in a fair way that defends human rights.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- The negotiations have now been conducted, we have a solution on the table.Do you think that it would be possible to intensify research on sustainable raw materials, now in the framework research program 9, in order to get substitute products for the minerals that would otherwise have to be imported?

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I believe in a holistic approach to these issues – to coin a phrase, ‘joined-up government’ – and part of it would be to find alternatives to some of these minerals, but also some of these minerals will continue to be demanded here and it is important, when Europe does trade in these minerals, that we do it in a way that is fair to the source countries and does not abuse human rights or other labour conditions.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate the Commissioner and Mrs Arena on having obtained the result we have today, even if I would perhaps be more nuanced in my judgment. In May 2015, our Parliament voted for an ambitious text which obliges all companies using conflict minerals to ensure traceability throughout the supply chain. This represents - I would remind you - 880,000 businesses. The trilogue agreement is obviously an important step forward, but it will only be binding on a minority of companies - smelters, refineries and importers of raw ore and metals beyond a certain quantity. For the others, it will be self-regulation, that is to say their more or less good will. The Council has missed, it seems to me, a remarkable opportunity to moralize behavior which is too often scandalous, which feeds deadly conflicts and turns a blind eye to the dire human situation of child diggers, victims of intolerant economic cynicism.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, mining and trading in minerals around the world is often linked to wars, conflicts and violations of human rights. The European Union is a major importer of these precious raw materials, both in raw form and as components of commonly used products, from laptops to mobile phones to jewelery. With the agreement reached in the trilogue, which makes the traceability of minerals from conflict zones binding and not only on a voluntary basis, the Union has taken a step in the right direction and therefore we will support this regulation, the result of a long and difficult process of negotiated, even if many of Parliament's requests have remained unfulfilled and much still remains to be done. In fact, minimum import quantities are established, below which there is no obligation of traceability. In this way, small importers will continue to be unaware of the origin of the minerals. Furthermore, the constraint does not concern all those elements that are today considered conflict minerals, but only some, and finally only the importers of these raw materials, and not only the manufacturers of the final products containing these minerals, have the obligation to traceability. We therefore see this as a first step and believe that the Commission should closely monitor the application of this regulation.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Madam President, we are obviously for good practices, for certification, for self-regulation and for responsible sectors.These good feelings, how can we not be for?They engage in words, they are always fun, but do they really change reality?The conflict in the DRC was triggered by an operation called Kabila, in which, from Uganda and Rwanda, the DRC was destabilized.At the same time, contracts were signed with American companies for the control of the resources of this country.The responsibility of our States must be denounced, because it corresponds to the reality of history.It is also about giving the full capacity to African States to remain masters of their resources.It is also a matter of denouncing, at home, the involvement of our States and their pharmacies in this trafficking.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Tomorrow we will see the birth of a new type of trade relationship. So far we have organized trade relations between countries, but that no longer reflects reality. We now have global value chains. 70% of global trade relate to value chains, and therefore it is right that we now start looking at the so-called conflict minerals and take responsibility for the entire value chain so that we can ensure that these substances are used responsibly throughout the value chain is handled. I believe that this is exactly the right way to pursue more trade policy in the future and ensure a duty of care for sensible, fair handling of products across the value chain. Then we can indeed say that our consumer products are fairly manufactured and traded. I think that we have also made this binding is also an important step - to say here that companies have a specific responsibility. With the OECD guidelines, we also have clear criteria on how to ensure due diligence for the entire value chain. And I'm glad we started with the conflict minerals. You can now think about whether we should continue with textile products, for example - we have OECD guidelines there too, because fair products must include all products.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, in 2014 the Commission published a weak proposal on a terrible problem of which Europe is a responsible party: the exploitation and trade of blood minerals. A year later, this Chamber took a position, with broad support, gathering the voices of citizens and organizations that asked us for a robust law that would force the control of the entire value chain, from the mines to our devices. After two years of negotiating with the Member States, the result remains half-done, it does not solve the root problem, but rather puts a patch that perhaps calms the consciences of those who settle for very little. The lobbies have worked hard. The torpedoing of this initiative has been constant. I will tell you that we will always be up front demanding that you comply with human rights. Even so, we will vote in favor, because this is better than nothing, because the direction is correct, although the low ambition is not. We will vote "yes" with a broken soul for this missed opportunity. We will vote 'yes', but we are thirsty. We will vote in favor, but we will return, again and again, to ask for everything.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is very easy when we are faced with an issue to listen to some of the voices opposite who say that the costs are too big. What is the response to that – that we do nothing, that we take no action at all? That is no response for this place, and it is not in keeping with our responsibilities as representatives of the world’s biggest market. We have a unique opportunity and, as the Commissioner has outlined, the responsibility has been abdicated from other parts of the world that might traditionally have taken a leadership role in this. It is up to us in this place, representing 500 million citizens, to demonstrate the benefit of working cooperatively at a European level to deal with these issues.  We can no longer have a situation where the products we buy and the products we use contain minerals that are sourced from countries that have mined those materials through the use of slavery. This is a hugely beneficial measure. I pay tribute to my colleagues, and to colleagues across the Chamber who have worked collaboratively on this, but crucially also to the millions of citizens who have contacted us and urged us to take action.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: - Madam president. Police station. Tomorrow I will vote 'yes' on a single regulation, because it obliges direct European importers of gold, tungsten, tin and tantalum to ensure that they do not come from mines controlled by armed groups or from areas affected by serious human rights conflicts. We have a moral duty to prevent the trade in these blood minerals, essential in the manufacture of our mobiles, cars or washing machines. This Regulation is a clear example of how European trade policy acts in defense of human rights. Against Trump, who has just announced that he will repeal the law that regulates him since 2010 because it hurts the profits of his industry. But a great challenge remains. The great challenge that Socialists will continue to work on is to guarantee its effectiveness with good accompanying measures. Because, if it is found that the obligated companies evade the application of the Regulation or that the exempted companies are not voluntarily accepted, or that the legislation has pernicious effects for the mining populations, we will demand that the obligation be fulfilled and extended to one hundred percent. A big step forward, but a way to go.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, "blood minerals" - as it has just been said - are everywhere and nowhere. They are everywhere, because they are the source of violent conflicts in Africa, but also in Asia. They are ubiquitous in everyday consumer products and, at the same time, they are invisible to European consumers. I believe that we have fully played our role, both because we have imposed this duty of care, but also because - this has not been said until now - we have responded to the call of our African partners who requested our support and, finally, because we have taken into account this new trend of European consumers, who want to make their consumption a citizen act, and when I see the representative of the National Front who speaks of good feelings - this is not what we are talking about, we are playing politics. Of course, there are some regrets - Mrs Maria Arena has said this - we would have liked compulsory certification throughout the chain, but we had to go through the narrow doors of compromise. I nevertheless think that it is a good text and we can be proud of the work accomplished, because at a time when the United States, in fact, unravel the Dodd-Frank law, we have shown the way, that of a Europe that was true to its values.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Who wants to buy products that contain violence and exploitation, so to speak? The regulation on conflict minerals ensures a more responsible trade in raw materials. Its purpose is to ensure that recyclable materials imported into the EU do not finance armed conflicts or human rights violations. This is why European companies have to be accountable for where they source the raw materials tungsten, tantalum, tin and gold. These minerals are mainly used in everyday objects such as laptops and smartphones. The European importers, refineries and smelters have to comply with their duties of care and transparency. Unfortunately, this does not yet affect the entire supply chain. It is our responsibility to end exploitation and violence in resource-rich countries and to promote fair and controlled trade with these regions. The regulation is a big step in the right direction.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this regulation finally puts an end to abuses and violations of human rights and above all to the link between conflicts and the illegal exploitation of certain minerals. So-called "conflict minerals" undermine government policies geared towards socio-economic development, good governance, the rule of law and the protection of human rights. It is important to have greater transparency and to have established due diligence in the supply chain for importers of certain minerals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas. Responsible importers should only source from smelters and refineries audited by third parties. The obligation of traceability is a great achievement and the same voluntary approach will motivate the participation of responsible companies and their number will gradually increase as a result of competitive and market pressures. In this regard, I think it is necessary to provide adequate incentives: importers, foundries and refineries who decide to make further efforts must have the opportunity to benefit from it in terms of image, perhaps through the publication of lists containing indications of importers, foundries and refineries. .

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, History has shown that wars and civil wars in the world, and especially in Africa, are largely done in order for the warring parties to seize the region's wealth and raw materials. ISIS has made huge profits from the sale of oil, so we need to enact legislation that covers all natural resources, not just the four ores. Let's not forget the so-called bloody diamonds and the death trade. In addition, the legislative proposal should concern all the companies involved and all the chains of the companies involved. At the same time, mining conditions must be set. For many years now, the Union has turned a blind eye to human and labor rights violations and to the problems faced by people working in mining. Many of them are young children. There are no safety conditions for these workers, so the European Parliament must act immediately and decisively.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, human rights are routinely violated in the extractive industries, which may include child labor, sexual violence, enforced disappearances, forced removals and the destruction of ritually and culturally important sites.
