Consumers are thus indirectly linked to conflicts that have serious implications for human rights, and in particular the rights of women and children, through the purchase of certain minerals and metals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas. Armed groups often use mass rape as a considered strategy to intimidate and control the local population in order to protect their interests. This is a truly inhuman practice that must be stopped, and I am very pleased that the EU is acting on this. However, companies trading in these materials must also be aware of their responsibility for the state of our world and act accordingly. And I firmly believe that, since it only concerns four minerals, we will continue this effort, because, as the predecessors said, there is a lot that is causing innocent people to die.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - So the adoption of this regulation will be an important moment.We would, of course, be even happier if this regulation were even more complete, if it had fewer exceptions, and if it actually listened to all those proposals that were also submitted in these lengthy negotiations.Nevertheless, this regulation communicates that we care, care for people, for children, for women who work in impossible conditions, who actually leave their lives for the profits of corporations, which then also finance conflicts, wars andand arming gangs.It is up to us, of course, to limit this, to break these chains, not to support the growing number of victims of all these conflicts, and of course competition cannot be above human rights, it cannot be above human dignity and not even basic human valuewe must do everything we can to put an end to this.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union is the biggest trader of the world; the biggest importer and the biggest exporter. So you are absolutely right: with that size comes a great responsibility and over the years this House has played an important role to raise awareness about the important issue of trade in conflict minerals. Thanks to your engagement and many people’s hard work here, very soon players in the mineral supply chain across the world are more aware of their obligations. We will continue to work in awareness-raising, including in small and medium size and even micro companies from the Commission’s side.  The legislation represents a major contribution to a modern trade policy, promoting values, shaping globalisation and ensuring that economic development is also sustainable. The link between minerals and financing conflicts is not acceptable in the world today; too many people have suffered. Soon we will have in place an effective and workable EU system to break this cycle; and this will benefit all those who have suffered including many children and women. It will benefit those who have seen their lives blighted, their futures falling apart because of war and instability linked to illicit trade in minerals. We have taken note of your views here. We will continue to engage with you on the monitoring and implementation of this regulation. It is not perfect, but it is a very important step forward and, as was mentioned, we also have a lot of accompanying measures in order to make this work. So thank you very much for the hard work done by the rapporteur, shadow rapporteurs, involved committees and others.

name: Iuliu Winkler
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you for this debate and listening to it, I grow even more and more convinced that we have a good piece of legislation on the table. Now we just have to implement this regulation. We have to make full use of all the provisions of the new conflict minerals regulation.  I believe the European Union has to maintain its leading position in the world as a promoter of development and peace. We believe that legal trade is good and that trade is meant to sustain jobs and prosperity for people and for communities. I believe that the new conflict minerals regulation will make a difference regarding the safety and prosperity of people and communities in conflict areas. Today, more than ever European well-being is interlinked with stability, peace and sustainable economic growth in all regions of the world including those regions which today are conflict areas or war zones. There is one thing that I believe we can do immediately, distinguished colleagues, tomorrow we can show the determination of the European Parliament to ensure a clean and sustainable mineral supply chain. We have hammered out an effective and workable regulation now let us show everybody that we are determined to make this first step. Let us ensure tomorrow a big majority vote and then let us start this whole process.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday March 16, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The new regulation that is going to be voted on is an important step since it will make it possible to know the origin of the direct import to the EU of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold. It is certainly much better than having nothing. We know that the extractive industry is unfortunately one of the sectors where the most human rights violations are recorded, including child exploitation, as well as being a source that finances corruption, mafia organizations or arms trafficking. However, the measures are insufficient. The European Commission, the Member States and even the right in this House could do much more to ensure that the provenance of all manufactured products complies with international standards of respect for human rights. This is also the case for mining and importing coal from third countries. The Commission itself recognized in its answer to one of my questions that the European Union does not control the origin of coal and that only some companies report on a voluntary basis. It is intolerable to plan the death of the mining sector while, at the same time, we encourage the energy sector to consume coal of doubtful origin. Not everything goes to import cheaper.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The order calls the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the revision of the regulation on the statute and the financing of European political parties and European political foundations, by Danuta Maria Hübner, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (O-000007/2017 - B8-0205 / 2017) (2017/2550 (RSP)).

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: author. – Madam President, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs of the European Parliament the revision of the regulation on the statute and funding of European political parties and European political foundations is indeed a matter of urgency. You probably know that a year ago the Presidents of three European political parties – the European People’s Party, the Party of European Socialists and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe – asked the Commission in a letter to present a legislative proposal amending this regulation. Since the beginning of this year, this regulation is now fully applicable. The Presidents requested the Commission to examine and initiate a review of the regulation on three substantial provisions related to efficiency, credibility and legitimacy. Those are the reduction to 7.5% of the 15% co—financing obligation, the increase of the minimum representation in the European Parliament to three members to qualify for receiving public funding, and the prevention of cross—party membership. In the reply the President of the Commission, though giving preference to first gathering some experience on the implementation of the regulation, also stated that the Commission was open to discussing the issues raised by the three co-signatories representing the main existing European political parties. In the meantime, Parliament’s Secretary—General also presented the report to the Bureau of the Parliament. We proposed three amendments, but there are many more issues that require reflection, for example  the possibility of limiting contributions in kind, allowing for the possibility to finance referendum campaigns or to provide for an assessment of the financial capacity of the parties before any application for funding, to mention just a few. After intense discussions, my committee, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, decided to present this oral question in order to raise awareness of this important issue. Let me say that we see that the new regulation ensures greater transparency and accountability of European political parties. However, there are shortcomings that need to be addressed. Let us be clear about one thing: this oral question is not about asking for more money, but for the money to be spent efficiently, correctly and with respect for the values of the European Union.  This is not about banning parties with critical opinions on the Union. We believe in democracy, and in a democratic system every person is entitled to freedom of speech and opinion. However, those who do not respect European values as they are stated in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union, and engage in clear racist, undemocratic and discriminatory actions and behaviour, should not fund their actions with European funds.  We may understand the Commission’s reluctance to initiate a revision of a regulation whose implementation has just started. However, I would also like to remind the Commission that, on a number of occasions, it stated very clearly that incentives for speculative behaviour should under no circumstances be granted. In our view it is becoming more and more evident from cases brought to our attention by the press that abuses with, and also misuse of, European funds are happening far too often. The shortcomings that have been signalled in the oral question should be swiftly addressed, in our view, in order to guarantee that the highest standards of probity are respected. We should indeed reflect whether one—man parties really contribute to forming European political awareness and expressing the political will of citizens of the Union.  But, besides elections, referenda are also an important instrument to express the will of the population in a democratic, organised and well—informed way. The current regulation prohibits any funding linked to referendums. It makes it impossible for parties and foundations to take positions in public on issues of fundamental importance for the future of citizens. This is in clear contradiction with the European Parliament’s position expressed in its resolution of 6 April 2011 on the European political parties’ participation in referendum campaigns when the referendums concerned are directly linked to issues relating to the European Union. We could reflect whether it would not be advisable to allow funding referendum campaigns on issues relating to the European Union where political parties can help form European political awareness. We would therefore like to hear from the Commission about its intentions, and we also urge it to react quickly to our request if this possible revision is to be, preferably, adopted before the next European elections in 2019. This regulation falls under the codecision procedure, so I would also like to ask the Commission whether it could inform Parliament on any exchanges it has undertaken with the Council in order to evaluate the openness of the other co—legislator towards this possible revision. I regret that we cannot ask the Council this question directly.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is an important question. The Commission is a strong supporter of a vibrant, dynamic system of political parties active in a European-level public space. This is important in our European Union based on democracy, as we have just heard. It contributes to the democratic foundations of our work together, including some of the bases for the election of the Commission President and the appointment of the Commission. We therefore welcome the opportunity to discuss the question of European political parties and foundations today, in particular – as has just been noted – the regulation adopted by Parliament and the Council in November 2014 is now coming into effect. The new regulation brings into play important innovations. These include a European-level legal personality for parties and foundations, and a more robust set of governance arrangements, including a new authority for European political parties and foundations, and enhanced safeguards to ensure respect for fundamental European values by all parties registered under the scheme. On this last point, it is now a condition for registration as a European party or foundation that the entity concerned respects, both in its programme and in its activities, the values on which the European Union is founded: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, and respect for human rights, including the right of people belonging to minorities. This clarity is most welcome.  Furthermore, at any time after registration, Parliament, the Council or the Commission may ask the new authority to verify whether a particular party or foundation continues to comply with these requirements. After consulting a new permanent committee of independent eminent persons, the authority can decide to deregister a party or foundation which is found not to comply, unless Parliament or the Council disagrees. This is an important standing safeguard. So the new regulation is a welcome and substantive improvement to the rules governing political parties and a good defence instrument for our European values. Beyond this, the Commission has taken good note of the suggestions for further possible changes to the regulation, which are outlined in the oral question in front of us today (the initiative of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs). We take these suggestions very seriously. Even good rules can be further improved. The Commission is fully prepared to assist Parliament with well-reflected initiatives and proposals. Of course, in line with our better regulation principles, our normal practice – as you know – is to evaluate existing legislation before proposing changes, and to assess fully the potential impact of such changes. As President Tajani always says, quality is often as important as speed. I am pleased that the regulation includes a very early review clause with first Parliament and then the Commission being obliged to report on its implementation in the coming months. The Commission’s report will be accompanied by proposals for any legislative changes that appear necessary. The Commission is more than willing to engage, in depth, with Parliament and the Council to monitor closely the early stages of implementing the new regulation and to reflect together on whether early proposals for change might be justified.  The Commission will be very open, if you agree, to setting up quickly an interinstitutional process – perhaps under the auspices of the new authority – to review developments, assess suggestions from stakeholders, and hopefully converge on a common approach. This would also help pave the way for the formal reviews that must in any case take place next year.  Turning to the specific suggestions, I would like to share some initial comments while stressing again that the Commission rules nothing out at this stage. First, on reducing the co-financing requirement. In 2012, the Commission, taking up a request from Parliament, proposed just such a change. Unfortunately, this met with strong opposition in the Council and was not included in the final text adopted by the co-legislators. As things stand, it is not clear that a new proposal on these lines would meet a different fate. Second, on increasing the level of representation required in this House before applying for EU funding. We need to consider carefully the principles of proportionality and equal treatment, since the rules on party funding should not tilt the balance in favour of incumbents, compared with new political movements, provided of course these new movements also uphold European values. Third, on cross-membership. The issue here is whether MEPs from a national party which is affiliated to a European party should be able to be members, on an individual basis, of different European parties. The new regulation already makes clear that in such circumstances, the individual membership does not count towards the representation threshold for funding of a European party. Could a similar restriction apply to the threshold for registration? We can think about it and examine the potential consequences. On the other hand, we are not aware of an objective basis for limiting choices of MEPs in this regard when their national party is not affiliated to a European one. Fourth, is the question of whether European parties should be able to finance campaigns for national referendums on EU issues. The Commission would like to hear the views of Parliament and Member States on this important but sensitive matter. As concerns several more technical issues such as a financial capacity criterion, we are happy to take a closer look. Parliament could also see how far its own implementing rules could be adjusted to help within the framework of the existing regulation.  Finally, we see many arguments against allowing reserve-building by parties and foundations. This would seem to go against the budgetary principles of annuality and sound financial management, and would increase risks to the control of EU contributions by making it more difficult to identify and correct possible irregularities. It would make it more likely that, should there be irregular spending, it would have to be recovered after European elections rather than before, which could prove sensitive for reasons we can all imagine. So at this stage, we continue to think the existing n+2 rule strikes the right balance. As I said, the Commission is keen to engage on all these issues with Parliament and with the Council, so we look forward to hearing all of your views in today’s debate.

name: György Schöpflin
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would particularly like to thank the Commissioner for a very thorough exposition of the Commission’s position. I think we can all agree on two things: without political parties democracy as we currently understand it is inconceivable. The running of political parties requires ever greater outlays in order to ensure that voters are properly informed of their choices. So if politics is a costly pastime, say, at the Member State level, how much more expensive is it at the European level? And as far as this Parliament is affected it is this European level that matters.  What we are focusing on today is the statute and funding of European political parties and European political foundations. When it comes to funding, the European political parties are currently required to secure 15% of their financing from their own resources. In the light of experience, this 15% should be reduced and the appropriate regulation be amended accordingly.  Then the definition of a European political party should be looked at again. Currently such a party can claim support from Parliament on the basis of having one elected MEP. This seems too low a threshold and should well be increased.  Finally, there is the perplexing situation where the European Parliament ends up financing parties or foundations that proclaim values entirely at variance with those of the European Union and indeed European integration. In a democracy the voicing of such views, repellent or otherwise, can be acceptable but it really is hard to see why the European Parliament should be subsidising political forces that are trying to ensure that it is eliminated. So, turkeys voting for an early Christmas? Well, not exactly, but I can see a certain family resemblance.

name: Claudia Țapardel
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the parties have a very important role to play in the current political context, and I am convinced that all the European institutions are aware of this. The regulation on the status and funding of European political parties and foundations needs to be revised and I am glad that the largest groups in the European Parliament have decided to ask the Commission to correct some problematic issues. To begin with, I am referring to the 15% of the obligation to finance the budget of European parties and foundations, which must be reduced. Maintaining this requirement will lead to budgetary constraints for European parties and foundations at a time when they should be active in countering growing Euroscepticism. In general, European parties receive this amount either from the parties in the national states, through the contributions of their own members, or from the national governments. However, it must be borne in mind that the number of party members across Europe is declining and funding from national governments has been reduced in most Member States. One argument for which we cannot postpone the revision of the regulation is also the approach of the European election in 2019, and a large-scale campaign can ensure the increase of interest and turnout of citizens. This also implies the need to fund the campaign of the candidates proposed for the post of President of the European Commission. The funding of other campaigns and referendums with an impact at European level must also be considered. In conclusion, although they are in great need of funding, European parties do not have sufficient funds. In addition, in order to increase transparency and prevent abuses, a Member of the European Parliament should be a member of a single European political party. Last but not least, the requirement for representation in the European Parliament a parties receiving funding.In order to prevent the fragmentation of the European political scene, the number of representatives in Parliament of a European party must be increased to a minimum of three.It is obvious that the resources that parties and foundations have to share under this regulation are limited, and hence the following situation: the more parties and foundations we have, the less funds each will receive.Dear colleagues, we need to make sure that parties and foundations will be able to finance their activities, while respecting all the rules of transparency in spending public funds.We therefore call for a revision of the existing regulation in the interests of both the European parties and the European Union as a whole.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Madam President!I am also glad that the regulations governing the financing of political parties and European foundations will be reviewed.I would like this review to be based on the right, reliable criteria.In short, we have the right and even a duty to fight pathology, but under the pretext of fighting pathology, we must not violate the political freedom of political parties and their independence.If the facts of corruption are known - they should be revealed, if the facts about the existence of fictitious European parties are known - they should be revealed and we should consider how to counteract it.But the whole regulation should be conducive to freedom and political pluralism, and parties with a positive mission, functioning without any problems, without pathology should enjoy unhindered freedom and support from European institutions.Fighting pathology - yes, but protecting freedom.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, public funding for European political parties is of the utmost importance for the rule of law, but it generates conflicting tensions within the democratic system. On the one hand, public subsidies to parties lessen the need for their private financing, and, consequently, the propensity for corruption, that is to say for the making of public decisions in exchange for payments or private advantages. But, on the other hand, the public financing of the parties generates an enormous aptitude to transform the political struggle into a professional activity, which becomes attractive because of its remunerations and personal benefits and not for its intrinsic purposes of public service and citizenship. The professionalization of political activity has the most damaging consequence of the overlap or prevalence of the professional interests of political agents over the collective interests of the citizens they represent. In addition, this professionalization favors cloudiness and opacity and not transference. Transparency not only in the allocation of funds, but also in the way in which political parties spend these funds. The best answer to prevent these dangers is more in the creation of mechanisms that effectively guarantee this transparency, as well as the effective public scrutiny of party spending, than in giving in to populist pressures or drives to reduce or hinder access to public funding by European democratic parties. European taxpayers' money will only be well spent if it is used only to achieve the public ends that determined the collection of taxes from citizens. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149 (8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Marinho, would you agree with me that the limiting of the freedom of speech and what people can say – no matter how appalling it may be, and I would go to the barricades personally to defend the rights of no matter whom, communists, fascists, anyone to say what they want to say – do you think that limiting the freedom of speech, and people in this Parliament making decisions about what is correct and what is not correct, and what is part of the European project and what is not part of the European project – do you not feel that this means the lights of liberty and freedom of speech are going out all over Europe, and this place cannot call itself the mother of European democracy?

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE)
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- I am an indefectible defender of freedom of expression and I have been for over fifty years, since I know myself as a citizen, first against the fascist dictatorship in Portugal and then against other attempts to limit it.On this principle, Mr. Coburn, I adopt Montesquieu's maxim, or Voltaire's best, according to which, although I do not agree with anything you say, I will beat myself with all my strength so that you can say itin freedom.Freedom of expression is the twin sister of responsibility and the abuses that can be committed in the political struggle in the area of freedom of expression must be combated politically and not administratively or through the courts.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! It is an unusual occurrence that European political parties want to have a regulation changed that is supposed to regulate their work, but has not yet come into force at the time of the complaint. I see two reasons for this: firstly, the ignorance of the rapporteur at the time, who made it very difficult in the last parliamentary term to successfully negotiate the dossier with the Council on a substantial basis. On the other hand, the framework conditions for the action of the European political parties are currently changing significantly, and new objectives are also emerging. It would be natural for the European Parliament to work out a position here. But there is still no such common opinion. The following questions therefore also remain unanswered: Do we really want European political parties to intervene in open political processes in member states? Do we really want parties that have been granted substantial funds to claim even more, on the assumption that they cannot raise their own funds? What new political requirement has arisen to allow the latter to be defined with regard to the prohibition of the profit purpose? In view of the diverging dynamics in the EU, I think it is more important to look at where the European political parties stand with the newly granted rights. And I have listened to you very carefully, Commissioner. You raised many substantial questions. What constructive contribution are you making to the future of the EU? However, this is a political issue and is beyond the regulatory responsibility of the Commission. So where are the initiatives to expand the European Parliament's right of initiative and investigation?

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, five points:  1. We are very reluctant to initiate a revision of a regulation which just entered into force two months ago and without a proper assessment. In fact the review clause is foreseen for the new regulation in 2018; there is no need for a revision now. 2. The main concern of some colleagues is to prevent the misuse of European funds, which has been detected as a practice of some extreme right wing parties; we completely agree with that. Mainly, we have to make it impossible for cross membership of MEPs belonging to the same party. We have to avoid being cheated by them. However, some of the proposals may put at risk the existence and funding of small pro-European parties; not to count members of the regional parliaments as elected members of a European party would also be negative as a representation contagion. We have to include them, since some measures would harm the political diversity and representation of citizens.  3. We agree with the reduction of the cofinancing obligation under 15%. Please Commissioner, try again.  4. The proposal to increase the number of MEPs in order to register and finance as an EU party could eliminate small groups in the Chamber.  5. We need to accomplish all with our democratic duties, all the parties.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, democracy is democracy is democracy. The true test of the strength of your commitment to democracy is what happens when people start expressing views that you do not like. We have heard some pretty awful examples, frankly, of the expression of freedom of speech right here. This House contains everything from communists to fascists – vile views from far-right to far-left. When we hear things like Korwin-Mikke’s views on women and equal rights, I do not want to defeat them through suppression and penalties. I want them to be defeated at the ballot box. When we hear communism or fascism expressed in this Chamber, or frankly anywhere else, I want it defeated in public democratic debate.  And so it is, I think with the European political parties. Weber wants to state-fund them, but only if he likes their views of the European Union. Well, state-funding views that you like and suppressing those that you do not that is not Voltaire. That is Orwell.  I think a lot of people who are pro-EU fear eurosceptic views and fear the popularity of eurosceptic views. But you cannot stop an idea whose time has come, and our time came on 23 June last year. I always try to take a broader perspective, to ask what it would be like if the boot was on the other foot. I just wonder, from the UK, I am a unionist, but could you imagine the uproar if the British government had treated the Scottish nationalists in this way? I do not agree with their secessionist mantra, but is the right of the people of Scotland to decide their own future, as they recently did in a referendum. If we in the UK treated the Scottish nationalists in the way that this place treats eurosceptics, then the people would be up in arms. It is a testament to how ineffective those European political parties are that nobody even notices. I would rather scrap them altogether, stop pouring taxpayers’ money at it. Which is it going to be: Orwellian groupthink or democracy?  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to thank the President very much.We had a direct democratic decision in Great Britain: the people decided with a small majority to leave democracy in Europe.Now I would like to ask you: why are you still here in this house?Why are you still making speeches here when it was decided in a direct vote that you would leave democracy in Europe?And here you want to teach us about democracy - I would like to ask: What is the background?

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, you say a minority but, of course, a majority voted in the United Kingdom to leave the European Union. If you want to know why we are still here, I think that is a question that should be put to Theresa May and to the British Government, which still has not got round to invoking Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty. It is not our fault that the Government is dragging its heels, and it is not our fault that the Government is taking so long, but every day that we are still here, we are still paying into the EU budget. We have recently talked in this House about guidelines for the 2018 EU budget. We are going to be paying for that through our taxes, and so of course we have a right to have our say.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - As the ENF Group, we are very concerned, not about the technical provisions, which we can agree with and which are an improvement of the system. We are concerned about this political provision which is included here in very general terms. “Fundamental values” is the term that is applied to something that we fear will immediately be applied by people like Manfred Weber and his associates to the way the ENF can function politically. No conditions other than technical requirements may be attached to those conditions, never political conditions. We will not be able to approve that provision unless we have guarantees that we may remain EU critical, that we may also remain critical with regard to the substantive policy of the European Union, in particular immigration policy, and that this provision is not used here to make our operation impossible. Based on our eligibility and our being elected, we are just as entitled to that money as anyone else here.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, within the last 24 hours, the most shocking action that I have ever seen in this Parliament has happened. This is quite blatantly an attempt to block other countries from following the route that the United Kingdom took with Brexit, and it is an attack on free speech and views expressed there. Now you can try to shut down what you believe to be the eurosceptic oxygen that this Parliament has, in terms of the ENF Group, the EFDD Group, and people like myself who stand as ‘non—inscrit’ and want to make the points that we continually do. Bear in mind where the frustration and the irritation comes from within voters. There are two points: one is that this institution, and the Council and the Commission, have shown themselves to be completely incapable of considering a change of direction or of invoking any change. That frustration and irritation leads to a eurosceptic voice that seeks representation in this Parliament. This Parliament has no right to start redrawing a map in terms of funding and resourcing just because it wants to shut down euroscepticism across the European continent. Now whether we like it or not, Brexit has happened and it could well be that the Netherlands follow suit, or that France takes a position on withdrawal from the euro, for instance. To try to block individuals – citizens – who have got every right for representation in this Parliament, is just absolutely unacceptable.

name: Rainer Wieland (PPE).
text: - Madam President! To comment briefly on the previous speaker: I hope that all of what the previous speaker understands by eurosceptic oxygen will not have to be experienced as nationalistic nitrogen that is coming our way. In the present debate we will certainly continue to have long discussions about what the requirements for a party should be from an immaterial point of view. I advocate that we eliminate the serious manual errors that Mr. Scholz correctly pointed out. The point is that we should no longer allow MEPs who have run and been elected for a national party and who are not part of any European structure to cheerfully set up one structure after the other. It has already been shown that this is being done, and we have to put a stop to it. In future, it should no longer be possible for a single MP from the second or third national level to be sufficient to found a party who just claims they will run in the next European elections. These are undesirable developments that we should not tolerate. We should also make it clear that those who use the money incorrectly - I do not mean to say fraudulently - must also be able to claim the money back, and that we do not then find out that the party is no longer there or is insolvent. It was therefore an important step today that the European Court of Justice considered it permissible for this House to demand bank guarantees in the given case, and in the justified case, in order to ensure that we get back money that was misused. And finally, one last thought: in the referendums, I do not believe that we should pretend that we are aseptic beings and that we can use a scalpel to tear apart party activities at the political level like a filet. That won't work - we should have political parties can have.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Madam president. I join the request that the Regulation must be reformed, and I am going to do so clearly saying that we have already verified that there are foundations and political parties, which are fascist in nature, that are taking advantage of European money. And I am opposed to that. Because it is one thing for democracy to respect all political wills and pluralism, which is evident: democracy is the defense of minorities. But, attention, attention, not all ideologies are respectable and not all political objectives are legitimate, ladies and gentlemen. I think we have to make it very clear that there are ideologies of hate, that there are ideologies of intolerance, that there are ideologies that discriminate against people, that there are ideologies that defend violence, and that cannot be allowed in a democracy. And my argument for that reform is that we do not allow European money to be taken advantage of. Clearly, I want to make it very clear. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for allowing me that. With all due respect, you are obviously a socialist and left wing, and I do not agree with your views at all, but I would die to defend your right to say what you want to say. I mean that quite clearly. I would go to the barricades to defend freedom of speech. Now, who are you to say what is respectable and what is not respectable? When does that become ‘statethink’? When does that become an Orwellian nightmare? I have a great fear. We are leaving this place and we have the House of Commons, but I fear that this place is going to turn into something bad. Could you tell me why that is not the case?

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: "blue card" response.- There are mechanisms in the law to establish what is respectable or not, but I want to make it very clear that I will also die to defend your ideas, to defend that you can say them.What I cannot allow is that the antidemocratic virus, which questions the values that the civic soil of the European Union has built, is questioned by the ideologies that combat hatred or discrimination.I cannot admit that a person, on behalf of a party, says that the one who killed fifty or eighty socialists on an island in Norway was doing the right thing.I cannot allow that.And this is what is at stake right now.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I have the honour of speaking here as the President of one of those European political parties, the Alliance of European Conservatives and Reformists (ACRE), which is the youngest, yet fastest growing, party. It is a serious party and a real party with the third largest group in the European Parliament. I am proud to say that, since our foundation in 2009, we have always been very cautious and careful in spending public money according to Parliament’s rules. Every year we have been audited without a single objection. Every year our books have been closed and approved by all relevant authorities: the external auditor, DG Finance and Parliament’s Bureau as well. We did not sign the letter of the three parties concerned, but we have absolutely no problem with all the provisions proposed. I will maybe just make one final remark. We are a pro-European party but an anti—federalist party. For instance, we do not agree with what Mr Verhofstadt thinks about the European Union and we do not agree with what the CDU-CSU from Germany says about the future of the European Union, but I firmly believe that different opinions on the course of the future of the EU will not be misinterpreted and misused in a political fight. Please consider this seriously.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: –  Madam President, you know why it has become necessary to review that? Because we have found that over the last one to two years there have been several parties – European parties and European foundations – that have found loopholes in our regulation. So it is necessary to do that. They have been doing things that are illegal and that are now under scrutiny.  Let me just answer some of the questions you had, Commissioner. One is that I think we have to prevent cross-party membership. It has been said already. There have been MEPs from one Member State party who have been supporting two different European parties, getting funding for both of them. This has to stop.  On another [matter you raised], I think, and I am not alone in this, that we have to publish the names of those elected members, of the European Parliament – that is [already] published – but also of national and regional ones who are members of the European political parties, because we are elected people and we are public. It is not about privacy. This is about knowing who makes up the European parties.  You asked about national referendums. No, I am against allowing national referendums to be held, because the Brexit campaign was a national campaign; you had one in Hungary; we had one against refugees; we have had several. We cannot allow that. European referendums, yes, but not national. And the last one, I think we have to stick to one MEP making up a European party, that is not... If we go further than that, this is not how to prevent abuse if we make it more than that. One is fine.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, any functioning democracy needs the rule of law to exist. Without legal certainty there is no rule of law. What we are currently witnessing from the EU institutions is legal uncertainty. What is allowed to some is banned to others. All eurosceptic parties and foundations at European level, either from the left or the right, have fallen victim to reinterpretation of the existing regulation with retrospective effect. Spending that was allowed to the EU federalist organisations were forbidden to others. Some civil servants have admitted being put under political pressure, and members of the bureau in charge of these matters have leaked confidential documents to the press before the recipient has received them. Therefore, before reviewing the regulation on the funding of pan-European parties, you should ensure that the existing regulations are observed and applied with fair treatment, respecting political diversity and allowing freedom of expression. Those attempts to silence the opposition in the only democratic institution of the EU are very worrying indeed, and this can only reinforce the anti-EU sentiment that is growing amongst our constituencies.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: - Madam President! A colleague from EPP said that he sees certain similarities here with Turkey. I can also tell you that I see certain similarities with Turkey in the course of this discussion. Because where do you want to go with this initiative? And - it has to be said clearly - this is about tax money. It is not about money coming from the EPP or the socialists, but about tax money from the Member States, and therefore transparency is definitely necessary. But where is this journey going? Ms. Huebner is not as clear about this as her own parliamentary group chairman, Mr. Weber, who says quite clearly: no EU funds to finance parties critical of the EU. What does this mean? That is the real aim of this discussion, which is behind it: no more EU funds for EU-critical parties. That means nothing else than that you want to silence the opposition here. I can tell you that I dread this understanding of democracy. And once again a new authority is to be created, once again with taxpayers' money from the Member States. I am telling you very clearly: the millions of voters who vote for parties critical of the EU are just as entitled to it as the millions of other voters who do not. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – I think there may be a misunderstanding; I do not know if the honourable gentleman heard me correctly. I talked about turkeys, the birds, not Turkey, the country.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Then it was a misunderstanding.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I want to support the initiative of my colleagues in the committee. I also believe that the regulation should be reviewed and some of the things that colleagues will point out here should be removed. There was a debate about the definition of a European political party that could be abused. There was a debate about whether one Member could be a member of more than one political party. These are practical problems that are now emerging, and even if the regulation is valid for a relatively short time, we should not wait and leave these problems alone, because the rules governing political party funding must be transparent, fair and their quality reflects the quality of the political system. . However, I have one specific reservation or one particular concern that has been mentioned here, and that is the question of freedom of expression. The proposals to be examined include the issue of tightening control over how European political parties respect the EU's fundamental values. I am not one of the Members who think that political parties that are skeptical of the EU should not receive money. I think that they should receive money from the European budget as part of the debate that is taking place here on Parliament's premises on individual proposals on the degree of integration within the EU. But those political parties that deny the values ​​of democracy, the values ​​of human rights, the basic universal values ​​on which European civilization stands, not just the EU, should not, in my view, receive money from the EU budget. So I see a difference: criticizing the EU on the one hand and denying the fundamental values ​​of humanity, democracy and human rights on the other. In the event that someone does not receive money, I still think that the refusal to pay money should be reviewed by an independent judiciary so that there is no political abuse and no political withdrawal of political competitors.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: - Madam President!The EU was founded more than 60 years ago.Nazism and fascism and war were to be thrown on the rubbish heap of history, but that did not happen.Colleague Schöpflin and a number of others have described the absurdity of the current situation - that we finance fascist activities with EU money.No one has suggested that freedom of opinion and expression should be curtailed in the slightest, but pouring European taxpayers' money over Holocaust deniers, fascists, Nazis is simply indecent.They have been financed under the old EU regulations.On 1 January this year, the new regulations came into force, but this means that they can continue to receive their money via the EU.I would like to ask you, Commissioner: When does the Commission intend to take these investments in fascism and Nazism seriously?

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I was a member of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs when in 2014 we approved this Regulation that regulated the financing of political parties and European foundations. Some of the problems that appeared then we bury them badly and, when something is buried badly, something usually resuscitates later. And we have to face these problems. Today we do not have sufficient guarantee that the European political parties receiving funding respect the fundamental values ​​of the Union. Today we are not sure whether, in order to obtain funding, a MEP belongs to more than one political party. Today we know that when European issues are confronted in a referendum, funding is appropriate to address the debate on that referendum. And today we know that we must remain firm in the defense of these European values, and that only those parties that respect them should have access to funding. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- You are aware that when the Lord talks about our money, about the money that the Lord gives to someone or possibly that this House gives, you are talking about the money of our citizens?This is their money, it is not your money.This is the money of all Europeans who have very different views, and the Lord should care about their freedom, so that they can exercise these views according to their beliefs.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: "blue card" response.- If it were my personal money, your party could not have any activity, because it would be frankly poor.I know that it is the money of European citizens and, therefore, I want that money not to defend, to finance political parties with behaviors that are not acceptable for the Union's values.Here's a mystification, throughout this debate.Ideas are never pursued.Behaviors are pursued.And those behaviors are not ideological.They have a racist character, because they consider some men superior to others, or because they consider one religion more true than another, or because they consider that there are human beings who have more rights.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President!I have the impression that Mr Guerrero Salom does not know my party at all, he does not know anything about its views, and he has expressed very categorical opinions on it.I would very much like to ask you to react to such manifestations of prejudices.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I want to say from the outset that I support this initiative. We need to re-examine the Regulation on the status and funding of political parties and foundations, and we have found in the debate that our colleagues on the right have either not read the proposal or do not want to understand it correctly. Nobody wants to shut the mouths of parties that have other ideas, they are Eurosceptics. However, we want only the parties that support European values ​​to be financed from the European Union budget, and I would ask my colleagues if they would have sales people in a company and would advocate for competition and not for company values. , would he keep them, would he pay them, would he still budget them? Parties have the right to self-finance. I also agree with the lowering of the ceiling and, most importantly, I think it is very appropriate not to have European parties with one member. I would say that three are few, but examine, Commissioner, and take action.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, it took years to complete the new regulation on European political parties. All stakeholders had many opportunities to engage in the process, including the largest parties. Now, even before the new rules are fully implemented, the large parties have decided that they want to change these new rules their way, without the mutual engagement of any other stakeholders in the report on the letter that the former oral question refers to. The new rules which have already been introduced measured new barriers for European parties, and that is good. This debate is an attempt to shut out smaller and new parties, which is against the spirit of the Treaty and the new regulation. Both large and small parties have abused funding, so higher barriers are no solution to that. The EU does not need less political involvement with the people, but more. This political involvement cannot be monopolised and covered by the large parties alone. It is necessary to first implement the new rules and then have the evaluation as already scheduled.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, I will first refer to something that was said by some colleagues: "defending the right of both the fascist and the communist to speak". How is it possible to bring to the same line a man who defends racist ideas intolerant ... and when did anyone hear here, in this room, either from a communist or from the left, any racist or intolerant talk? And I think we need to be more careful about that. I defend the view that there must be transparency. Everyone should have the right to speak, everyone should have the right to receive funds. Of course, it must be checked if he is defending racist and intolerant views, but I do not think that if anyone is defending the view that another European Union can replace the present one, a better, more prosperous and so on, we should exclude him from the financing.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we really should not be behaving like ostriches, expecting the problem to go away when we stick our heads into the sand. As Commissioner King said, the vibrant system of political parties is, of course, a cornerstone of parliamentary democracy. But I do not really think that political parties are a kind of endangered species – au contraire.  They are the only man-made organisations which are entitled to an endless windfall of public funds. But it should not be like that, because, as many colleagues have pointed out, it leads to abuse. Instead we should put parties – almost semi-divine organisations – onto an equal footing with other types of human organisations. Think of all sorts of NGOs, for instance. That is why I must quote Martin Luther here – ‘hier stehe ich’ – and demand the creation of a totally new system in which political parties could manage themselves only on the basis of membership fees, and that should be their only income. That kind of draconian remedy would end a vicious circle in which money – public and private – plays such an incredible and unbearable role in calling the shots in politics.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, this oral question is indeed an opportunity to stress the very important role of political parties in a democratic society. Without political parties, all individual adventures are possible and we unfortunately know where this can lead. Our European democracy is no exception to this rule. It must support representative European political parties, since public funding is also a guarantee of the independence and freedom of organizations. The political parties are there to enlighten opinion and the media, in order to promote the values ​​that are theirs, on human, economic, social issues, etc. They must have a real activity in order to be recognized as legitimate. Everyone here has mentioned Voltaire and indeed freedom of expression is part of our values, but also part of the constitutive elements of the rule of law, but the rule of law also guarantees respect for human values ​​and must punish acts of hatred, racism and intolerance.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is an important subject, which obviously elicits some strongly-held views. I have listened carefully and I will report fully to First Vice-President Timmermans and colleagues. I personally can understand that some people might have a philosophical objection to public funding of any sort for the political process. But it exists, albeit in different forms in most Member States, perhaps because the alternatives for funding the political system – relying on donations from individuals, from business or from interest groups – can also have disadvantages. So I do not think any of us should be surprised if a similar system exists at the European level. When it comes to funding from the EU budget, I would just observe that the existing legislation already includes safeguards regarding the respect by parties of fundamental values. As I said, when we talk about fundamental values, it is respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.  At the same time, as I said at the outset, the Commission is a strong supporter of having vibrant and dynamic political parties at the European level and is very ready to engage with you and with the Council to monitor how the 2014 regulation is working in practice in its first months of operation. We stand ready to engage constructively in such an interinstitutional process that can look at the issues in depth and could help pave the way for the formal reviews – which, as a number of people have noted, are slated for 2018 – and for drawing any necessary conclusions together about possible future developments.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: written. - It is necessary to improve some of the provisions of the Regulation on the status and financing of European political parties and European political foundations, approved in 2014, to ensure greater transparency and accountability of European political parties and a use of the European funds more efficiently and correctly. Therefore, a revision of the Regulation is necessary on several substantial provisions: the reduction to 7.5% of the co-financing obligation from 15%, the increase of the minimum representation in the European Parliament to three members in order to receive public funding and the possibility of financing campaigns for referendums. We Socialists have urged the Commission to reform the regulation to strengthen existing controls aimed at ensuring that European political groups respect the fundamental values ​​of the Union. We want to ensure that the European political parties receiving funding fully respect European values, as stipulated in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. With these changes, we do not intend to pursue critical opinions about the Union, but hateful and intolerant behaviors and ideologies that go against the values ​​of the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - Political parties at European level, as well as their respective institutions, must contribute to informing the citizens of the Union in order to understand the political, economic, social and cultural dimensions of cooperation between European states within the EU. They must also contribute to increase citizen participation in the European elections, as well as to develop a dialogue on the major issues of concern to European societies with particular emphasis on employment, social Europe and the equitable distribution of wealth. In addition, the funding received by political parties at European level and their institutions must be transparent and not abused or misused. The regulation on the financing of political parties at European level must be defined by a specific legal, financial and regulatory framework, increase funding efficiency, serve transparency and good governance. Any illegal funding and other illegal aid to political parties at European level should result in the cessation of their further funding and severe criminal and other sanctions against those responsible.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing.- The revision of the regulation on the statute and funding of European political parties and foundations at the request of the three largest European groups seems to be by all means justified.After all, it is about making European political parties more transparent and accountable.This money should be spent effectively and in line with the values of the Union, in line with Art.2 of the Treaty on European Union.Recently disclosed cases of abuse and even fraud are all too common.And although such practices are used by a few, they undermine voters' confidence in all politicians.I hope that the planned revision of the regulations governing the financing of political parties and European foundations will be carried out quickly and will be carried out on the basis of reliable criteria, using all the experience to date.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Michael Gahler and Esteban González Pons, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the proposal entitled 'Constitutional, legal and institutional implications of the common security and defense policy: the Lisbon Treaty' (2015/2343 (INI)) (A8-0042 / 2017).

name: Michael Gahler
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I am pleased that we are having this security and defense debate as part of our report. I would like to thank my colleague Gonzáles Pons and the shadow rapporteurs - thank you for the constructive cooperation. Given the deterioration in our security situation, it is imperative that we go boldly on the path to a European Defense Union. We must do more to better ensure the security and defense of our citizens and the EU as a whole. Russia's war in Ukraine, tensions in the Balkans and crumbling states in the southern neighborhood require it. Our transatlantic partners will only stand by their obligations to us if we do our part. The decision-making situation in the NATO framework is very ambitious. We cannot avoid additional spending, but at EU level better spending means using European procedures and also the EU budget intelligently. Even with more joint planning and procurement, a European Defense Union as a European pillar will strengthen the transatlantic alliance. Especially in our immediate neighborhood - in the Western Balkans or in North Africa - NATO is not necessarily the instrument with which our transatlantic partners want to be involved in these problem areas. With this report we are setting a new milestone on the way to common defense and a defense union. For years, the Commission and the Member States failed to make use of the security and defense policy possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty. We have pointed this out in the EP since the Treaty entered into force. For example, we are now looking forward to concrete proposals to implement the European Defense Action Plan and the Defense Fund. We want a reformed European Defense Agency and the one to be launched Establish permanent structured cooperation as EU institutions sui generis. This means nothing more than that we want to give these institutions access to EU procedures and funding. We are not militarizing the EU with this. What we are doing, however, is to improve the protection of our citizens and the Union by improving existing military capabilities with the help of EU instruments. Not we are waging a war in Ukraine, but Russia. We are not destabilizing the Sahel, Iraq and Syria, but Islamist terrorists. It is not us who play dangerous games in the Western Balkans - but we have to react if necessary. The Dayton Agreement with Bosnia-Herzegovina will not be guaranteed by the USA, if anyone questions it, we have to do it ourselves. We must finally put an end to the fact that the European Council and the Member States have decided that business as usual is simply going on. By this I mean parts of the summit resolutions on defense of 2013 and 2015 that have not yet been implemented. I ask you: where is the EU-wide system of security of supply? Where are the civil-military standards or common or at least mutually recognized certification rules for armaments? Why did the EP have to take action on defense research? And when does the Commission dare to put an end to the abusive application of Article 346 when Member States are undermining the internal market for defense equipment and bypassing the Europe-wide tender with the reference to a “requirement to safeguard essential security interests”? Most of the time, it is a matter of placing orders with one's own company despite higher costs at the expense of the taxpayer. There is an urgent need to start common defense, European capability and arms policy, as well as permanent structured cooperation and the Defense Agency to make it fit for future tasks with a reform.The Lisbon Treaty enables us to do this. Let us use what is possible and necessary, in the common interest.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: speaker. - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Michael Gahler for his tireless work on this report, as well as the shadow rapporteurs and officials from the committees and Parliament. Europe - including the UK - faces an uncertain and confusing international scene in the area of ​​security and defense. Fortunately, we seem to finally realize that taking on more responsibility is no longer a task of the future, but a requirement of the present. It seems that we have finally assumed that Europe has to be able to defend and protect itself - because they will not always come from outside to defend us - that we have to guarantee the permanence of our values ​​and the safety of our citizens. The report that we present today expresses the position of this Parliament to advance in the construction of a Europe of security and defense and reminds us that we cannot start the house with the roof. The Lisbon Treaty is a coherent and sufficient institutional framework to make our way. No new Treaties are needed. The problem is that, until now, we have not used it. Because - make no mistake - the little progress that has been made in European common defense to date depends only on the lack of political will of the States and not on the lack of legal instruments. That is why we ask the States to participate in the mechanisms of permanent structured cooperation and in the creation of an integrated European force, as provided for in the Protocol. We welcome the Commission's announcement of the launch of the first joint planning military barracks, which is also a demand of this report and which should serve as the embryo of the future European Union headquarters for its military operations. This report makes it very clear - and we also wanted it to make it very clear - that the Europe of common defense is not incompatible with NATO. What we analyze it's how we can better cooperate and complement NATO to be more efficient. The point is that we must consider how to participate in NATO, united or divided into twenty-seven parts. Uniting our defensive capacities instead of adding twenty-seven national policies would also suppose a great economic saving, because we are buying or investigating twenty-seven times the same thing. A saving that a report by this Parliament estimates between 26 and 130 billion euros. If we can spend together, shop together, and invest to research together, we will spend much less. More defense integration will also bring operational advantages, improve the competitiveness and functioning of the European defense industry, create jobs - this is important - and allow States to implement projects that they could not on their own, especially those that could not. they are the biggest. And coordination and information sharing will be improved, which are some of the most important pending tasks we have. In this report, we also claim that the European Defense Agency has full political, economic and operational support. I therefore ask for a vote in favor of this report, so that it can serve as a roadmap for the European Commission and also for the Rome Declaration next week, which has made security and defense one of its priorities. . The European Parliament must lead the search for a common defense and security project. We cannot move forward without all countries making a real commitment to do so; there are no excuses. Because there is no greater respect for national sovereignty, for the territorial integrity of each of our countries, than being able to defend jointly, each contributing the best it has. Common European defense is already an urgent matter on which the future of the Union also depends. No one is going to come back to defend us. We will have to defend ourselves from now on and, for that, the first thing is organize ourselves.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, today I am here speaking on behalf of High Representative Mogherini as she could not be in the Chamber for this debate. However, allow me to remark that the High Representative appreciates the work of Mr Gahler and Mr González Pons on the report, and her views and those of Parliament coincide in many areas. The report addresses critical issues that you have been working on during the implementation of the security and defence aspects of the EU Global Strategy (EUGS). The conclusions reached on the EUGS implementation define common strategic priorities and a common vision in security and defence and has set out how CSDP, as part of wider EU efforts, can contribute to tackling today’s and tomorrow’s multifaceted security challenges and protect European citizens. I know that High Representative Mogherini would like to underline, at the very beginning, that she attaches critical importance to working together with the European Parliament on defence issues as natural allies in this effort. As you know, on 6 March, High Representative Mogherini presented the progress achieved in the security and defence implementation of the EUGS to the Foreign Affairs Council. The Council conclusions adopted served as the first progress report to the March European Council according to the tasking received in December last year. On 9 March, the Heads of State and Government welcomed the work done and asked to continue with even greater determination and speed.  The High Representative is pleased to report that, despite very tight timelines, significant progress has been made since December. Currently there is work being done on the three pillars of the package: not only on the global strategic implementation of security and defence, but also on the European defence action plan from the Commission, EU-NATO cooperation and the follow-up to the Warsaw Joint Declaration. This work is even more important at a time when expectations and questions are raised more or less openly inside the European Union, as well as outside, about the EU’s commitment and ability to act as a security provider. There is no better answer to such expectations and questions than real, tangible progress on concrete issues. On military planning and conduct capability, the Foreign Affairs Council last week agreed to establish a permanent military planning and conduct capability for the European Union’s non-executive military missions. It will be established within the European Military Staff (EUMS) and will operate under the responsibility and command of the Director-General of the military staff. At present, there are three such missions: in Mali, Central African Republic and Somalia, which are currently only led by headquarters in the field. This decision will also contribute to enhanced civilian or military cooperation. Experts from the Military Planning and Conduct Capability (MPCC) and its civilian counterpart, the CPCC, will form a joint support coordination cell to facilitate mutual assistance and coordination. The new structure will be operational in the coming weeks. On defence cooperation: the European External Action Service also has a clear mandate from the European Council to strengthen defence cooperation. Ambitions need to be underpinned by sufficient resources, both nationally and at EU level. It is equally important to make more effective use of the defence budgets by reducing fragmentations. The 28 Member States, for example, have 154 weapons systems in use. The United States has only 27. Moreover, around 80% of defence investment in Europe is still spent on a national basis. In the report, reference is also made to the costs of non-European defence. The European Defence Agency is working hard to strengthen defence cooperation, and the Commission is also mobilising its instruments. It is clear that defence capabilities will remain Member State-owned. Progress in this field, through EU instruments, will also benefit NATO, as there will be a single set of forces. Therefore, these efforts will be pursued further in a way that ensures coherence with parallel work within NATO. It is important to note as well that any success will have an impact on transatlantic burden-sharing. But let us be clear: Europeans have to do this for themselves. This is about protecting our citizens. The main current efforts to deepen defence cooperation in developing capabilities are centred on the Coordinated Annual Review on Defence, permanent structured cooperation, as well as the European Defence Action Plan. The Coordinated Annual Review on Defence should be a Member States-driven mechanism. It will contribute to the increased transparency of national defence plans and help make cooperation the norm. Based on Member States’ guidance, a set of concrete modalities will be prepared. The Council has also been tasked with further work on the permanent structured cooperation, an important tool also highlighted in your report. Permanent structured cooperation is about enabling those Member States who are willing to undertake more binding commitments towards one another to do so. Countries wishing to be part of it will need to make concrete commitments and join concrete cooperation projects. While it is open to all Member States and maximum inclusiveness is pursued, there is no automaticity or a free ride. Permanent structured cooperation can help develop defence capabilities but also to pool and share existing military assets so that we can make more efficient use of them in our operations. Member States will work on the common commitments as well as the projects and initiatives they can provide to the permanent structured cooperation. These projects need to be ambitious and support the overarching aim of preparing the most demanding missions. On the European Defence Action Plan, it proposes actions to support Member States’ efforts in delivering capabilities through greater cooperation and fostering a strong, competitive and innovative European defence industrial base, including by setting up a European Defence Fund. These are very important initiatives that also show the added value of the European Union to enhance the effectiveness and the performance of our defence sector. Once again, on behalf of High Representative Mogherini, I would like to reiterate that further work on the EU battle groups will be undertaken, as these are key military assets. Yet the European Union has never deployed a battle group, despite the fact that it could have been useful on several occasions. This will be referred back to Council in May. There is also work to be done to improve situational awareness, reinforcing the structures that sustain these efforts, in particular the Intelligence and Situation Centre (INTCEN). On the capacity-building and support of security and development, a proactive approach is being promoted to identify concrete projects while supporting a positive outcome on the legislative process including the European Parliament. The report also highlights the importance of providing appropriate equipment to the forces that the EU trains. It is important to work together across the nexus security or development to achieve peaceful societies protected by armed forces under civilian control.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, not being able to establish a Europe of defense, the six founding countries opted for the common market. Sixty years after the signing of the Treaty of Rome, the time has come to put the defense project back on the table. In a world that has become dangerous, we expect Europe to protect us, in particular through military capacity. Our colleagues Gahler and Gonzáles Pons have brilliantly demonstrated that the advent of a common defense depends on the political will of our heads of state or government, and not on legal considerations. Now, what do we see? States which, for the most part, have neither the critical size nor the military tool adapted to the threats of the 21st century, but which are reluctant to choose efficiency and pooling, which are reluctant to make the choice from Europe. As proof of this, the preparatory action on defense research, for which we have budgeted for 2017 25 million, nibbled at the expense of other programs and pilot projects, 25 million where the Americans spend more than 60 billion. In the aftermath of the election of Donald Trump, at a time when the continental states are increasing their military capabilities, our defense future is European. A political dwarf, Europe must assert itself as a world power.

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, thank you and congratulations to our rapporteurs for this useful reminder that everything we should have already done is contained in a treaty which has been signed and ratified by all the Member States and whose implementation - we are sure. reports on it every day - is more than incomplete. Unfortunately, it takes Mr. Trump's statements for Europeans to wake up when all the parameters of the strategic equation already existed before Trump's election to warn us that if we don't do this job, for our own safety, no one will do it for us. So it really is time to wake up. However, I regret that the Member States are still dragging their feet. Obviously, the progress of the last few years has been so weak that we are now happy to see any progress even if it is very modest. So indeed - as you have pointed out - a military planning and conduct capacity will emerge: thirty officers to supervise non-executive missions, that is to say modest training missions in Mali, in the CAR. and Somalia. They are useful, but they are not decisive. I have just returned from Mali and it is not our training mission - unfortunately, however professional it is - that will make the difference in the instability that this country is experiencing.
