On the other hand, what I do know is that it is the French troops - once again - who are on the front line and that European solidarity is expressed very timidly, and that the European countries which send contingents in Mali assign them mostly non-combatant functions, with the fewest possible problems. This is not European solidarity and this is not how we will move forward. So the qualitative leap, especially operational, that we have to make, does not exist. Industrially, I hear about the costs of non-Europe, but the cost of non-Europe to our own defense industry is when the equipment exists in Europe and some countries continue to buy off the shelf from the United States.It is also a blow from non-Europe that must one day be highlighted.Let us not forget that security is the first of European solidarities.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: question "blue card".- Madam President, dear colleague, you know that I appreciate you very much.Let me ask you if you are in favor of the idea of establishing an independent European anti-terrorism agency, with its own intelligence service, to better protect our citizens.After all that has happened in Europe, don't you think it is time to strengthen our security and defense and to cooperate more on security and defense?

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE)
text: answer "blue card".- It is not precisely a subject covered by the report, but if you ask me my opinion, I do not believe in a European intelligence superagency.This is not what we need.What we need is to strengthen information exchange platforms.A full-fledged agency would be a new bureaucratic monster, with no guarantee of operational efficiency.What we need is that our national agencies, which are good, efficient and professional, cooperate more with each other, exchange more with each other, but certainly not a new European superstructure with very limited usefulness in terms ofoperational.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, I would like, first of all, to congratulate the two rapporteurs, Mr Gahler and Mr González Pons, for the report and for the openness they have had with the shadow rapporteurs, among whom I am. Security and defense policy has been, from the beginning, a weak link in the European Union. There was an initial period where there was neither ambition nor means. Then there was an intermediate period when there were means, but there was no ambition. And today we need both, ambition and means. It has been necessary for the devastating effects of foreign wars to reach our borders, in our neighborhood, for us to be aware of the close link between internal security and external security. It has been necessary for terrorist attacks to take place in Madrid, in Berlin, in Paris, in London and in many other cities of the European Union, in Brussels, so that we are aware that we need to share intelligence, share operational means and share, too, judicial cooperation. It has been necessary for Russia to rekindle its hegemonic ambition and for the United States to reinforce the part of its isolationist soul so that we are aware that the European Union has to be a global actor, and it can only be if it has a security and defense policy common. Therefore, more European ambition? Definitely. More European agency or European Defense Agency? Definitely. More commitment to NATO? Yes, but already in a European dimension; united, as pointed out by Mr. González Pons. More budget? Yes, but not at the cost of other budget lines that are necessary for the daily well-being of European citizens. More democratic control of Parliament? Definitely. And, also, more political voice as the European Union in the United Nations.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! The European Union has a right to think about its own defense efforts, as long as it bases them on good, healthy principles. First of all - on real solidarity. Mr Danjean spoke about the loneliness of the French in Mali, but real solidarity means solidarity in all directions: also that the French, Spaniards and Italians will treat the protection of the Baltic states as their own, they will support Ukraine, treat the security of Central and Eastern Europe as their own issue, as a matter of your own safety. Secondly - responsibility, i.e. respecting the 2% GDP criterion for defense spending by states. Only a few European countries use this, and I am very surprised that some are in favor of a common defense policy and, at the same time, against increasing spending. Finally, the third point: these efforts must complement, not confront the North Atlantic Alliance. If the report had followed these principles, I would have been in favor of it; because it does not express them - I cannot support it.

name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Gahler and González Pons, for their very good report and good cooperation. The main finding of the report is that there are no legal obstacles to the development of the European common security and defense policy, and the main recommendations of the report are the establishment of the European Defense Agency and permanent structured cooperation as the original agencies of the European Union and the institutions of the common security and defense policy. integrated forces and a joint civilian and military command that would be permanent. However, I would like to point out the limitations that exist, the limitations of a legal nature that are not limitations of the European treaties, but of the international world order, and that is that if we achieved all the goals we set in this report, the European Union would not be able to intervene. nor in its neighborhood, those areas that particularly concern them because it could not therefore obtain the consent of the Security Council, a member of the Security Council because it would touch on their strategic interests. This is, in fact, the biggest legal constraint on the development and effectiveness of the common European security and defense policy. I therefore particularly welcome and emphasize the part of the report calling on Member States to act in terms of reform of the United Nations, and in particular in terms of reform of the United Nations Security Council, so that the European Union can intervene in those areas such as today. the case of the Middle East, North Africa, areas where crises particularly affect the European Union, and there is no opportunity to intervene and act in those areas.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! The topic of the report is: How can passages of the Lisbon Treaty be made usable for the further militarization of the EU? Against the background of Brexit and Trump, the current window of opportunity is now being used. Joint military projects are supposed to form the cement of the crumbling EU, and there are loud and vehement calls for military independence. A special focus of the report is the activation of constant structured cooperation. Certain aspects of EU military policy could be withdrawn from the consensus principle here. The demand that both the permanent structured cooperation and the EU defense agency should be treated as an institution sui generis, which means that they are largely removed from parliamentary control, is particularly explosive. It is true that the report also contains statements about the greater involvement of Parliament and the strengthening of its rights, but that remains vague. One looks in vain for demands for a parliamentary reservation, for example. Even now, the military EU is hardly controlled by parliament. Mr Borg said control was up to the Member States. How is that supposed to work with the proposals in this report? This report aims to further tighten the ties of the EU military union and to deliver the wish lists to the arms lobby even more directly - even less disturbed by an effective parliament. So there are many reasons to reject it.

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, let me first of all thank all the rapporteurs for the work they put into this report; considerable innovative energy went into this. Sometimes I have the feeling that there is a little too much of this innovative energy.  We, in the Green Group, believe that the report is an important one; the aim of it is a very legitimate and crucial one for the time. Had it been about unleashing the full potential of the Lisbon Treaty in the field of security and defence, we would have been in full support. However, we feel – and I am sorry to say so – that this report is more of a missed opportunity in that regard.  (The President cut off the speaker due to a technical problem with interpretation) I am sorry to our Italian colleagues for missing the first part. However, the idea that the EDA should be transformed into a sui-generis institution and, as such, be the nucleus of a potential European Minister of Defence is indeed a very controversial one. It would be an agency without transparency, parliamentary oversight, let alone control. We are in full support of centralisation; it makes sense in this field, but not in this way, without any accountability whatsoever. Secondly, we believe that, before committing large amounts of fresh money to defence and security, we should explore the full potential of efficiency gains through cooperation, and only after this should we consider additional funding that might be available through the European Union budget or from Member States. These are the main reasons why our Group is unable to support the report, even though we are committed to a stronger European common defence and security policy and there are many very good ideas in the report in general.

name: Patrick O'Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, it is often claimed in this Chamber that the EU has secured peace in Europe since the Second World War, and it is often pointed out from these benches that in fact it is NATO that has preserved peace and freedom. In fact, even as someone who has campaigned vigorously for Britain to leave the European Union, I have still acknowledged that, for a time after the Second World War, having France and Germany engaged in a joint political project was indeed a useful support to NATO in maintaining peace. But I would hope everyone in this Chamber would equally acknowledge that, in cold hard terms of armies and military hardware and nuclear deterrence, it was indeed NATO that shielded Western Europe from the threat of external attack. So what a shame that now, in the second decade of the 21st century, NATO seems to be out of fashion with European politicians. Most governments do not honour their commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defence, and the US has grown tired of bearing a disproportionate burden. So I am afraid the opportunists of Brussels are seeking to acquire another element of nationhood: an EU army to add to the flag, the Parliament, the anthem and the currency.  This idea of a common defence identity is pure folly. You do not have sufficient social solidarity, nor commonality of interest, to support the financial bailouts necessitated by the euro, let alone the shedding of blood in military combat under an EU cap badge. By far the best thing would be to re-engage with NATO, meet your defence spending pledges and allow Britain to be a bridge to a US administration that has certainly had some tough things to say of late. Stick with the entity that has stood the test of time. Do not let an ideological dream, that is not shared by most people in Europe, put the security of a continent in jeopardy.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe's weakened political and economic situation and the ambiguous EU-NATO relationship mark the objective limits of this project. I would like to point out that in the first two months of the year alone, dozens and dozens of ships are docked in European ports after making mysterious stops, closing the radars, thus making it impossible to identify the landing place, and coincidentally in the areas controlled by the Isis and by Al Qaeda. So what are we talking about? There is no European foreign policy that establishes who the friends are and who the enemies, if any, and, of course, I am well aware that these enemies exist and are called Islamic terrorism, Al Qaeda, etc. Maybe, tomorrow or the day after Turkey too, who knows, let's hope not. So, increased expenses, but to do what? Maybe to buy the F35? I believe that more than anything else we can think of an alliance between countries that want to cooperate in defense. I would like to point out the latest news: there is a country, Germany, whose Bundeswehr already recruits European volunteers; it is in the White Paper, but it is not mentioned in this report. It seems to me a topic that should interest us all in a little more depth.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, the report promotes the further deepening of the common security and defense policy, which deviates from the general objectives of the Treaty provisions and contains an expansive interpretation. No one in the European Parliament, having underground political aspirations, has the political and moral legitimacy to change the Treaty as they see fit. The Treaty may be revised, as provided for in the constitutional order of the Member States, solely by ratification by national parliaments or by referendum. However, if it is put to the citizens' judgment, the decision for more Europe and less homeland and nation will be voted against, as the European Constitution was voted against in similar referendums. It would be wrong to equate or attempt to further unite national needs and challenges. There is no room for further compromise on national priorities. No Member State will place its army as a consumable pawn on the world geopolitical chessboard. A common security and defense policy does not exist and will not exist as long as Turkey disputes sovereign rights and threatens Greece with casus belli, illegally occupies 1/3 of the territory of Cyprus and does not recognize the Republic of Cyprus. The proposed nominal, constitutional, legal and institutional implications will not bend those who provocatively raise redemptive claims. Example: the country of Skopje, which steals the history of Greece and talks about Macedonian identity, nation and language. As much as you seek to limit national sovereignty in the Member States, their territorial integrity and national independence is their sole responsibility and is secured autonomously and through alliances between states that have common interests and aspirations.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this report could hardly be more timely, and my congratulations to the rapporteur, because for too long Europe has lived off the so-called peace dividend and relied on soft power and, in parallel, has tended to neglect hard power. The developments of the last few years tell us why we need to change: the ongoing crisis in the Middle East, terrorism, the rule of Russia, and more recently the demand by Washington that Europe must play a significantly more active role in its own defence are the key factors in this respect.  Yet the possible defence structures of the European Union are already in place, notably in Article 42 of the Treaty. This article is fairly clear in mentioning operational capacity at the European level, common defence, and an undertaking by Member States progressively to improve their military capabilities. It could not be clearer. So the scope for change is considerable. To the above, one can usefully add: improvement in security and counterterrorism cooperation – a sensitive area of course. Major cost benefits can be expected from joint military procurement. Having a shared defence objective can also mean much greater investment in military technology, bringing spill-over with it and the transfer of innovation into the civilian sector.  It is clear enough that the private sector is generally risk-averse where blue sky research is concerned, but the state can transform this, precisely because the state can focus on the long term rather than on short-run profitability. There is enormous scope for the European Union to push forward in this broad area of common defence.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Dear Mr Gahler, thank you very much for your report. We largely agree with what you have written down, and that is why the vast majority of my colleagues will agree with him. A common defense policy enables more efficiency - and that has nothing to do with senseless armament - creates the air that is needed for new investments, because there are also new challenges. And it has something to do with more responsibility - also in our neighborhood. Whether we want it or not, we have to be prepared for it. However, four things also need to be clear. First: Territorial defense is a matter for NATO and not a mini-NATO called the EU. Second: New tasks cost money. We need to talk to the Member States about how these new tasks are going to cost them, and how they are going to be covered. Thirdly, we are in favor of parliamentary scrutiny for purely military missions; this has to be discussed in the course of the proceedings. And ultimately we are of the opinion that the military component is only part of a holistic foreign policy. We are proud of the soft skills that the EU has developed and the EU should develop them further. That is why we are of the opinion that the SEDE committee should initially remain a subcommittee. That did not find a majority in committee, but that should not prevent us from agreeing to it.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am a bit confused by Mr Borg’s remarks. One set of EU forces? Or national forces under national control? You seem to think it’s both. I mean it’s all smoke and mirrors. God help us if we have to rely on the European Union for our defence. Where’s all this money going to come from, I wonder? I have to say one of the many objections we had to the Treaty of Lisbon was the licence it gave to those pursuing this sort of mirage of an autonomous EU defence policy.  The report we are discussing confirms our misgivings. The Euro-federalists seem to inhabit a curious bleak and empty space where no one else is doing anything to address the security challenges that we all face, and where their answer to every problem is more EU. Of course the reality is quite different. As has been pointed out, the defence of our democracies against the threat of aggression is carried out by NATO. Twenty-two of the 28 EU Member States are NATO members, four of the remainder work closely with NATO, and just a month ago Finland, for instance, agreed a cyber defence cooperation arrangement with NATO.  NATO harnesses the overwhelming military power of the United States to that of the European nations for their mutual defence, and we have the vital Article 5 guarantee. So I just wonder what on earth the EU is up to with its ambitions for an autonomous defence capability. Yet another bureaucratic monster, perhaps, as Mr Danjean put it a few moments ago referring to another bit of EU activity.

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, an analysis of a Eurostat poll shows us that our citizens are in fact ahead of European defense policy. It's quite paradoxical, but in reviving the spirit that prevailed in 1954, when the EDC - the European Defense Community - was on the verge of success, our citizens are, of course, more than a half a century on ambitions, but ahead of politics, which remains too passive in this area. The current context, in addition to the various types of shortcomings in European defense, further complicates the debate. Military defense is an ultimate means that can be engaged when all other means have failed. Let us remember, in the midst of the Cold War, the former German foreign minister Genscher made a bet on the future: Frieden schaffen mit weniger Waffen (ensuring peace with less armament). Genscher won his bet thanks to a vast diplomatic offensive and also thanks to the agreement of the United States. Today, since Trump's election, transatlantic relations are in such a state that even a very substantial increase in European defense spending would still leave the question of European security open, unless Trump put an end to his ambivalent speech. One of the priorities at the moment is therefore to provide some clarification in this area and to test the solidity of relations within NATO. This in no way undermines the value of the report by our colleague Gahler, whose proposals are useful for the future, but only a coherent approach would be able to produce satisfactory results in terms of safety. In this context, very effective diplomacy should also be promoted. A face for European politics could be a French personality. Why a French personality? Because France is everywhere where others don't want to go, it is the first and it is rarely followed by others, who only have "via cases" to offer it.Thirdly, respect for our European institutions and our treaties: an external policy and not 28 parallel policies, which make us lose all benchmarks in the matter, this to remind us that the credibility of our security and defense policy requiresmastery of all policy aggregates relating to security and defense.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the report on the common European security and defense policy we are discussing today contains some positive elements on a verbal level. One such element is the call for collective financing by the Member States of the Union of expenditure arising from defense operations of a Member State which is the victim of an armed attack on its territory. However, this should not be a general wish list, but should be specialized at the present time, since there are such Member States today and specifically Greece and Cyprus. The Turkish Air Force almost daily violates Greek airspace and overflights over Greek islands, forcing the Greek Air Force to spend large sums on fuel and spare parts for interceptor flights. In fact, this is happening while the Greek budget is being dramatically burdened with the service of a huge public debt and the Greek people are suffering the heavy consequences of austerity policies. In fact, the fiscal situation in Greece has reached the levels of the last seven years and the three memoranda to a large extent due to the huge equipment to deal with the aggression of Turkey, a country with seven times the population and four times the economic size. We need action, not words, to support the threatened Member States of the Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are not against a Europe of defense, quite the contrary. But the problem with this relationship is that, as often happens, the order of factors is confused, in this case the outsiders prevail. Brexit, as well as the result of the American elections, while highlighting the European fragility in the sector, do not justify an acceleration on choices that should be reasoned, considered and shared with citizens. When Member States are asked to raise spending to 2%, we are talking about one hundred billion euros: these are not insignificant figures to ask of our peoples, especially in the face of the devastating social impact of austerity. Precisely for this reason, waste and duplication should be eliminated to reinvest savings in something else or, at least, to avoid increasing expenses. The report is correct when it says that the governance, funding and objectives of a possible European Defense Fund should be clarified and we should know this information first, not after the vote on this text. Not to mention the effective control that the European Parliament and the national ones will have. We should have a White Paper with the various options and begin the wide-ranging path not only with the European and national institutions but also with citizens and civil society. Only in this way can a conscious political will be built which, to date, appears far from clear.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we would now move towards a Europe of defense, this is what our Parliament wants, as Great Britain leaves the European Union. We want a Europe of defense by welcoming the departure of one of the only solid armies on the continent. In fact, there will be no Defense Europe within the current institutions. Why? To defend yourself you have to see friend and foe, yet we send soldiers to Russia's borders, support jihadists in Syria and Libya and therefore do not understand our own interests. In order to defend yourself you have to be able to fight yourself, but we do not have a European military-industrial complex, and Europe tends to destroy national complexes to include them in transatlantic ones. To defend yourself, you have to want to live and we leave our doors wide open to mafia and criminal networks. So no, there will be no Europe of defense, there will either be the destruction of national defenses by Europe, or the nations defending themselves against new threats.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I would like, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteurs on this report, which comes at a very particular point in our calendar. I believe that we cannot define ourselves at this moment in the European Union only as the consumers of a large market, but as citizens of a Union. And there is a qualitative social leap from the condition of consumer to the condition of citizen. Mr. Gahler, in his presentation you told us that citizens demand from us not only higher levels of well-being and progress, but higher levels of security. There are colleagues in this House who think that the European Union is in a kind of post-historical paradise, where wars, the military and conflicts are someone else's business. At this moment we have serious threats that weigh on the European Union and, today, we have armies that have no apparent enemies and we have enemies that do not have an army. The European Union must make it through to adulthood once and for all. And although the transatlantic code is somehow inscribed in the genes of the European Union, we have to start developing our defense capabilities. That is why we must congratulate ourselves on the progress that has been made and that has been promoted by the High Representative since the December European Council and congratulate the rapporteurs. And I am convinced that there will be no future for the European Union if, together with our economic, commercial, financial or industrial capacities, we do not develop - as the co-rapporteur, Mr. González Pons, told us - a mobilization of the political will to equip ourselves with capacities in the field of security and defense that allow us to face the new configuration of threats.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: - Mister President! At the beginning of European unification, over 70 years ago, there was already the idea of ​​a community for security and defense. After more than 70 years, this idea is back on our agenda, and many colleagues have also said why: because the geopolitical situation has changed dramatically. There are uncertainties ranging from Vladimir Putin's policy in Moscow to - very likely - Donald's policy in Washington, not to mention the crisis belt around the EU. The EU is a soft power, and it will stay that way because the Lisbon Treaty states that all EU missions to maintain peace are carried out with the approval of the international community. The militarization of the EU or the EU as world police cannot happen with the existing treaty. We all know that our capabilities are very limited and that a lot of money is wasted because of duplication and mismanagement. It cannot be forbidden to create a single market for armaments, as it is in the treaty. It cannot be forbidden to establish a common headquarters for the missions and the better equipment of these missions. Of course, finances are also necessary. And I think that the EU budget must go hand in hand with the reform of the EU's own revenues. I think diplomacy has priority, but we also need military capabilities under the control of parliaments. I am also in favor of flagging the institutions: a council of defense ministers and, soon, a committee on defense here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to ask my colleague Jo Leinen: If we are talking about European added value here today, then it is certainly justified, and so is the cost of non-Europe.Is it actually conceivable that small and medium-sized companies in particular will be more closely integrated into public tenders in the future, because that could of course also lead to new jobs?

name: Jo Leinen (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.-  Colleague!The internal market creates more opportunities for both large and small companies.And I can imagine, if we open up this market for armaments, that everyone really will have their advantage, that not only Airbus and Krauss Maffei and similar large companies, but also the small and medium-sized companies that you value, will have access, because weHave EU standards for tendering and awarding these contracts.And that's why I agree with you.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Mr President!The debate on a common EU foreign and defense policy could hardly be more misplaced.We see a US administration demanding that their European allies in NATO live up to their treaty obligations.What was Juncker's answer to that?Juncker's answer was that it should be taken seriously.So you had to break the treaty obligations in NATO because they came from a US administration that you did not like.At the same time, we are talking about duplicating the capabilities of the defense here in the European Union.I simply do not know where it would take us to a better place when there is no willingness in the Member States to invest just up to the 2% of gross domestic product in our common defense.The core of Europe's security is NATO, both for the vast majority of NATO members but also for the rest.Let us therefore focus on the transatlantic partnership and put aside the idea of a European Defense Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, different reasons have given us the possibility to undertake more defence cooperation between the European countries. We have to use this opportunity to be able to defend Europe and increase its security. I welcome the report of Mr Gahler and Mr González Pons with its concrete steps on how to use the possibilities given us by the Lisbon Treaty in the area of defence cooperation.  I would like to highlight that European countries must seriously aim for the goal of spending 2% of their GDP on defence. This would give a clear signal of joint positions of the EU and NATO. We need to work together with NATO, complement it where possible, and not see NATO as a reason for not having a stronger European defence policy. The Member States that are ready to undertake more binding commitments would set up a permanent structured cooperation so that it would be possible to establish multinational forces.  A very concrete thing to work on is the movement of defence forces personnel of allies inside Europe which right now is troublesome, bureaucratic and time-consuming. The EU must create a system that would coordinate the fast movement of defence forces personnel and equipment when the solidarity clause is invoked.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on an interesting report, which in some places is very ambitious, and it remains to be seen whether it will be fulfilled in the future. I consider the part of the report where money is clearly mentioned to be particularly important. Vain glory, it is difficult for Europe to increase its defense in the future if it does not raise money from individual national budgets and, if necessary, does not debate whether money from the European budget should not be used for defense. So, several times, the 2% of the GDP budgets of the individual Member States here are, in my opinion, the basis. We should do everything we can to ensure that the individual EU countries really increase their defense money significantly. Only four EU countries account for 2% of GDP, an absolute minority. Without money, it is difficult to raise your defenses in the future. The report states a very interesting figure that, if defense spending could really be raised in the future, we could raise up to EUR 100 billion, an admirable amount that, if invested in the European defense industry, if invested in joint research, I think that this would have a significant multiplier effect not only on greater defense, but also on creating new jobs, strengthening European businesses and, of course, military research always has positive results for the civilian population and has other positive benefits. I agree with the thesis that has been expressed here, cooperation with NATO is necessary. After all, the report, I commend it, makes it clear that the strategic partnership between the EU and NATO needs to be balanced and expanded. I think this is very important, because any components we build must be compatible with NATO, not competitive.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I believe in this Europe of defense and security. I want the Europe of security and defense, because it is a necessity. It will be a long march. It will be a long march. It will be complicated. But we have to make very clear progress, because, in addition to the needs that have been highlighted, and that the rapporteurs have brilliantly explained, I believe that there is a convergence - I would say that it is not normal - between all the Member States. Even among the Twenty-eight. I dare say that also in the UK. Now, we have two major difficulties. A first is political pedagogy. Public opinion is not aware of the problems. And politics and leadership demand that we explain to public opinion why the Europe of defense and security is necessary. And secondly, we have a problem with funding. And I think that the report does very well to insist that a source of funding from the European Union is needed. We cannot ask the austerity countries to include more defense spending. We cannot ask that of them. We will have to establish a European Union source of resources for this ambitious mission that Europe needs.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! I think we all agree that the authors of the report are right in pointing to the need to increase Europe's ability to provide security both within the European Union and beyond its borders. But, as has already been mentioned in this House, it is crucial to increase national defense spending to 2% of GDP. And this is the minimum that - as we know - not all Member States are ready to meet. And the second important postulate, the most important one, is to strengthen, not weaken, NATO. And I do not know, I am not sure that all the proposals in this project are for strengthening NATO, not weakening it. The authors rightly propose the development of cooperation in the field of defense between member states, but it seems that the far-reaching Europeanization of defense policy is not the right way to increase the security of member states. Instead, we should consolidate our partnership with NATO, strengthen transatlantic relations without being guided by the mood of the moment (and this report seems to succumb to it), and not be guided by the anti-American resentment that exists in many societies of the member states.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this initiative is of fundamental importance because we are still lagging behind in our preparedness to address multiple security threats.  I would make three points. Firstly, two thirds of EU citizens expect enhanced EU cooperation on security and defence. Now this report makes it clear that much more efficient cooperation can and should happen, making use of the existing treaties. Second, a key target is a European Defence Union, based on permanent structured cooperation and ending hopefully in establishing European integrated forces. It is not parallel to NATO, but serving as a European pillar of NATO.  Third, the other key to enhanced security is information-sharing – that is compulsory information-sharing between national intelligence bodies, with adequate cooperation structures. Finally, there is no escape from bringing national defence expenditure to the 2% level. Here the US criticism is in place, and there is absolutely no time to waste.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, who have done an excellent job on this text. As we said again this morning, the future of Europe depends on that of the Europe of defense. It is as much a security necessity - our neighborhood is more and more worrying and terrorism is making a comeback on our soil - as a political necessity, because Europe needs concrete action and successful projects to make its added value undeniable. Without it, it will be even more difficult to defend Europe, the most beautiful and perhaps the only great political project that we have before us. This report, today - it is in its interest - is a wake-up call. Europe already has a large panoply of instruments, legal tools, facilities for military cooperation, but - and this is the last straw - nothing is being used. No common military groups, no common headquarters, no efficient sharing of the financial burden of military activities. The conclusion to all this is simple: our problem in really building a Europe of defense is to use it, to animate it, to give content to content that already exists. In other words, the only thing Europe lacked was political will, that political courage and that infallible will in defense of Europeans. This is the stake, this is the message, this is the horizon that the European Parliament must send to the heads of state and government for the 60 years of the Treaties of Rome.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! There is a simple principle that we should stick to: the "as-much" principle - as many common institutions and competences as common values ​​and interests. Institutions should be created to strengthen policy, to increase its effectiveness, not instead of policy. Institutions without people to make decisions will not pursue any politics, will not get anywhere. It was at a time when Central Europe was under Soviet domination that the authorities always had one recipe: give us more power, the problems will be solved. We have had some significant attempts recently, in the last decade: the Russian invasion of Georgia, the war in Ukraine, the immigration wave, which also had its own security dimension due to the illegal immigration industry. Generally speaking, we did not perform well, so let's really strengthen politics and then we will think about institution building. First, let the government of the Federal Republic stop the construction of Nord Stream 2.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I guess we all agree that rapidly changing geopolitical circumstances and serious security threats characterise the international environment. I firmly believe no European country can address these challenges alone, and to overcome national prerogatives and double structures that impede the efficiency of EU security and defence policy, we have to be more flexible. I welcome, therefore, that for instance, the Foreign Affairs Council on 6 March underlined that ‘the permanent structured cooperation could facilitate the development of Member States’ defence capabilities and strengthen European defence cooperation’. Therefore I urge our Member States now to make full use of the legal instruments provided by the Treaty of Lisbon in this field. We need to join forces and to become more flexible to ensure the security of our Union. I would like to thank and congratulate Michael Gahler and Esteban González Pons for an excellent report.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: -  Mister President! The development of a common security and defense policy could be a good example of European added value. Yes, collaboration on research would likely guarantee efficiency gains. In this context, however, I am continually concerned that many reports on this subject easily call for substantial amounts of money in order to finance the various elements of the new common security and defense policy. The European Defense Agency is to become a joint institution, the joint headquarters for security missions has been decided. The Commission proposes EUR 500 million for defense research in the new medium-term financial framework. All of this applies to a budget that is already chronically underfunded. And so I think that this House has to be honest in this context: Do we want to raise these costs from this budget? That meant less money for civil research, less for regional aid, less money for protecting the external borders and caring for refugees. I am convinced we cannot afford that. So please let us be so consistent and ask the Commission and the Council that this common security and defense policy be financed by a corresponding expansion of the next medium-term financial framework!

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, distinguished rapporteurs, finally a message with a view to making a Europe of defense a reality. It is carried by two quite remarkable reports. After a momentum, which was also carried by several countries in the years 2000 to 2007, let us indeed recognize that Europe of defense has stagnated. With the appearance of new threats and new geostrategic and geopolitical challenges - especially on our European soil - it has become obvious that Europe, in order to protect its own citizens and to have influence on the global diplomatic level, must organize itself in defense. Rather than seeking to innovate, at any cost, let us concretely take advantage, as the reports propose, of the possibilities that the Treaty of Lisbon offers us, and which have still not been called into question. First of all, the commitment of all the Member States to increase their defense budget, to the tune of 2% of GDP, and I stress that nothing prevents defense credits from being outside the Maastricht criteria, which would not be that justice towards the countries which, today, make all the effort for the others. There is the establishment of a military capacity for planning and conduct of operations which has been refused for too long by one of the member countries of Europe, there is also the improvement of cooperation with the 'NATO or improving research and development. These are concrete efforts that are needed if we want Europe to become a real political power at world level. The problem, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, is whether it will really have the will and the political courage.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we are on the verge of a new era in Europe and defence and security. What Europe needs is a closer integration in intelligence and law enforcement. How can we protect Europeans – say, from a major terrorist attack – when our national security services do not share information with each other? How can we protect European institutions and values from Russia’s hybrid warfare if each Member State works on the basis of its own intelligence? But it also concerns any future defence union. How can we plan a common military or civilian mission if there is no shared assessment of the situation on the ground? Europe needs its own intelligence agency. This is no longer a luxury or some Euro-federalist dream. If you understand the problems, you know it is a strategic necessity, not a new bureaucracy. It is precondition for European strategic autonomy.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteurs, Mr Gahler and Mr González Pons, on their report. The deterioration of our security environment, the changes in the international scenario and the technological revolution make it necessary for us to advance in the European security and defense policy, a dimension that has not been developed until now. As the report clearly points out, the Treaties already contain the necessary elements to gradually equip us with that autonomous defense and security capacity that we desire; Take, for example, permanent structured cooperation. Now, what is involved is the political will to take advantage of and develop these articles of the Treaty. In this sense, I welcome the steps taken by the European Council, without going any further last week, and by the Foreign Affairs Council, and also the measures that the Commission is taking. We are, as we all know, in a delicate moment for the European Union and, at the same time, I believe that our citizens are asking us for more Europe in terms of security and defense. The Union may thus be strengthened thanks to the development of defense, which offers a positive horizon, beyond Brexit and the current difficulties. I will end with a truism: this defense progress must be accompanied by an increasingly cohesive foreign policy.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, 60 years after the Treaty of Rome, we must move towards more political unification, not only for those who want it but also for those who can, because I am very afraid that those who can will continue to decline. We need solidarity in the budget, in the refugee, in the defense. Integration in defense and security policy will enable us to do more with less money. It is unthinkable for countries like Greece, which is in a difficult economic situation, to devote a significant percentage of GDP to this sector and at the same time richer countries to maintain much less spending. This practice does not mean solidarity and in the long run undermines the security of the peoples of Europe. Finally, especially after the election of Mr. Trump in the United States, it is necessary to work together for the European Union to have structures that allow it to act flexibly and autonomously beyond the Euro-Atlantic alliance.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - (The beginning of the speech is muted) ... years. It creates an urgent need for the European Union to stabilize the region in its neighborhood, the Western Balkans, the Eastern Partnership, North Africa and the Middle East. This calls for a common security and defense policy to cease to be a paper tiger and to be filled with content. It is necessary to build a common capacity to ensure the security of the European continent, without duplicating NATO's activities. This includes strengthening resilience to hybrid threats, including propaganda threats, contributing to border security, and actions related to cybersecurity, energy and maritime security. European citizens expect solutions from us and let us not be deceived - if we do not offer them, there are many others on the far left and far right who will offer and try to get support. We need political will. I welcome the decision to set up a permanent headquarters for planning and conducting operations, which is an important step on the path to a defense union. It is important to speed up the work on building permanent structural cooperation, but to be open to all countries of the European Union that want it. No party should be excluded.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - I thank my colleagues Michael Gahler and Esteban González Pons for their excellent report. The subject is particularly important because, in a rapidly deteriorating security environment, it is more necessary than ever to achieve the objectives of the CSDP. In particular, strengthen the EU's operational capacity so that, if necessary, the European Union can take real action to ensure peace and prevent armed conflict. The security and defense threats facing the EU, its territory and its citizens are common and cannot be tackled by one Member State alone. The EU must urgently develop a unified and effective defense system, which has unfortunately not been established so far. This will in no way undermine national sovereignty, as this policy is pursued by the Member States. They are political subjects. We need clarity in the transatlantic relationship, which is currently lacking. It is in this context that we need to rebalance and expand the strategic partnership between the EU and NATO in order to ensure coherence, develop common capabilities and avoid duplication of efforts and structures.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Mr President, security risks for the European Union have changed over the last ten years.If we want to face them, we need to define them.That is why the report calls on the Council and the High Representative to draw up an EU White Paper on Security and Defense, which will include a definition of threats.I would like to draw attention to one current danger that should be described in the White Paper.This is a danger that directly undermines the concept of future cooperation between the EU and NATO.This danger is called: the resuscitation of European communism.It is no secret that, for example, the Czech Communists, including our fellow MEPs, are already openly calling for the Czech Republic's withdrawal from NATO.If they come to power again, and this is realistic, as the Communists are the third strongest party in parliament in the Czech Republic, they will achieve their goal of breaking up NATO from within.Don't underestimate communism, Mrs Mogherini.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Thanks to Michael Gahler and González Pons for a clear, committed and very substantial report. We act out of responsibility for our citizens. Something is going on in the defense policy of the European Union. The foreign and defense ministers decided on an EU military center because they recognized that we are facing internal and external security challenges and threats that no country can solve alone. We have too little money, too few staff, too little efficiency. The European Parliament is stepping up the pace in this debate. We want the permanent structured cooperation - planning together, researching together, procuring together - to be intensified and for all member states to participate. We need an expansion of the tasks of the European Defense Agency. We need a European Council of Defense Ministers, and I say also a European Defense Minister who, together with the Foreign Minister, will advance the common foreign and security policy. Let's move ahead faster than before - may the report provide the right initial spark.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, considering our geopolitical circumstances and the conflicts in our wider neighbouring region – be it in Ukraine, Syria, or Libya – it is obvious that in the area of defence policy, Europe needs a common sense of direction and purpose, and a vision that is up to the threats we face. Establishing a common European defence policy would make sense both economically and politically. As we squander billions of euros by maintaining parallel structures, which weighs upon our efficiency, European added value is evident through more cost-effective capacities, more interoperability and more common spending on research. As regards political considerations, with the globally deteriorating security environment – including, at our doorsteps, at the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome – revisiting the ideas of the founding fathers on closer military integration in order to reinforce our security at home and act externally for peacekeeping and conflict prevention externally makes more sense than ever.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as highlighted by the speakers, the changes in international geopolitics, the terrorist attacks that have taken place not only in Europe, and the persistence of conflicts in various areas of the world certainly make it essential to have a united response to risks and threats from which individual states cannot defend themselves. A common defense, within the scope of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty, however, requires a new model of governance, with the coordination and commitment of the Member States, strengthening the existing instruments and agencies. However, while in line with the need to guarantee external security and internal security, which are inextricably linked, it is necessary to ensure adequate budgetary resources for common defense action, however, actions and initiatives to support citizens, especially the most vulnerable. Only under these conditions can common defense really be an added value for Europe.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, let's be clear.Until this European Union has a clear defense force, a strong security policy and a military force, we will not be a fully respected partner practically anywhere.We can have good political ideas, we can have peace initiatives, but without serious military force the European Union will not be a fully credible world player.The example of Syria is the best example.Russia and the United States are at war in Syria.They are agreeing on both war and peace, and we are feeling the crisis from Syria and we are falling apart because of it.Due to the migrant crisis, we are falling apart.So we need to be credible to the end in order to really take advantage of what lies ahead, and that is to defend the interests of our citizens and to create a true security and defense union.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr President, it cannot be hidden from the European Union and its governments that the common denominator of all five reactionary scenarios for the future of the European Union is the issue of defense and security. It is even seen as the privileged ground for any, looser or stronger, cooperation between Member States. The proclamations, the meetings, the reports-hare of the European Parliament like it argue that the European Union is strengthening its militarization with a global strategy, White Paper on defense, European defense union, Euromilitary. In addition to NATO and independently, the European Union seeks to regain ground over the military supremacy of the United States, China and Russia. The international capitalist arms race, in which the Greek government is particularly involved, shows that the clouds of war are thickening with the control of the energy sources of their transport routes. This includes Turkey's aggression in the Aegean, for which both the European Union and NATO turn a blind eye. Against all of them and all this, the people should be organized and prepared to be vigilant.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, congratulations to the two rapporteurs on their ambitious report. Our common future and interest include common defense. The future of the European Union, it was said, will depend on our stance on this issue. Two urgent reasons have already been mentioned: Russia's behavior and Trump's isolationism. However, in order to have credibility in our words, we must really feel that the external borders of the European Union are the external borders of all of us, from the Baltic countries to the Aegean and Cyprus. The legal framework of the Lisbon Treaty is sufficient for us to move forward. Article 2 states that the Union must provide its citizens with an area of ​​freedom, security and justice. However, Article 2 is already being violated in Cyprus, where Turkey illegally holds European territory of the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we have heard many big and bold words about the so-called common defense and security policy. What we have today in relation to Greece is the aggression of Turkey, which violates the airspace, violates the territorial waters; a few days ago a Turkish gunman fired a cannon into the Greek territorial waters in Farmakonisi. We have a question of the Greekness of Imia. What has the European Union done about Turkey's aggression? Some lukewarm announcements. Otherwise she washes her hands. I believe that all this effort for common defense and security is essentially what it is doing to fund the military-industrial establishment in the European Union, boost the profitability of the military-equipment industries, militarize the European Union and open an offensive European Union policy towards the developing world.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a common defense policy is more necessary than ever. A priority commitment of the Member States is needed to create a political path based on shared resources and capabilities and on coordinated planning at Union level. States can benefit from a sufficient and coherent regulatory and functional framework after the reform brought about by the Lisbon Treaty to the common security and defense policy. Security and defense constitute an area with clear European added value, if only one considers the estimates that each euro invested in defense generates a return of € 1.06. But the strengthening of the Union's operational capacity is worth much more when we consider the cost of non-Europe that comes from the failure to maintain peace, prevent conflict and strengthen European security. In the constant search for the right political and operational dimension with regard to the common security and defense policy, this Parliament must, however, play a real leading role.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Europe needs to be a new global pole for promoting peace and reconciliation between peoples and nations. If we also become a third or fourth military pillar, then we only serve war, immigration and poverty as a result of these wars. I am particularly concerned about trying to join NATO. Under no circumstances should the European Union become an arm of another body. But I will tell you this: I will review, ladies and gentlemen, if anyone here tells me, a representative of the Council or a representative of the Commission, that, when all that the Commission and the Council have said is done, this army will send its forces to Cyprus, to expel Turkish troops from European territory.

name: Ian Borg
text: president-inOffice of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I really appreciated the debate. I am here and once again on behalf of High Representative Mogherini. I appreciate the work of the rapporteurs but also the contribution of the House. Security and defence will remain high on the EU’s political agenda in the coming weeks and months, and the European Council asked to maintain the momentum and to continue the work with determination and speed. More than ever, it is imperative that Europeans take more responsibility for their own security, and therefore Member States, together with the help of institutions, will continue to work hard to fulfil these ambitions and take forward the actions needed to make the European Union stronger, more effective and, ultimately, safer.

name: Michael Gahler
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I would like to briefly reflect on a few points that have been raised by colleagues. First of all, thank you very much for the broad support that I believe this report deserves. We will organize a good majority for it. Secondly, I agree with all of my colleagues who have said that we need all aspects of foreign policy in this context, that is, from soft skills to strong diplomacy, and that includes development cooperation. I always try to sum it up: we must be able to use everything credibly in our external dealings with the Union, from verbal notes to battle tanks, and of course we must try to achieve this with the most peaceful means possible. I also believe that we have to seek solidarity with the United Nations, although I do not see ourselves as being completely dependent. If I now think of the Western Balkans, for example, or Bosnia and Herzegovina in particular: When it comes to defending Dayton, I could also imagine that Russia might veto it if we prevent Banja Luka from going there a referendum is taking place. Therefore we should reserve ourselves in our immediate surroundings to do what is necessary. I find it interesting when there is a broad range of opinions in some groups. In the ECR you can see that there are some who will stay in the EU and others who will leave the EU, and accordingly the opinion is somewhat different. However, I did not understand that if you are not in NATO yourself, that you are betting on NATO and not wanting the EU to become active in the field of defense. Turkey is actually also an argument for moving out of dependence on NATO - if necessary. Because if we have to fall back on NATO resources, a Turkish veto can block everything. And I want to actually have no veto from a Mr. Erdoğan in our own affairs.So I think we are on the right track with what we are proposing here.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: speaker. - Mr. president. We will not be a truly united Europe until the concern felt by the Baltic Republics about the proximity of Russia is not understood in Portugal and Spain. Or until Sweden does not understand what is the situation of Europeans living in Cyprus, or fear, or concern with which Greece sees what happens in Turkey. If we are divided, we are weak in all areas. If we stand up for ourselves together, we are strong and they will respect us more. The problem of each European, regardless of the nation they belong to, has to be the problem of all Europeans and that can only be achieved with a common defense that, indeed - as Mr. Jáuregui said - does not have and should not cost more . On the contrary, if instead of twenty-seven budgets we have a single budget, it is evident that we will save money. Because we will buy together, because we will investigate together, because we will create units together. I think it is obvious that we have to create the European internal defense market, which will serve small and medium-sized enterprises and which will serve European research. If we really aspire to do something together sometime, the first thing we learn from school, in the playground, at recess, after class, is that you are with someone when you defend yourself with someone. We will defend ourselves together, we will work together for the safety of all. And I have nothing else to add, except many thanks to those who will vote in favor and those who will vote against. Together, today we have made Europe a little stronger.

name: Przewodniczący.
text: - I am closing the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 March 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: written. - Make Europe's voice heard in the world - the EU is more influential today than ever, but when it comes to security and defense policy, individual member states dominate. The challenges facing the EU have grown: from the Syrian crisis to fighting poverty in Africa, from energy dependency to hybrid threats. But the Trump presidency and the upcoming Brexit also require a united Europe that speaks with one voice, loud and clear. A real common foreign policy can only work if the member states commit to a solidarity-based approach and then implement it. There must also be a strong role for countries like Austria without calling into question neutrality. The EU must not get stuck in its payment role, but must become a self-confident player. The Lisbon Treaty offers this possibility. Peace and stability in Europe cannot be taken for granted. They require active action. We should refrain from continuing to fund expensive headquarters and soliciting more funding without specifying how they will be used. Rather, we need a coordinated approach by the EU member states for a future-proof, capable European security and defense policy.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. - This is a report in which we make concrete recommendations in the light of the current EU legal framework for effective cooperation in the area of ​​security and defense. We argue that the European Defense Agency (EDA) and the permanent enhanced cooperation mechanism (PESCO) should be treated as EU sui generis institutions and financed from the Union budget, a budget that needs to be considerably strengthened. We highlight the role that the EDA should play in coordination between Member States, namely in the development of capacities and the acquisition of equipment, with economic and efficiency gains. We call for the creation of a permanent headquarters for CSDP and PESCO, and we clarify that no Member State that wants to integrate PESCO should be excluded. We call for the reform of the Athena mechanism, to ensure an equitable sharing of operating costs and for Member States to be encouraged to contribute forces, not to be constrained by their financial capabilities. More than ever, the EU needs to equip itself with the tools to ensure its own security and defense, in the face of threats common to all Member States and with the increasing unpredictability of acting within the framework of NATO, clearly broken into by Trump, say whatever your ministers say.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the own-initiative report by Urmas Paet, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and Sirpa Pietikäinen, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on an integrated policy for the European Union on the Arctic (2016/2228 (INI)) (A8-0032 / 2017).

name: Urmas Paet
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the geopolitical importance of the Arctic is growing. The climate change effects and growing competition for access to the Arctic natural resources and increasing economic activities have brought opportunities but also risks to the region. This also includes challenges to security. The Arctic has long been an area of constructive international cooperation and it has remained a low-tension cooperative regional order in the world. We want to keep it that way. We need to keep the Arctic a low-tension area. There is a need to avoid the militarisation of the Arctic. The EU has a long-standing engagement in the Arctic. Three EU Member States are full members of the Arctic Council and seven others are observers. Considering that the EU is the world’s leading funder in the Arctic, it should finally be able to become an observer as well. All of the EU Arctic Member States, as well as some other states, have their own national Arctic strategies, which include a security dimension, but the EU does not have such a strategy. Our report foresees the need for a more coherent EU internal and external policy, an Arctic strategy and a concrete action plan on the EU’s engagement in the Arctic taking into account all the aspects. That includes the foreign and security dimension. The geopolitical developments in the Arctic region affect the security situation in northern Europe and globally. Cooperation in the Arctic has been good between countries, but we cannot bury our heads in the sand. We need to acknowledge the increased activities of Russia in the Arctic, the opening of military bases and their increased military presence in the Russian Arctic. The report acknowledges the fact that Russia is more and more active in the Arctic region and that cooperation with Russia in this area must be continued with the aim of keeping the Arctic a low-tension area. The European Union should contribute in building civilian security mechanisms as well as in enhancing crisis and disaster management capacities, search and rescue infrastructure and support the development of infrastructure in the European Arctic, including infotechnology, and communications. There are three paragraphs in this report that were introduced during the Committee on Foreign Affairs/Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety joint committee votes that have caused concern in the Arctic Member States. These paragraphs talk about the ban on the oil and gas extraction in the Arctic that has an important energy security dimension for the European Union. First and foremost, oil and gas extraction in the Arctic is a sovereign decision of the Arctic states, as manifested in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, Article 77. The EU should not call for a ban on something that is a sovereign right of a state under international law. Secondly, it is important for the energy security of the EU. Gas accounts for about 25% of Europe’s primary energy demand. Norwegian gas covers more than 20% of the European consumption. More than half of the remaining resources are expected to be located north of the Arctic Circle. If we propose to ban the oil and gas extraction for the EU and EEA Arctic states, as proposed by these paragraphs, then we are deliberately putting ourselves in a more vulnerable position. What we do want is to have oil and gas extraction in the Arctic that these in line with safety regulations in the strongest terms, which is also already the case as regards EU and EEA Arctic countries. I would also like to thank my co-rapporteur, all the shadow rapporteurs and all of my colleagues for good cooperation in preparation of this report.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: demonstrator. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Urmas Paet, for his very good cooperation, as well as all my colleagues in the ENVI and AFET committees. I believe that our common message is clear, as we have already heard here: it is high time for the European Union to steel its Arctic policy. Firstly, the European Union is an Arctic player, as three of its Member States are located in the Arctic. Secondly, as with security policy, changes and challenges in the Arctic will be our challenges throughout the EU, and we have a special obligation and responsibility to take into account the specificities of the Arctic in terms of our own climate policy and our own use of natural resources. We all know that climate change in the Arctic is progressing about two degrees faster than in other regions. We know, for example, that the melting of ice over the last decade has exceeded all forecasts, and the same seems to continue. We know that the Arctic is a particularly vulnerable region where the effects, measured in terms of both time span and multiplier effects, are manifold: much longer, often more irreversible, such as deforestation or fish stock pollution, and reflected in a variety of ecosystems and livelihood opportunities. If we ruin the sustainable use of the resources of this vulnerable region, we will not only destroy the unique Arctic, but we will, for our part, accelerate climate change, destroy and threaten access to clean water, and the effects on global fish stocks will be permanent and dramatic. This eleventh moment is highlighted for the European Union because, sadly, paradoxically, it is precisely because of climate change that the race for natural resources in the northern and arctic regions is accelerating. The clear message in this report is therefore that the EU must have a strong responsibility and a strong role in the Arctic Council as an actor, to make peaceful co-operation based on the principles of research co-operation and peaceful co-operation a guiding principle, and to implement an Arctic environmental impact assessment that takes into account both multiple time spans, permanent damage and multiple multiplier effects in the case of major resource use projects such as energy industry. It is also absolutely essential to take into account the rights of indigenous peoples. The only indigenous peoples in Europe are in the Arctic, and so the report also calls for their own representation and financial support for representation in EU politics. It also emphasizes support for sustainable investment, especially those based on clean technology, better use of information technology and sustainable investment. Last but not least, we need more and more information. That is why we also call in the report for a permanent Arctic knowledge and science center and permanent funding for it.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf in particular of my colleagues Vice-President Mogherini and Commissioner Vella, I would like, on behalf of the Commission to welcome this own-initiative report on an integrated European Union policy for the Arctic presented by the two rapporteurs. Our joint communication sets out an integrated policy framework for dealing with the challenges and the opportunities in the Arctic and for enhancing the EU’s already substantial presence in in the region. Such a framework is needed because developments in the EU and the Arctic are interlinked in many ways, as we have just heard. The impact of the EU on the Arctic, and indeed of the Arctic on the EU, is becoming increasingly clear and pressing. Our communication focuses on three priorities. First, we must address the challenges facing the Arctic by responding to climate change and protecting the Arctic environment. The Arctic is warming, as we have heard, twice as fast as the rest of the world, but that affects not just the region itself, but also the rest of the world. The Arctic is home to 4 million people. Our second priority must therefore be to support its sustainable development, so that it is a place where people can continue to live, study and work. Our joint communication highlights that safeguarding the Arctic’s fragile environment and the sustainable development of the region can and must go hand in hand. It is not sustainable to only consider the economic development without due regard to the rich biodiversity and the consequences of climate change in the region, and it is not possible to aim to protect the fragile environment without considering the needs of the local communities and the potential for developing a vibrant economy in a sustainable way. This balancing effort is at the centre of everyone’s attention on Arctic matters, including national and local authorities of the Arctic States and also in multilateral fora. So it is no surprise that the draft resolution before you today shows that it has also been discussed extensively in this House. Our third priority is to strengthen cooperation with our Arctic partners, to address the challenges and opportunities we are discussing. Challenges like climate change are on a scale too big for any one state tackle alone, so international cooperation is, obviously, key. Across all these areas we have sought to emphasise the crucial role of science, research and innovation, and we have stressed the role of those who inhabit the Arctic, including indigenous peoples, in this process. We have included the Arctic within our recent initiative for better international ocean governance. The challenges that our oceans face today do not recognise national boundaries, therefore stronger efforts are needed globally to address governance issues in this context. Again, thank you very much for this report and the opportunity to discuss these important subjects.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. –  Mr President, one of the key points for the Fisheries Committee in giving an opinion on this important topic was to advocate that any further development of commercial fisheries in the Arctic region must take place in compliance with international agreements relating to this area. The right to fish, in fact the right to equal access to natural resources of the archipelago of Spitsbergen, is guaranteed by a non-discrimination clause of the Spitsbergen Treaty which was signed by all major European countries. Unfortunately, we are witnessing unjustified and gradual appropriation of fish resources in the area and preferential treatment of Norway, which is not respecting the provisions of international agreements. This leads European fishermen to bankruptcy, as well as allowing Norway to disregard and disrespect the European Union as a partner. We cannot accept this. Therefore, it is imperative that we fully address this issue in this report. In this context, I have tabled an amendment and I ask colleagues to support it.

name: Jens Nilsson
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Mr President! When the regional committee commented on the Arctic and had a discussion about it, the focus was on the region and the region's conditions for development. There is in fact a collaboration between the fourteen northernmost regions in Finland, Sweden and Norway, NSPA - Northern Sparsely Populated Areas, where 2.5 million people live. Development must also be ensured there. What we have said and which is now included in our joint opinion is that we must ensure that sufficient funds from cohesion policy and the funds are also available in these sparsely populated areas, with reference also to the Accession Treaty for Finland and Sweden from 1994. We also emphasize both the importance of indigenous peoples and the local community. The Commission should go hand in hand with the regions in this area. This is where people live who are incredibly careful about the Arctic, but who also want to survive. I am particularly pleased that we have the issue of setting up an Arctic Information Center, as it is needed in this region.

name: Michael Gahler
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! I would like to thank the two co-rapporteurs for a good report, which will certainly get a large majority here. As the European Union, we have a great interest in working as partners in the Arctic in a variety of areas with those who have their own territories there. It is a good thing that we have three Member States who are also full members of the Arctic Council and who certainly also represent our interests there. We as the European Union can offer a lot in the various policy areas because we are good there and we have a lot of experience in research and in other areas - including environmental protection - from other areas too. But I think we should hold back in areas where we don't have our own competencies. Unfortunately, we in the committee decided on political content such that we want to prescribe to states - also outside the EU - that we should aim for a drilling ban for oil and gas. I believe that we are going beyond our competencies, especially because we do not even have this as an acquis within the EU. So I hope that we can get this aspect out of the report in the final vote. As I said, the point is to act in partnership with the residents in order to represent our interests in the best possible way. I am confident that we will achieve that too.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
