text: On behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, I am really pleased that this report strongly emphasizes international cooperation and that cooperation takes place on an equal footing with väärttien with partners, and in compliance with international law and justice. This work has, in fact, worked so well and it is really interesting that, although there is a lot of tension in the world, cooperation with Russia, for example, in the Arctic has worked very well, and this report highlights that. The rapporteur, Mr Paet, rightly said that the European Union's great goal is to become a permanent observer in the Arctic Council. Why aren't we already? Well, simply because the European Parliament has angered Canada. The fact that Canada is opposed and that Russia is not really a friend of the European Union has put a brake on this. Our most important ally, partner and supporter has been Norway. I am a little afraid that if we now say in this report, for example, that drilling must stop precisely in the Arctic, where Norway has drilled oil and gas to high standards - fortunately we have no right to say that, because this is an INI report and no legislation. - yes, we will lose one good supporter of our entry as a permanent observer in the Arctic Council. The most important thing now is that we get a report that is balanced, that respects the right of sovereign countries to make their own decisions, and we are in a hurry that the Commission is really commissioning us and making the Arctic strategy that has been going on for nine years. I am sure that Parliament will give it its full support. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE)
text: blue card question.- Mr President, I find it a little problematic that Mr Jaakonsaari is talking about the need to respect the countries' own sovereign solutions.As if climate change is not something we all have in common, it is as if it is not important for the European Union to do its utmost to achieve a gradual total ban on highly dangerous oil drilling in the Arctic in the Arctic Council and other international fora.Why do you want to equate this now with having to become a member or observer of the Arctic Council?

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: the answer to the blue card question.- Mr Hautala, I emphasized that Arctic policy has been achieved through cooperation and respect for each other.This is illustrated by the Nordic spirit, the emphasis on the importance of dialogue.That is why I do not think it is right and fatal for the European Union if we go to say to some countries that you must stop drilling for oil and especially gas, even if you use the highest possible standards, for example, and you are very environmentally friendly.At the same time, why are we subjecting ourselves to much worse-done Russian energy and dependence on Russian energy?

name: Jørn Dohrmann
text: for the ECR Group. - Sir. Chairman! I would like to talk a little bit about the three controversial points, which are about oil and gas. The very idea of ​​this report is to strengthen European foreign policy in the Arctic, but when EU politicians want to tell the Arctic states how to manage their own natural resources, that idea is completely undermined. The EU must not decide on the oil and gas of non-EU countries! Dot! Right now, we parliamentarians talk so much about energy security. We will not be dependent on oil and gas from the Middle East and from Russia, we say. What does it look like, so to speak, to our main supplier, Norway, that they should cease their activities? Not the entire Arctic is frozen. The Arctic Circle stretches far to the south, out of the icy waters. It is not very well thought out to talk about such bans. Do you think it will be easier to get support for the EU to become a member of the Arctic Council with such announcements? That the proposal was made in part by the Five Star Movement and the Finnish Left-wing Alliance is one thing, but that the Social Democrats have supported this line is completely incomprehensible and foolish.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the EU is an Arctic actor and must have its own foreign policy and strategy for the Arctic. One that is based on sustainable development, but at the same time realistic and respects and respects the Member States in the region. More than four million people live in the area, so it is not a void area. There are more people living there than in many small EU Member States combined, so while we are talking about the environment, we must also take into account the opportunities for these people to live, to earn a living and also to move around. The Arctic is in many ways a sensitive and extreme region. In the coming years and decades, the Arctic will change perhaps more than in the past history of all mankind. This is due to the climate change that is advancing in these very polar regions. Climate change has far-reaching effects on people, the environment and the living conditions in that area. The whole of the environment, human life and the use of resources must be in balance. The interests of the various actors are in some respects cross-cutting, so finding a balance can be difficult, but it must be pursued and it can be found. Finding this balance is the most important task of the Arctic region, its states and peoples, and the EU in all possible fora. With regard to the use of resources, the vulnerability of the Arctic region must be borne in mind, and this report has sought to take the best possible account of it, as well as the conditions in which people live.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your good cooperation with the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs. In a challenging matter, the work went in a very constructive way. Our lives at a time when international relations have tightened all over the world, and that is also reflected in the Arctic report. We are committed to doing everything we can to bring climate change under control and, in the Arctic, the effects of climate will be more visible and reflected around the world. The future of the Arctic must be approached from the perspective of the environment and the rights of the region's indigenous peoples. If we are unable to reach an agreement through cooperation, the concern mentioned and expressed in our report about the rights of the indigenous peoples of the region and, for example, the potential of clean technology will remain largely a buzzword. I hope that we will be able to find solutions that shift the use of fossil fuels in the Arctic to more environmentally friendly alternatives. We have a duty to both the people of the region and the environment, and I therefore hope that we in Europe will have the courage to act as a mediator, to seek common solutions, to negotiate and to remember that a peaceful path is, after all, the best asset for the Arctic. I warmly support Mr Pietikäinen's idea of ​​an Arctic center and securing its funding.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! In November, it was spring weather in the Arctic. In February, 3 plus degrees were measured at Greenland's northernmost tip not far from the North Pole. Researchers have alerted about new heat records of as much as 20 degrees above normal. With the same temperature rise in Sweden, we would have had bathing weather in the middle of winter. The ice melts with each passing day, and when the white ice cover is replaced by dark water, the sun's rays are absorbed into the water, heating it and in this way the ice is also melted by the warmer water from below. We know that those who will be most affected by the melting ice are people in low-lying areas such as Bangladesh and small island nations in the Pacific. Where we Greens see an impending climate catastrophe, unfortunately others see a business opportunity. Under the ice cover rests more of the fossil fuels that have caused the warming from the beginning. We Greens therefore want to ban the exploitation of oil, gas and other natural resources, which risk damaging the climate and the sensitive Arctic environment. We want to set up new national reserves and an international moratorium on Arctic waters. Only then can we protect the Arctic and only then can we achieve the climate goals we have set for ourselves.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, this report on an integrated European Union policy for the Arctic undoubtedly contains very good intentions. Whether it is to preserve the ecosystem of this northern region, to guarantee the rights of indigenous people or to support scientific research, we can only agree. However, the increased involvement of the European Union in this part of the world, in particular via the Arctic Council, is not desirable, on the one hand, because the action of the European Union in this area is less legitimate than that of States at the international level and on the other hand, because it would reduce the influence of certain Member States which are historical assets or, like my country, France, observer members . Finally, this text considers it necessary to reaffirm - I quote - the interests of the Union vis-à-vis Russia. As often, the latter finds itself singled out by the European Union, when it should be our natural partner.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - The importance of the Arctic region is enormous, and it is increasingly recognized by the world. Climate change, the opening up of new navigation routes, new areas of fishing and natural resources, and increasing competition for access to the Arctic and its natural resources are prompting many countries to become more active in the region. Russia is currently the most active player. We also see China, which, although geographically inaccessible to the Arctic, bases its participation in the exploitation of its resources on the fact that the Arctic and its assets belong to all humankind, and not just to those countries that belong to the Arctic region. The European Union has a long-standing commitment in the Arctic: EU Member States participate in the work of the Arctic Council, and the European Union is waiting, as has already been said, for observer status on this council. It is vital that the Arctic remains a region of low tension and that the militarization of this region is avoided. We are following with great concern the developments in the region where Russia is setting up military bases, establishing an Arctic military district. The European Commission's communication did not really address the security aspects of the Arctic, so it is good that the Global Strategy has addressed this. We, the European Union, need to devote much more attention and resources to implementing Arctic policy. The EU definitely needs a more integrated, comprehensive Arctic policy. Finally, I agree with what Mr Wałęsa said and support his amendment.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Madam President! In the old days, a canary was sent with the workers down into the coal mines. This was so that the bird could warn them if the oxygen was about to run out. The canary was sensitive and felt oxygen depletion before the coal miners. The canary was simply important for survival. The Arctic is the canary of the earth! The Arctic shows us the true state of the planet. The Arctic shows us that climate change is here and that it is violent. The ice at the North Pole has melted to a greater extent and at a faster speed than any expert had predicted. So right now, the Arctic is alarming the whole world that we need to take climate change deeply seriously. And that is what we are doing in this report. It is also important to keep in mind that climate change has not been created by the Arctic or by the countries of the Arctic. But the area's air, water and the citizens there have to live with the consequences of climate change. When we in the European Parliament have drawn up this report, it is because we want to send our message to the Arctic that the area is important to us, both in terms of security policy, the environment and the climate, and that the area is important to the planet in general. The EU must offer the Arctic countries a dialogue and close cooperation on combating and reducing climate change and helping to protect the amazing nature that exists. Their challenges are the responsibility of us all. Air pollution in the Arctic comes primarily from Asia, North America and Europe, and water pollution is created by transport from continent to continent. It is therefore our responsibility to help ensure that we reduce this pollution. Our report contains a large number of proposals for how we can protect the environment and the climate. It is important that we help, but it is also important that we do it in a way where we enter into dialogue with the countries around the Arctic, so that together in a dignified cooperation we can do something about climate change and environmental pollution.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: –  Madam President, there are Polish interests in the Arctic and therefore I express my disapproval of a drilling ban as well as the concept of selective engagement with Russia. Why, after a negative experience in the eastern neighbourhood and in Syria, after military steps taken in the Arctic by Russia, should we expect peaceful cooperation there?

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, I welcome the report by my colleague Pietikäinen and my colleague Paet. I believe that this is a major step towards an integrated European Union policy towards the Arctic and that this policy is essential for the European Union to take a leading position in the negotiations in the Arctic Council because preserving the Arctic is a global priority and not just a regional one. a fact or regional problem that we must pay attention to. What I would also point out is that we’ve probably all seen satellite images of NASA or other agencies showing how the ice surface in the Arctic is shrinking over the years. And we must not actually view this as an opportunity for a business that wants to see just that as a gift to be able to further explore and exploit oil and gas. And that is why I am in favor of a moratorium on oil and gas exploration and exploitation in the Arctic in order to preserve it for the future and to actually ensure the sustainability of the development of countries that would be threatened by rising sea levels.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - We need action, action to force Norway and also Russia to finally respect the 1920 Treaty of Spitsbergen. This is necessary for the other goals we pursue for our Arctic strategy: optimal but sustainable use of raw materials and respect for international treaties. With Norway for years denying our herring fishermen access to the waters around Spitsbergen and with many ships remaining in their ports for fear of being brought up or detained, Europe must act and respond. In 2015, Dutch herring fishermen had to flee the Norwegian coast guard for fear of being detained. Norway is challenging the European Union and in the meantime just admitting Russian fishermen and leaving them alone. Norwegian judges have rightly condemned the actions of their own Norwegian navy and coastguard against our snow crab fishermen and Norway is still not listening. Let's be clear: we respect the twelve-mile zone. The waters around Spitsbergen outside the zone are accessible to our fishermen according to international law, also for the fishing of snow crab and also for other commercial activities and treaty partners. Norway's stance is deeply troubling and casts a shadow on the future of Atlantic fishing and European Arctic exploration. We must forcefully call Norway to order: stay away from our fishermen of Spitsbergen in the future. We must take action for our fishermen, for international law and for other interests.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the biodiversity of the Arctic and the nature of its ecosystems give it a critical importance for the biological, chemical and physical balance of the entire planet. The industrial exploitation of resources therefore poses special challenges in the Arctic and calls for urgent international cooperation. The destruction of boreal ices is already releasing methane from permafrost soils, thus increasing global warming. Going further is like fueling a fire with gasoline. The Arctic must be seen as our canary in a coal mine, as colleague Schaldemose said, an alarm system to accelerate actions that reduce human processes that amplify global warming. Exploring Arctic resources has to be viewed with great concern. A new source of exploitation of fossil resources will not be compatible with the ambitions of a decarbonized economy and with the Paris Agreement. The European Union is in a privileged position to facilitate cooperation and dialogue between the countries concerned. Three principles must emerge: protection, sustainable and precautionary use and international cooperation. The fact is that today's economies live in a state of fossil energy addiction, a civilizational alcohol addiction that we are not trying to get out of. Opening the “cabaret de la dernière chance” in the Arctic, where, misfits, we will drink more and more, and another glass, will be the last sign of civilizational recklessness.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - The fragile Arctic is definitely in danger. The melting ice sheet and increasing human activity are a serious threat. Temperatures have risen almost twice as fast as the global average in recent years. In addition, there is a proven interaction between our activities and the North Pole. We influence the environment and climate in the Arctic and vice versa. The geostrategic importance of the area can hardly be overestimated. The resolution rightly stresses the importance of stability in the Arctic for people, the environment and the economy. I will fully support the text, including the paragraphs calling for an end to oil and gas extraction in the Arctic. The exploitation of oil and gas in the Arctic has always been controversial. It is particularly dangerous for the environment and also very expensive. The challenges in the field of energy security must not give free rein to Arctic oil, quite the contrary. It is precisely the transition to a low-carbon society that makes the EU less dependent on fossil fuels that should improve our energy security.

name: Marco Affronte (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with a strange paradox. We have attacked and exploited all the resources of the planet as if they were infinite and without seeing a tomorrow, without thinking about the consequences. This has caused enormous damage to the environment, of which the worst of all is climate change. Now climate change has its very serious repercussions on a very delicate environment, which is the Arctic, and we, instead of standing up to defend this environment that is severely suffering the consequences of climate change, see it as a new frontier of resources to be exploit again without thinking about the consequences and only at a certain point, looking back, will we see what we have caused. Parliament's report is good: it contains important points which can give a strong signal. Who is causing these climate changes and the exploitation of fossils? At least in that area stop the exploitation of fossil resources.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Arctic area is not only a common environmental or economic programme. The Arctic is more and more becoming a vast region of international competition for natural resources, transport corridors and specific interests, with increased military importance.  The EU has to play a relevant and constructive role here. The minimum would be to become a full observer on the Arctic Council. Achieving this status has been blocked by Russia, which is a main beneficiary in the Arctic region. The absence of the EU has had adverse effects on territorial cooperation and on a whole range of policies. The EU could also facilitate the setting up of cross-border e-governance and e-services structures for the whole region.  The call for a total ban on offshore drilling in the Arctic waters and on extraction of Arctic oil and gas may be unbalanced and impractical, because Norway has been extending oil drilling and exploring. I am especially concerned that Greenland will thus be forbidden to make use of its fishing resources and oil resources. What we need is a specific policy, a strategy by the Commission to defend EU interests in this area.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the times we live in require clear positions from all global players and the European Union, in particular, in the most sensitive areas for the sustainability of the planet. The signals given by the new American administration and the possible contagion of other global resource explorers is a great risk for the planet, but at the same time, it opens a window of opportunity for European leadership in the transition to the green and blue economy. I therefore emphasize the importance of this own-initiative report. The environmental conditions of the North Seas are so sensitive and vulnerable that even a slight disturbance to their structure can have irreversible consequences. The Arctic region is already suffering the impacts of climate change, with the acceleration of melting glaciers. Increased exploitation of oil and gas reserves in the region would increase the imbalance of its ecosystems. Therefore, in a context of energy transition in all areas of society and, in particular, in transport, a cautious approach, as proposed in the report under consideration, seems to me to be the most appropriate.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Urmas Paet and Sirpa Pietikäinen, for their hard work, which has resulted in a very good report after the vote in committee - a result which I really hope will stand up in tomorrow's vote in plenary. The ice sheet in the Arctic is melting faster and faster with each passing year. When the ice shrinks, areas where no one has fished before are exposed. It is basically the only area on the earth's surface that is completely untouched by humans. At the same time, more and more vessels are fishing with bottom trawls and further north as the ice melts. We still lack science on these vulnerable ecosystems in the Arctic. We in the EU must therefore work for a total moratorium on industrial fishing and a ban on the use of bottom trawls in waters where no fishing has taken place before. We also need to establish a marine protected area in the international waters around the North Pole where all extraction, including oil, gas and fishing, is prohibited. It is important for the EU to pursue the issue to protect the Arctic from all forms of exploitation. If we are to reach our climate goals with a maximum of 1.5 degrees warming, all extraction of oil and gas must be banned. I urge everyone to vote for a halt to oil drilling today.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Dear Colleagues, there are great social, environmental and economic challenges in the Arctic region: a sparse and dispersed population over a wide area, the dramatic effect of climate change, increasing competition in access to its natural and mineral resources and the opening of new shipping routes and fishing zones. The Arctic is, at the same time, a region of increasing geostrategic importance. For all these reasons, our debate is of particular importance, which is not unrelated to the fact that today we live in a time of uncertainty and the resurgence of dangerous protectionist policies, which open up an unknown about the future of the Arctic region. Scientific assessments show us well that it is a fragile and at risk ecosystem, which has more than half of the world's wetlands, whose volume of sea ice present during the summer has dropped by more than 40% in 35 years, and that The increase in temperature has grown at a rate approximately twice that of the global average. Dear colleagues, climate change in the Arctic has an important impact on coastal regions worldwide, including the European Union. Coastal erosion and rising sea levels are just a few of the environmental problems caused by climate change in the Arctic that are being felt drastically all over the world. I therefore believe that this own-initiative report is an important step for the European Union to play a leading role in safeguarding the Arctic's environmental weaknesses and the fundamental rights of indigenous peoples and local populations. But, dear colleagues, time is of the essence and the moment is one of action and not of mere intentions.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must act swiftly to safeguard the Arctic to avoid a militarization of the area and to preserve the fragile ecosystem from climate change and aggressive competition for natural resources. We must first of all ensure peaceful cooperation in the Arctic region. The Arctic environment is particularly fragile and requires prudent policies that favor sustainable development, which takes into account the peculiarities of the places. A reduction in oil and gas extraction activities would be desirable, but also a halt to offshore drilling to search for fossil fuels. The European Union must work in international fora to foster a shared strategy for the Arctic that makes it possible to achieve the goal of a low-carbon economy. There is a risk of overexploitation also of fish resources, it is essential to determine the fishing levels that allow to preserve fish stocks on the basis of scientific, reliable and prudent assessments but which could also recommend a moratorium on industrial fishing of Arctic waters.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, the volume of Arctic Ocean glaciers and adjacent seas has been declining rapidly since 1984, with the lowest levels of Arctic and Antarctic ice being recorded in January. The rising concentration of carbon dioxide over the last 50 years has raised the surface temperature in the Arctic by 2 degrees, and while the Arctic is sounding the alarm, international competition for access to and exploitation of its natural resources is growing. The European Union is stepping up its efforts to join the Arctic Council, aiming to increase its influence in an area that is said to have vast unexplored oil and gas reserves. It is estimated that up to 25% of the planet's natural reserves of natural gas and oil can be found in the Arctic. The European Union strategy for the Arctic must focus mainly on the protection and conservation of the region as well as on the promotion of sustainable use of its resources.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: - The European Union, as a global player, has no right to ignore such large and important regions as the Arctic.Many essential interests intersect in the Arctic, i.y.: the division of territories between neighboring countries, the use of the energy resources located there, the emergence of important and new transport routes, the conservation of the resources obtained in the light of climate change and the increase of military capabilities and their wider deployment throughout the region.There are other problems.Thus, the complex problems that are particularly evident in the Arctic, such as the extreme climate, on the one hand, and the vast natural resources there, on the other, high-investment and attractive infrastructure projects, and on the other, require a broad and effective partnership.I personally welcome the European Union's initiative to undertake this work, and I believe that together we can achieve excellent results.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, I would like to say at the outset that I agree with the rapporteurs on almost everything, and it is true that, as the geopolitical value of the Arctic increases, so do the risks. We must protect it and keep it away from the competitions of the world; we must finally keep a place on earth away from wars and rivalries. It is the ultimate foundation for world peace. The European Union must develop cooperation policies to mitigate, if not eliminate, risks. Whatever is done on the issue of mining must be done with honest consultation between the states of the region but also with the contribution of the European Union.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: –  Madam President, many of you may not have noticed that Norway has just this week announced that they will open 93 new blocks in the very northernmost waters of the Barents Sea for oil drilling. I believe that with Norway being a part of the European Economic Area, a very close partner of the European Union, we have to care about that. Many colleagues have spoken very well about the alarming pace of climate change in the Arctic and believe me, a lot is at stake. If the Gulf Stream changes its course we will all be in trouble in the North.  I think we should not be polite to Norway and accept that they do this. I think we have to accept the wordings in the report that the Commission and the Member States should work very hard on international fora to get a full ban on Arctic oil drilling. It is also the most dangerous kind of oil drilling that there is.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Arctic is a precious ecosystem that plays a crucial role in regulating ocean currents and the climate of the entire planet. If he gets sick, the world gets sick, which is not already in excellent health. But the earth fever for some is just another opportunity to profit. As the ice recedes due to climate change, exploiting these waters rich in life and natural resources becomes easier and easier. Intensive fishing, navigation, drilling for fossil fuels threaten this ecosystem. The Norwegian government just this week proposed a record expansion of oil and gas exploration in the Arctic. The risk of an exploitation race, as well as an environmental catastrophe, can lead to geopolitical and military tensions in these international waters and in this land that must not belong to anyone. We welcome this report and ask that the EU be the herald of a new way of managing this area, which must not be exploited for its resources but which must rather become a large space for research and monitoring of changes. climate: a true arctic sanctuary. Above all, we ask for the promotion of an international agreement for the total ban on mining activities. The Arctic, like our Earth, we did not inherit from our fathers: we borrowed it from our children.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you to everyone here this evening for this report first of all, and for this evening’s debate which has been very valuable and which we will take fully into account as we implement our Arctic policy communication.  Just a couple of comments on that if I may. The EU-Arctic stakeholder forum has now been set up and has met on a number of occasions. We are also continuing to engage with Arctic indigenous people and local communities. The next Arctic stakeholder forum session and annual dialogue meeting will be organised in the context of the EU high-level event on Arctic policy, which is being organised together with Vice-President Mogherini in Finland in mid-June.  In terms of international ocean governance, and in particular the ongoing work on an international agreement to prevent unregulated fisheries in the central Arctic Ocean, the Commission hopes a deal on such an agreement might be reached in Reykjavik as early as next week.  Another point I would like to draw attention to is the International Polar Code which entered into force in January. It creates mandatory provisions covering safety and pollution prevention measures that apply to ships navigating through polar waters, and also includes guidance on implementation, design, construction, environmental protection, equipment, training and operational matters.  We are making progress on environmental policies that will contribute to the protection of the Arctic environment. We have just allocated funding to a project to address the problem of black carbon in the Arctic. On oil and gas, there is not, of course, any oil and gas exploration in the EU Arctic. Offshore activities are taking place in the territorial waters of third countries. We will continue to call for the highest standards both of accident prevention and environmental control. We can and we must remain vigilant and we need to continue to drive forward our shared objectives in close partnership with all the Arctic stakeholders.

name: Urmas Paet
text: rapporteur. –  Madam President, I would like to thank all my colleagues and the Commissioner. While overall we have reached, I guess, a good agreement on this report, there is still, as we all realise, one open question on oil and gas extraction that we need to vote on tomorrow. I would just like to mention that the EU has outlined energy security as one of the cornerstones of the Energy Union strategy and as a key political priority, and this means less dependency on non-European countries and sources and also diversifying our own energy sources here in Europe. Also in 2014, the European Parliament itself underlined that the EU will be a main consumer of Arctic natural gas.  The second remark I want to make is that it should be very clear that the EU has to stick very strongly to international law whatever the developments in the Arctic area. Finally, I would like to conclude my statement by saying that we have worked long and hard with the co-rapporteur Sirpa Pietikäinen on this paper to take into account both the concrete environmental and security aspects. However, hopefully the report will give an impetus for a real EU-Arctic strategy that takes into account the realities on the ground, with a sustainable, environmental and conflict-free future in mind.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, firstly I would like to underline our special responsibility towards the indigenous people, namely the Sami people. Thank you to the Commission for taking some affirmative actions on this side. We are quite eager, as we should be, to tell third countries how to deal with their minorities and indigenous peoples, and indeed, this is something we should take better into account in our own activities. Then of course there is the question of Russia and other Arctic areas and the run for natural resources threatening their livelihoods and their right to land very seriously. My second point would be the role of the EU in the Arctic. Tuna fish is not only a property and issue concerning Italy and Greece, and this is the point of our common fisheries policy and debate in general. So the Arctic itself is not the property of any country willing to claim so; it is a common heritage, like the fish, and this is, of course, underlined with the abundance of international agreements and conventions such as anglers or the role of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO), and so on. This is exactly why we need the EU to be stronger in the Arctic policy, in the Arctic Council and international negotiations. I welcome the Commission’s announcement being very strong here. The EU is not the third party in the area; it is an Arctic actor, and this is something, I think, that the Commission, the Council and the EU as a whole should very clearly have in mind. Lastly, I hope that they we can duly treat the Arctic as our common heritage. If we fail on that, we will also fail in many other policies.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 16 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. - If we are here this evening talking about future activities in the Arctic, it is above all a tragedy for our planet, in the face of which we are facing bad luck. If it is undeniable that a new area of ​​human activity is emerging, it is imperative that we do not reproduce the same errors there as on land, or even sometimes at sea. It is imperative that this area is understood in a concerted manner, between all political actors and possible future users of the sea. With regard to fishing in particular, the EU will have to defend in international bodies the precautionary approach and sustainable development that 'it applies to its waters. While we have just adopted the freeze on the footprint of deep-sea fishing activities in European waters, and for some years already in NEAFC, we will have to consider it also as a protective measure in the Arctic area. But be careful, preserving the pristine seabed of deep-sea fishing will make no sense if other activities destroy them in a much more radical and irremediable way. It will take a consistent and fair approach to all uses.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - Mr President, the importance of the Arctic region is growing in our modern world. The European Union has a long history of commitment to history, geography, the economy and research in the Arctic and has a major influence on politics throughout the region. It must be borne in mind that geopolitical changes in the Arctic also affect the security situation in Northern Europe and the world. The Arctic region is particularly primitive and vulnerable to human activity. The main goal of the world community must be to preserve and strengthen the capacity of the Arctic ecosystem. In this area, EU investment and structural funds play a vital role in the development of the European Arctic, promoting sustainable economic growth and the creation of quality jobs in future-oriented sectors. There is therefore a need to develop the Arctic's natural resources responsibly and in moderation in such a way as to avoid destroying the current natural structure. To this end, scientific and research cooperation between all international stakeholders in Arctic research should be encouraged and facilitated. The Commission's proposal to set up a stakeholder forum focusing on local actors is a very welcome initiative.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Charles Tannock, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Commission's 2016 report on Montenegro (2016/2309 (INI)) (A8-0050 / 2017).

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, this June will mark five years since Montenegro began accession negotiations. Having now opened 26 of the 33 chapters, with two of these provisionally closed already, the country’s strong progress as an EU candidate is clear to all. In the key areas of chapters 23 and 24 concerning justice and home affairs, genuine reform by the government of Montenegro in these areas is evident. Of course tackling organised crime and corruption remains a priority, but it is important we recognise that at the political level reforms have been implemented, and so it is now the time to give the support that is needed for these changes to take root.  Last year was an important one for Montenegro. Parliamentary elections took place in October. There has been a change of prime minister – I was delighted to meet the new prime minister Marković earlier this year in Brussels – and the accession protocol to join NATO was signed. The elections were held under a new regulatory framework with individual voter registration and an electronic identification system in place. A government of electoral trust was formed in the few months preceding the election, which saw opposition parties in charge of over a dozen state organisations and several ministries, to ensure a level playing field before the election.  This followed concerns from some members of the opposition parties about the possibility of undue influence from the governing parties who could abuse or use administrative resources of the state. I believe that the solution was a pragmatic one, a fair one, and welcomed by all, and I was particularly pleased to see this resolved internally within Montenegro. International observers of the elections reported them to be free and fair, with fundamental freedoms generally respected by all. I am aware that there were some concerns about the closure of certain social media platforms on the day of the election, but this must be seen in the wider context of the allegations of a coup and assassination attempt against the then prime minister Đukanović and a backdrop of attempts to influence events by external parties. Indeed the closures in question were implemented by the Agency for Electronic Communication and lasted for a mere hour and a half.  With regard to the planned coup and assassination, judicial investigations continue, but there is a growing consensus amongst both the Montenegrin authorities and EU governments that the planned attack on the then prime minister was a real and credible threat. I remain deeply concerned about the situation and I believe that it is illustrative of the growing presence that Russia is seeking on the ground to exert on Montenegro, and other countries for that matter in the Western Balkans region. Intelligence linking Eduard Shishmakov, a Russian national and a known GRU agent, to the plot, supports claims of Russian participation. It is clear that there is an attempt now to prevent Montenegrin accession to NATO in May, and also to disrupt its EU trajectory. It is for this reason that it is more important than ever for all the political parties to engage fully and properly in the parliamentary democratic process. The continued boycott of the parliament by the opposition is therefore very disappointing to friends of Montenegro, and extremely damaging to the long-term credibility of Montenegro’s democratic processes and institutions. I am increasingly concerned by the motives of some regarding the parliamentary boycott, and I now call from this House on all of those taking part in the boycott to consider the effects of their actions and the forces that they are helping to legitimise by their continued participation in not going to parliament.  As Montenegro now seeks to join NATO later this year, I think it is key that we in this House demonstrate our support for that decision. NATO and the EU are of course two very separate institutions, but from the perspective of Montenegro the two together represent a Euro-Atlanticist pivot. For reasons discussed earlier in my speech it is an important time now to support that agenda and I hope that when we all vote tomorrow we will all feel minded to support the text as it is currently present in the resolution.  I have always described Montenegro, for the last seven years as the standing rapporteur, as a good news story of the Western Balkans, and I believe that this is still the case today. At the moment, however, we are hearing less and less good news stories from other countries in the region. I therefore welcome the recent visit of the High Representative Federica Mogherini to the region and wholeheartedly support her message that the door remains open to all countries of the Western Balkans towards EU membership. It is vital that we ensure this message gets across. Montenegro has shown how this can work, and I hope this will continue to be so for itself and all its neighbours.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Before I give the floor to Minister Borg, I would like to express my understanding that you will have to leave a little early because you have to catch your plane.I am sure that you will in any case still listen to the debate on the Internet and also know what the European Parliament thinks about this important issue.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is a great pleasure to be with you once again. You have been here all day since 9.00 in the morning, not least to discuss the 2016 report on Montenegro. As you know, the Western Balkans featured on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council and the European Council last week, and on both occasions Member States reconfirmed the European Union’s engagement with the region, including through deepening political and the economic ties. Last week the European Council conclusions clearly reaffirmed the unequivocal support for the European perspective of the Western Balkans. In this spirit, the Presidency is committed to advancing the enlargement process in full respect of the basic principles of conditionality and on merit.  Montenegro remains the frontrunner in the accession process and it made further progress last year. We welcome, in particular, the latest accession conference of 13 December, where it was possible to open two further negotiating chapters: Chapter 11 on Agriculture and Rural Development and Chapter 19 on Social Policy and Employment. With a view to advancing negotiations, the Council continues to pay close attention to Montenegro’s progress in the rule of law, which, as per the negotiating framework, determines the overall pace of Montenegro’s negotiation process. As the report rightly points out, the legal framework and institutional set-up in this area are largely complete. Progress has been registered, but further implementation remains key, building on the results achieved so far and also leading to a strengthened and sustainable track record, in particular in the fight against corruption and organised crime.  The need for a continued focus on fundamental reforms is also something clearly expressed in your draft resolution and in the Commission’s report. They spell out important challenges for Montenegro to ensure freedom of expression and media freedom, to pursue public administration reform, and to strengthen the independence of institutions. On the economic side, Montenegro needs to take measures to ensure fiscal sustainability, to control public, and to improve the trade balance and the business environment. Advances on the rule of law can make a significant contribution in this regard.  Whilst progress has been made, there are still a number of reforms which Montenegro needs to carry out. 2017 will be an important year for Montenegro’s Euro-Atlantic integration, and we encourage the country to build on the progress already made and to take the reform process forward.  The process should not be considered merely as being an accession requirement, but a means leading to a more stable, prosperous and fair country. In this respect, one cannot over emphasise the importance of taking ownership of these reforms, which first and foremost are in the interest of, and to, the Montenegrin people.  We are well aware that Montenegro is currently facing a difficult political situation. It remains important for the government to maintain political commitment to the reform process and for all political parties to re-engage in a constructive dialogue, notably within the Parliament. The Council also closely followed Montenegro’s parliamentary elections in October and took good note of the overall positive assessment by the OSCE. Alleged irregularities in the elections need to be investigated, along with follow-up to the recommendations by international election observers. The clear messages in your draft resolution are well appreciated. I would also like to highlight two points regarding Montenegro’s external relations. In the area of foreign policy, the country remains a reliable partner to the European Union. Let me use this opportunity to strongly commend Montenegro for its consistent cooperation in this regard and in particular for its full alignment with the EU common foreign and security policy. Montenegro also continues to play a positive role in further developing regional cooperation and in advancing good neighbourly relations. In light of the overall situation in the Western Balkans, we should continue to highlight this point, as it actively contributes to the stabilisation of the very same region. In summary, Montenegro continues to make steady progress in the EU accession negotiations and maintains its good cooperation with the EU and its neighbours in the region. Looking ahead, we hope to move the accession negotiations forward under our presidency by opening and provisionally closing those negotiating chapters which are technically ready with Montenegro.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to start, in particular on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Hahn, by extending thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, for this very well-balanced report. Indeed, may I extend my thanks to all here who contributed to this important work. As we have been hearing, Montenegro has made steady progress on its EU path. Rule of Law is the fundamental element that will continue to determine the pace of the accession negotiations. The revised legal and institutional framework is largely in place and now needs to deliver further results. Montenegro is strongly committed to regional cooperation, as ministers noted, and has good relations with its neighbouring countries. In the Western Balkan context that is no minor achievement. Let me also reiterate our praise for Montenegro’s complete alignment with the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy, as Mr Borg said. Montenegro is a country with a clear EU perspective and, undoubtedly, the front-runner in the EU integration process with, as we have heard, 26 chapters open for negotiation, two of which are provisionally closed. Opinion polls show overwhelming support for EU membership, so in many ways Montenegro is, indeed, the good news story in the region, if the rapporteur will forgive me for pinching his expression. There are, of course, certain challenges, and it is fitting to discuss these with you here this evening in a parliamentary setting. Unfortunately, in Montenegro, parliament is half empty, as the opposition is boycotting the work of this key institution. We share the concerns already expressed over this, and the Commission’s repeated message to all the political parties has been to work out a compromise and to return the political debate to parliament, where it belongs. A boycott is not a sustainable solution, even less for a negotiating country. As Montenegro stands at the doorstep of NATO, the external pressure on it is mounting, but we trust that the Montenegrin leaders in government and in opposition will be wise enough to put their differences aside and to work together to preserve the progress made in Euro-Atlantic integration over the years – in fact, since their independence. The October 2016 parliamentary elections were held under a substantially revised legal framework, and our assessment is based on the OSCE/ODIHR report. We now expect all political groups to return to constructive engagement and to work together to implement the ODIHR recommendations on further election reforms. Inclusive dialogue is crucial for elections and EU-related reforms, as well as the overall modernisation of the country. Furthermore, we expect the relevant domestic authorities swiftly and transparently to conclude the investigation of the election day events, in accordance with domestic laws and international standards. We all, I am sure, look forward to the easing of political tensions and the continuation of the EU integration process, most notably the creation of a sustainable track record in the fight against corruption and organised crime. Fiscal imbalances should also be addressed in a determined way by implementing the approved budget and adopting a fiscal consolidation plan. Last week’s European Council unequivocally reaffirmed the European perspective of the Western Balkans, so this is a good moment to build momentum. A balanced economic environment and strong sense of rule of law will bring the necessary business opportunities and investment to Montenegro. The EU is assisting with technical advice and financial investment, so that the journey towards EU membership can already bring benefits to Montenegrin citizens, ranging from students to entrepreneurs, from farmers to consumers.

name: Андрей Ковачев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - With the European Union turning to its own internal problems and the recent changes in Washington, a political vacuum has arisen in the Western Balkans, which has allowed Russia to increase its influence in the region. This influence has strengthened Russia's geopolitical presence and called into question the Euro-Atlantic orientation of the countries in the region. On the other hand, corruption, dependent media and an inefficient judiciary in a number of countries in the region allow certain leaders to escalate tensions through nationalist talk and inter-ethnic opposition, posing as saviors of the nation, while this rhetoric is a cover for economic crimes. and illegal activities. In the Balkan vacuum, such nationalist sparks as the Bosnian referendum, the attempted coup in Montenegro, nationalist speeches in Serbia against EU member states such as Bulgaria, and the situation in Macedonia are not harmless. On the one hand, we must send a strong signal that the countries of the region have their own European perspective, with a specific time frame. On the other hand, we must encourage them to limit nationalist rhetoric, anti-democratic abuses and corruption and to pursue reforms in various sectors to meet the criteria for membership. In this regard, it is no less important to continue supporting the Euro-Atlantic integration of the Western Balkans, as this is crucial for the stability and progress of the region. In 2016, we opened the door for Montenegro to become a member of the Alliance. So far, 25 members have signed the accession protocol so that Montenegro can become the 29th member of NATO. Montenegro has made steady progress in the negotiation process, with 26 chapters currently open. I welcome the reform of public administration and public finance management, the establishment of the anti-corruption agency and 100% compliance of the country's foreign policy with the common security and defense policy.I call for support for Mr Tanak's report, and especially for the amendments that support Montenegro's direction of staying on the path to Euro-Atlantic development.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D team. - Madam President, Montenegro remains the champion of the Western Balkans on its way to the European Union, 26 of the 35 chapters have been closed, of which 2 have been temporarily closed. I want to congratulate the government on the relatively good conduct of the elections, as confirmed by OASA observers. As a Socialist Group, we welcome the country's efforts all these years, in the process of successfully concluding the negotiations. But we must avoid reform fatigue, which can create obstacles. That is why, in the resolution, in addition to the important reforms that have taken place, we emphasize the need for additional efforts in the areas of public administration, the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime. We are still waiting for actions to tackle tax evasion, high social inequalities, long-term unemployment and poverty, taking advantage of the recent opening of Chapter 19. Social progress is for us an important factor in the accession process. I would also like to note that this report comes at a very critical time for the country. On election day, some appear to have attempted to assassinate former Prime Minister Djukanovic and overthrow the legitimately elected government. Fortunately they failed. We await the outcome of the inquiries by the middle of next month and call on the European Commission and the High Representative to monitor developments closely. I would also like to call on the Member States as well as third countries to work with the Montenegrin authorities to fully and transparently investigate the case. In this context, we must thank Serbia for its constructive role. The opposition should also recognize the result of the elections and return to Parliament, avoiding actions that strengthen political climate and divide society.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I congratulate Charles Tannock and share his assessment, in particular concerning the Euro—Atlantic integration and internal security. I would like to stress the necessity to make the positive processes in place more inclusive and also engage heavily in combating corruption. Not all signs of fatigue that are visible in Montenegro are due to Russia’s influence.

name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, Colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking Mr. Tannock for his good cooperation and for his measured progress report on Montenegro in 2016. Montenegro is a progressive country. It has passed many laws and created institutions, but there is still much to be done in key areas such as the judiciary, public administration, the fight against corruption, media freedom, which shows that the process of a country's accession to the European Union is demanding and can be discouraging. and that country, but also the European Union on this very important path because it is a thorough transformation of one state and the whole society. That's why it's not easy at all. Montenegro also has special problems and difficulties, and that is the division within the state itself around the fundamental issues facing the state and, of course, such divided and weak countries are easy prey, fertile ground for negative external influences. Given the situation, not only in Montenegro but also the deteriorating situation in the entire Western Balkans, which means unresolved issues for many years, internal divisions, blockades, increased involvement of countries that, it seems to me, do not do well for the Western Balkans , a stronger, more engaged presence of the European Union is especially important in Montenegro, but also in other countries of the Western Balkans. This is in the interest not only of these countries but also of the European Union because the Western Balkans is geographically the space of the European Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Montenegro is facing a very serious process of accession to the European Union, and I also support the efforts of the European Union and the Parliament to overcome the chronic conflicts and external interventions in have so tragically affected the lives of ordinary people in this particular corner of Europe. Montenegro is particularly plagued by internal strife, and it is our duty to be helpful in developing those institutions that will make political life orderly and functional, but we cannot, in a supervisory manner, seek to impose our own terms and aspirations. The report, to some extent, unfortunately serves, rather than alleviates, the European Union's conflict with Russia. The reports and appeals regarding the country's membership in NATO will unfortunately create new conflicts within it, given that society there is already very divided on this issue. As the European Parliament, our goal should be to deepen our relations with Montenegro so that it can tackle the problems it faces, such as corruption, organized crime, poverty and the rule of law.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank my colleague Mr Tannock and the shadows for their very good cooperation and a very well-drafted and balanced report. Montenegro has already made progress but still more needs to be done, whether on corruption, organised crime, reform of the judiciary, media freedom, the rights of ethnic and sexual minorities and gender equality. Overall there has been some progress, but it is still not enough. Nevertheless, I would like to congratulate the Montenegrin Government and citizens for the progress they have already achieved in their progress towards the European Union. The issue of election day has already been raised. I have to say that, as Greens, although we have no doubt about Russian influence – not just in Montenegro but also in other parts of the region – we would have liked to separate the language on Russian influence and on the coup attempt on election day, because this is still under investigation. We do not yet have any independent information about what really happened. We would also have liked to separate the EU and NATO, because this is about EU accession and not NATO accession. Nevertheless, thank you for including many aspects on ecology. I hope we will have your support for two more amendments tomorrow on the protection of Lake Skadar and our concern about 80 hydropower power plants, which need to be constructed with environmental impact assessments.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, when it comes to texts on the process of accession of third countries to the European Union, your reports follow one another and are similar. In terms of diversity, you are constantly interfering in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, to standardize it under the aegis of this ideology. This report on Montenegro is no exception. It is funny that you denounce in this report, a so-called Russian interference in the electoral processes of Montenegro, whereas by the admission of the Montenegrin special prosecutor Milivoje Katnić, the intelligence services of the friendly countries in Europe - and in particular of the United States and Great Britain - aided Montenegro in the investigation of the alleged attempted coup by the opposition in the last legislative elections in October. To wonder if implicating Russia and surrounding it, via NATO, does not interest you, in reality, more than the democratic process in Montenegro. Finally, in view of the observations you make on the social, economic and political situation in this country, I really wonder how you can continue to ask for the acceleration of negotiations with a view to soon joining the Union. We can worry about the state of democracy in Montenegro when it is truly and fully respected in the Union.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like to welcome Montenegro's progress on the road to the European Union. The sign of this progress is very clear: 26 open negotiation chapters, 2 closed ones; another indicator is that the parliamentary elections that took place in October 2016 were successfully organized, which shows that democratic practices are beginning to take root. I also hope that this example will inspire other countries in the region, candidates or potential candidates. That being said, Montenegro still has a number of important steps to take. One of the most important is overcoming the culture of boycott and fierce opposition. Negotiation and compromise are as necessary ingredients as confrontation in a democracy. The fight against corruption and excessive politicization of public administration seems to me to be a priority. It is also important to strengthen the freedom of the press, because, unfortunately, it continues to lack the necessary independence. As far as we are concerned, I hope that we will be able to respond correctly to the progress and, in particular, to the expectations of the candidate and potential candidate countries in the region. I believe that we need more than ever to provide a reasonable time horizon for the date of accession to the European Union to each of the states interested in this in the Western Balkans. I think that promising them a bright, unclear future is not a solution, and these days I had many discussions with Mrs. Mogherini and Mr. Hahn on this topic. The Commission's strategy must change if we are not to lose these peoples of the Western Balkans, because the Russians and the Turks are there and they are very serious competitors. We have seen, moreover, how concerned are those who support Russia's interests here rather than European ones.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it was good to see EU leaders reaffirming their commitment to the Western Balkans during the last European Council. Ahead of the meeting, as we know, some EU leaders voiced concerns about external destabilising influences on the region, and these have been mentioned again tonight. I believe our response has to be ever more visible and strong engagement in the region to support those forces that fight for human rights and the rule of law.  The EU is a peace project, a project that aims to end frequent and bloody wars between neighbours, horrible experiences that the Western Balkans know only too well. The prospect of European integration for Montenegro and the Western Balkans is therefore essential for peace in the region and across Europe. As the Commissioner noted, Montenegro continues to demonstrate a strong commitment to EU integration. Its steady progress in opening chapters is not only bringing it closer to EU accession, but, as many others have said, is also providing a positive example for other countries in the region. My group tabled a number of amendments to the report, specifically focused on enhancing human rights. I am pleased that many of these are reflected in the report, covering topics from ensuring media freedom to improving working conditions for civil society, to better arrangements for victims of gender-based violence, to eliminating obstacles to health care, education, housing and employment for Roma people. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their very constructive collaboration during all stages of the report.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Montenegro’s steady path towards EU integration is most welcome. I particularly welcome the ongoing progress in judicial reform and the fight against corruption in this country. Furthermore, Montenegro’s aim to join NATO this year is a clear sign of its commitment towards our Euro-Atlantic Alliance. As NATO remains an important factor for peace and stability in the Western Balkans, this decision deserves our strong support. Notwithstanding the important progress, there also remain significant challenges ahead, as my colleague, Mr Preda, has just pointed out. I would also like to name just a few. These include the deeply polarised political climate, the politicisation of the public administration, undue external influence on the judiciary, corruption and the freedom of the media. I remain deeply concerned about alleged Russian attempts to influence development in this country, which could potentially destabilise the whole region. Therefore, I would like to join the call of High Representative Federica Mogherini to follow ongoing investigations into the alleged coup d’état attempt on 16 October last year, including, notably, the purported involvement of Russian intelligence. As the standing rapporteur for Serbia – and to close on a positive note – I would like to commend the state of Montenegrin—Serbian relations, which continue to be a source of stability for the region. If the two front runners in the Western Balkans, Serbia and Montenegro, stay on their respective European paths, we will be able to ensure long—term stability in the region. I would like to thank my distinguished colleague Charles Tannock for his good work.

name: Петър Курумбашев (S&D).
text: - You know how many threats the European Union is facing and I think the best response to these threats is the continued enlargement of the Union. I would like to pay special attention to the fact that the accession of Montenegro to the European Union will have an extremely favorable impact on its neighbors in the face of Albania and Serbia, as well as on Bulgaria's neighboring Macedonia. I also want to say that I hope that during the presidency of Bulgaria, which will be in a year's time, we will have more closed heads than open ones, and I also hope that there will be a very clear horizon and a specific time frame for the adoption. of Montenegro, because when we mention that no new countries will be admitted until 2020, we are not encouraging candidates for membership of the European Union. I would also like to express, after hearing the speeches of many of my colleagues, my assurance that Montenegro has many true and sincere friends in the European Parliament.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would firstly like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, for the excellent report he has presented to us and for the accurate analysis he makes, not only of the progress that Montenegro has made but also of the general context of the regional situation. The rapporteur tells us that the context is worrying and the European Council tells us, in its conclusions this weekend, that the situation is very fragile. That is why the rapporteur reminds us of what happened around the electoral process and what happened after the elections that have been held recently. I think it is a mistake, Madam President, the analysis made by some to consider Russia, a country that extends its borders from Alaska to Poland, as a regional actor. Russia is a global power that, by the way, challenges the West on almost every board and almost always with success. That is why I believe that the timely visit of the High Representative to the region and the treatment that this matter has had in the Council of Ministers and in the European Council should be underlined and given due importance. I believe that the recipes are very clear: we must continue with the reform process, we must give a perspective of regional action and there is also, Madam President, very clearly that place this problem - as I said at the beginning - in a regional context that it comes across as very disturbing. We already had precedents at the Vilnius Summit in November 2013. We saw what happened with the crisis in Ukraine, the destabilization and annexation of Crimea and everything that has happened since. I believe, Madam President, that this precedent is an example not to be followed and, therefore, we very warmly welcome this excellent report presented by Mr Tannock on the processes and progress that Montenegro has experienced.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Union's enlargement policy represents an investment in terms of peace, security and prosperity in Europe, providing economic and trade opportunities for the mutual benefit of the European Union and the countries aspiring to join it. However, it must be ensured that future Member States are well prepared and implement profound reforms in every area. Personally, I would like to mention transport and trans-European networks as a real junction with Europe. Important investments have been made and still need to be made for a true union, even physical, with the Western Balkans. Cross-border connections must be strengthened, customs procedures standardized and the results required by COP 21 shared. Furthermore, let's not forget the problem of road safety: in countries such as Montenegro the death rate from accidents is still high. I therefore hope that efforts will multiply in every sector, particularly in transport, also in view of the summit on the Western Balkans, which will be held in Trieste in July.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first, my highest appreciation goes to the rapporteur Charles Tannock for having shown once again his devotion to this file, which resulted in a very good, objective and balanced draft resolution. Looking back at the last 12 months, Montenegro remains clearly the frontrunner in the integration process in the region, which enjoys the continuous and high support of its citizens. For this, our partners in Montenegro deserve our further backing in keeping up the momentum and continuing with the reforms, notably in the domain of the rule of law, judiciary reform, the fight against corruption and organised crime, and improving the media environment. Yet these advances are overshadowed by the current boycott of the parliament which stalls the reform work. As the opposition is currently out of the parliament, I appreciate the prime minister’s gesture in extending a hand to the opposition, and hope that regular parliamentary work will resume soon. With regard to the events around the October 2016 elections, investigation needs to take place in accordance with Montenegrin law and international standards. The outstanding issues relating to the election should be addressed with a special focus on the OSCE Final Report recommendations which should act as a guideline.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating Rapporteur Tannock on a well-balanced report which clearly states that Montenegro has made excellent progress in its accession negotiations with the European Union. At the moment, Montenegro is the most advanced candidate country and shows sincere aspirations in joining the European Union. In addition to messages of support for the progress made so far, I would like to emphasize the importance of establishing an efficient and independent judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime as key reforms in meeting the criteria for membership. Further efforts are needed to address outstanding bilateral issues with neighboring countries. On this occasion, I would like to express my concern about the influence of third non-European countries on the internal political processes and foreign policy priorities in Montenegro and other countries in the region, which may further endanger the peace and stability of the Western Balkans. The European Union must engage more visibly in the Western Balkans in order to strengthen the aspirations of Montenegro, but also of other countries on their path to European integration. It is the only path to peace in the region, but also in Europe.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the situation in the Western Balkans is really worrying. I think we have a consensus on such an assessment. There are numerous tensions between the countries of the Western Balkans and within countries between different ethnic, religious and political communities. The external influences of Russia and Turkey are also strong, and the European Union is quite reserved. All this further complicates the already complex situation, which can escalate into conflicts. Montenegro has unequivocally expressed its intentions to integrate into Euro-Atlantic integration and has made significant progress. We know that a pro-European coalition with a narrow majority is in power. We know that most can easily come into question. We have also witnessed a coup attempt during the last parliamentary elections. The pro-Serbian opposition in Montenegro wants to prevent Montenegro's European path and that is why we should not be surprised by their boycott in the Parliament. We know that there are still some problems in Montenegro in the area of ​​justice, that corruption and crime are still a serious problem, and others mentioned in the report. But I wonder what our role is in the accession process? Can we be passive observers of the process? Can we be satisfied with the engagement so far ... (The end of the speech is not clear.)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! I consider it extremely flawed that the report ignores the multi-ethnic nature of Montenegro and its consequences, the need for equality between the different national and ethnic communities. Although the text mentions the preservation of the multi-ethnic identity of the Bay of Kotor in this regard, this call must be made for the whole country. In addition to the social inclusion of the Roma and Egyptian communities, the fundamental rights of the Serb, Albanian, Bosnian, Muslim and Croatian communities living in the country must also be taken into account. When we talk about the countries of the Western Balkans, we must not lose sight of the fact that state borders and ethnic and ethnic boundaries do not coincide, each state has a large number of minorities, so mutual reconciliation and tensions can only be reduced by respecting the rights of national minorities. In many cases, the closer a country is to joining the EU, the less weight these issues seem to be, and it is rude to talk to Member States. However, this is a denial of reality ... (The President cut off the Member)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, we welcome the negotiations between Montenegro and the European Union in order to implement Montenegro's accession to the Union. Greece supports the European perspective of Montenegro and already in 2011 signed a cooperation agreement to provide know-how on European Union issues. We welcome the steady progress of the accession negotiations with Montenegro, but corruption remains a serious problem, especially in the areas of public procurement, public health, education, spatial planning, privatization and construction. That is why we call on Montenegro to make the fight against corruption one of its priorities. Finally, we should note that the European course of Montenegro must include the solution of the problems that this country has with its neighboring countries, and this solution of the problems must be done in a constructive way and in a spirit of good neighborliness.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Montenegro is a good example in the Western Balkans.A good example when we talk about good neighborly cooperation with other countries, when we talk about minority rights because Croats, Bosniaks and Albanians are involved in the running of the state and in the processes in the state itself.A good example when we talk about overall regional stability, what it means, for example, the specific Adriatic Sea, what it means to have important relations, which are indicated here, relations with Serbia and, of course, far from that country has no problems, but the clear Euro-Atlantic aspiration that prevails in Montenegro today is a good indicator.That is why I call on the opposition to take part in these fateful moments for the future of this country, to take part in the work of Parliament, because the European Union will accept Montenegro.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, according to the indicators, Montenegro is obviously the most advanced candidate country for membership in the European Union. However, Montenegro, like other countries in the region when they joined, shows a lack of political will to implement EU public policy, especially in environmental protection and public health. And here I want to highlight three key, black spots that exist in Montenegro. This is Kombinat aluminij Podgorica with pools of red mud. We know how dangerous they are for the environment and currently threaten, if an ecological catastrophe occurs, Skadar Lake. We are talking about the Nikšić steel plant, which has been polluting the air of its citizens for decades. We are talking about the Plevlja coal-fired power plant, for which the Montenegrin government has no will to modernize and is still planning to build a new block.
