So, I call on the European Commission not only formally, but also financially, technically, to help the Montenegrin government because these same Montenegrin citizens will decide in a referendum tomorrow when they will join the European Union and must see the benefits of that membership.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you once again for this report and for tonight’s debate. As already noted, last week’s discussions in the Foreign Affairs Council, as well as the European Council, reconfirmed our commitment towards the Western Balkan region. While the EU is not alone in recognising the importance of the region, we are in a unique position to help address the challenges, and the European perspective is our best instrument for bringing stability and reform, regionally as well as in each of the countries. Montenegro has achieved a lot and now needs to find the political maturity to sustain the gains made and advance on the path towards accession. The latest opinion polls show, as a number of you have said, an overwhelming support for EU membership across party lines. Montenegro is firmly committed to its EU path and the EU remains equally dedicated to Montenegro’s future in the EU. However, as has been pointed out in the discussion and as is pointed out in the report, there is still more work ahead. Montenegro needs to stay focused on, among other things, rule of law, the fight against corruption and organised crime, freedom of the media and public administration reform. We support the calls for immediate follow-up to the OSCE/ODIHR recommendations and hope that all political actors can take part in this process. Calming down the political tensions, preserving the reform path and the creation of a tangible track record of rule of law will move Montenegro closer to the EU. To a considerable extent, the pace of progress is in Montenegro’s own hands, but we should continue to support and encourage them. Thank you for this evening’s debate.

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like first of all to thank colleagues for the very warm words they said about my report this evening. The debate has highlighted the continued interest that our Parliament has towards Montenegro and the wider Western Balkan region. Our Parliament remains engaged in the enlargement process generally and, by an overwhelming majority, supports the aims of the countries in the Western Balkans to all join the European Union. As a Member coming from a country, the United Kingdom, that has now chosen, regrettably, to leave the European Union, I am particularly keen to note that I believe that this was the wrong choice for Britain and that Montenegro should by no means see this as a reason to give up its bid for membership. As I noted earlier, EU membership can act as a vehicle for peace, security and prosperity in the Balkans, and these are values that encapsulate the entire purposes of EU membership.  All that remains for me to say now is that I hope tomorrow we will see the report adopted by a large majority, similar to the one we saw at the committee stage.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 16 March 2017.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next and last item on the agenda for today is the debate on the report by Ramón Jáuregui Atondo, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on digital democracy in the European Union: potential and challenges (2016/2008 (INI)) (A8-0041 /2017).

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report that we are going to discuss tonight, and vote tomorrow, tries to link communication technologies with democracy. It may seem like a strange equation, but it is not. The idea behind the report tries to establish the improvements that our democracy could acquire by virtue of communication technologies, understanding that our democracy, indeed, is suffering, in recent years in particular - I would say with the economic crisis more specifically -, a disaffection; I do not know if it is a discredit, but a certain distance of the citizens from the public institutions. This worries us, and the idea is to know if, indeed, the networks, the communication technologies, could help us to improve that relationship, understanding that this gap, that distance between citizens and politics has become increasingly greater, depending on the complexity of the issues that governance raises; by virtue of the economic crisis, which has transferred to certain economic institutions, outside of democracy itself, the ability to decide on the lives of the people; and, in general, due to the phenomena of political discredit that the parties and some representatives in some countries, by virtue of corruption, for example, have been generating. This state of things worries us and the reflection that brought us in return was the idea that it was necessary to take advantage of communication technologies to give meaning, I would not say new, but more positive to that relationship between citizenship and democracy. The balance of the report, logically, starts from considering that this is possible, that technologies are there to help us, not the opposite. And, in that sense, we highlight the importance that, for example, communication technologies could have, and already have in electronic governance, in relation to what is the relationship between citizen and public administration, when it comes to - let's put - establish their fiscal relationship, when accessing public services. There is an entire electronic governance that has to serve to improve that relationship. There is an opportunity for electronic participation to help citizens participate more in the deliberation of democratic processes, in the consultations that government officials can ask citizens about the impacts of certain measures, in e-voting —the possibility of voting online - in political parties and their relationship with their affiliates, with their supporters and with their citizens. Therefore, there is a positive approach to the idea that technologies can help us enrich democracy and bring it closer to citizens. But there is also a cautious look at these effects. It is not an alternative democracy, the report says. We cannot be so naive to believe that we are going to invent a new democracy on the basis of direct democracy, since technologies, although they facilitate this possibility, do not really substitute for the system of representative democracy. It is prudent, because the report warns that there are risks. There is risk in digital access to participation platforms, which have to be fair so that everyone can access; It is the risk of privacy, of ensuring the rights of individuals so that their rights are guaranteed. All this set of situations demands from us, therefore, a report that has been approved by the majority of the entire Chamber.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is another very important subject. On behalf of Vice—President Ansip, I would like to thank Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Jáuregui Atondo, for this report on the subject of e-Democracy. It concerns issues that are fundamental to how we evolve as democratic and innovative societies, and it recognises the strategic role that new digital technologies play in shaping public policy and public services. Vice-President Ansip has asked me to make a number of comments, so I hope you will bear with me. Citizens and businesses expect better services from public authorities, greater transparency and less administrative burden. Despite many EU projects over the years to develop concepts, tools and solutions for participatory democracy, the pace of modernisation is still too slow. We need to accelerate the transformation of government and improve people’s participation in decision-making processes. If we can use digital technology to support an increased public involvement, that is good for legitimacy, accountability and ultimately trust in government.  The new e-government Action Plan will contribute to this digital transformation. It is part of our broader vision for creating a digital single market. It aims to promote open and transparent government, as well as to improve the interaction of government and individual citizens. Governments and administrations need to be open, transparent and collaborative. This means open data, open services and open processes. ICT is a great tool to engage people, to improve transparency and to increase the accountability and relevance of public administration. That is why the Commission recognises the importance of e-Democracy and e-participation. It helps us to make sure our policies respond to individual and business needs and so increases trust in our political systems. The EU citizenship report 2017 underlined the Commission’s commitment to promoting best practices to help people vote and stand in EU elections. With European elections in 2019, the aim is to support turnout and broad democratic participation.  These best practices should also address e-Democracy, remote voting arrangements like e-voting, and cross-border access to political information. They will also focus on improving the low voter turnout. In its report, Parliament highlights the importance of all of this and calls for greater EU-wide cooperation, but we also need to recognise the challenges. Political parties and elections increasingly attract the attention of cyber criminals and other cyber activists. This risk to our democratic processes is, unfortunately, real and we need to take it very seriously. For the DSM to work, our digital networks have to be protected. That is why cyber security needs to be a top political priority for us all, and it certainly is for the Commission. E-Democracy also requires equal, open and neutral access to the internet. The Commission has always been committed to the internet as a single unfragmented space. Our approach continues to be one where the internet is anchored in the defence of human rights and democratic values, where the same rights that apply offline are also protected online. We also need to ensure that everyone can benefit from new opportunities that are presented by the new technologies. Recently the Web Accessibility Directive entered into force. This means making the internet accessible for everyone, including the elderly and people with disabilities. But to make the most of internet access and for people to engage digitally, we need wide availability and take-up of high-speed broadband connectivity. That is why the Commission has proposed connectivity targets for 2025. One of these is for all European households to have access to download speeds of at least 100 Mbps. In addition, given the investment challenge ahead, especially in less densely populated areas, EU cohesion policies complement private investment and support broadband deployment to the tune of some EUR 6 billion up to 2020, with a particular focus on under-served and rural areas.  For e-Democracy to be efficient and thrive, people must also have access to information as well as the necessary skills. At the same time, people who do not have the full means or skills to participate should not be excluded, which is an essential part of building trust. In its communication last year ‘A new skills agenda for Europe’, the Commission proposed a skills guarantee to help Europeans to get more access to basic literacy, numeracy and digital skills training. We also work with Member States under the Education and Training 2020 Initiative to bring more digital skills to students and into school and university curricula.  Lastly, let us remember the importance of media pluralism and freedom of expression, values that are enshrined in the Charter. They are the backbone of our democratic societies whether people are online or offline. Media literacy is a key factor for people to make the most of the unprecedented amount of data information and views that they can now access thanks to digital technologies.  So once again thank you to the rapporteur for raising these subjects in an interesting and important report, and thank you for the opportunity to discuss them so fully this evening.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the 5 Star Movement was born and developed through the Internet. We, spokesmen in the European Parliament, are living proof of this, because we are ordinary citizens who have come into contact on the Internet who have given birth to a new and revolutionary political community. The 5 Star Movement was born anticipating the future. We practice direct and e-democracy, allowing citizens to choose their representatives online and empowering citizens to choose and amend bills. We are convinced that only through a healthy use of the Internet can we revive this European democracy which today is increasingly hostage to lobbies and multinationals. This is one of our main battles: it is our mission. You have finally understood it too and this e-democracy report proves it. Finally, even here in Europe we are starting to talk about how to bring citizens closer to the institutions and how to reduce the so-called democratic deficit. The report presents several interesting passages: for example, when the European Parliament is invited to take a strong role in the implementation of e-democracy and to develop online platforms to put citizens in direct contact with the legislator. We of the 5 Star Movement already use our platform, which is called Rousseau, and we are very happy that the European Parliament also feels the need to use a similar tool. Or, again, when the Member States of the European Union are urged to provide dignified media literacy and eradicate the digital divide. Lastly, I am pleased that my suggestion to draw up a European Charter of Internet Rights has been accepted which formally establishes Internet access and net neutrality as fundamental rights. I therefore urge my colleagues to keep this up reference.Today we are writing a beautiful page of democracy: I cannot therefore be happy about this report, which represents a first important step in the accomplished realization of e-democracy also at the European level.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate my Socialist colleague on his report and, in particular, on his availability to work with the other political groups. I believe that indeed, we need broad agreement on this issue, because we have a large number of recommendations that are contained in the text, since online democracy concerns us all. It is indeed a question of reflecting together on how to integrate into our political life this inevitable development that constitutes information technologies, but it is not at all a question of replacing our good old representative democracy by e -democracy. That is a utopia, it is for revolutionaries and we are far from being revolutionaries, at least in my political group. The EPP group has also supported all the compromises drawn up within the AFCO committee, with the exception of the one relating to the development of a European charter of rights relating to the Internet, taking as a basis the declaration Italian from 2015. We are against that. I think we need careful thought and we have instruments to protect these rights with our current European framework for the protection of fundamental rights. Another issue I would like to mention is that of online voting. I am delighted that the references to this subject which now appear in the text are realistic and in line with what we already voted in November 2015, as part of the reform of European electoral law. In particular, I fully support the Estonian experience. I believe that we have lessons to learn from it and that we can eventually transfer this magnificent experience to other European companies. Of course, we need high standards in terms of data protection and additional principles of equality, freedom of suffrage and access to the vote.

name: Marju Lauristin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur and all the people who worked on this very important report. I would also like to thank the Commissioner, who gave a very concise overview of the technological conditions. Without those, we cannot have any kind of new developments in democracy.  I am also glad that we are now speaking, not only about the digital single market, but also about digital Europe, digital society and digital democracy. Coming from Estonia, which has already been mentioned as a laboratory of e-Democracy, I have to say that our experience shows not only how far we are already capable of going, but also how technology itself does not really give us better democracy when we do not complement that with a proper education. It is not only digital skills in the narrow sense: what I really want to stress is that we need to think about what it will mean to have civic education, not only for young people and children, but also for older people so that they will not only be capable of using technological devices, but will be capable of using all the information which is available in this digital world. For example, our experience with digital voting or e—Elections shows that new quality comes only when parties provide new digital content. Instead of a kind of commercial approach to elections, there should be an information- and knowledge—based approach, so that voters not only vote digitally but also have basic information and analytical information. However, to do that they also need analytical skills. Young people are really no longer interested in traditional forms of democracy. They are interested in democracy, but in the e-Environment. They can also use totally different methods, so I suppose that we have to think much more about education, not only digital, but education in general in the digital world.

name: Yana Toom
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first let me say that I largely agree with the rapporteur and Commissioner Ansip that remote internet voting systems can widen citizens’ inclusion and facilitate democratic participation, especially when people are geographically and socially marginalised. Estonia introduced online voting as early as the 2005 election, and my country is often cited as a positive example, as we have just heard now, and also in this report. Indeed, these days Estonia is the only EU country where you can choose to vote online rather than go to a traditional polling station to vote on paper. Online voting is available during the advance voting period. In the 2014 European elections, every third Estonian voter used this opportunity. It should be stressed that in Estonia there is no unanimous support for i-voting. International IT experts have presented proof to the public that our most advanced and internationally praised Estonian system is vulnerable to service side and client side attacks. We are improving this at the moment. Today, e-Democracy offers us plenty of opportunities and we cannot imagine contemporary life without IT. Regretfully, we also cannot imagine our lives without cyber—attacks and internet fraud. Democracy is a keystone of European identity and European values. The results of electoral procedures cannot be suspect, unclear or questionable. In several European countries, e-Vote and i-Vote are still not in use because of security considerations. Why? So far we do not have all the necessary data to use technical solutions to organise i-Vote in a safe and reliable manner. We first need to solve all technical and security problems, and only then will we call on Member States to implement i-Vote in practice.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur with whom the dialogue has been really fruitful. I also think that e-democracy is an instrument that can strengthen citizen participation and prevent the oligarchic risks of democracy. I am less convinced by the analysis that is made of the disaffection of citizens: I do not think it is apathy, as it is written in the report, because there is a lot of passion in today's waste. In them there is a demand for change to listen to. E-democracy has proven to work: the rewriting of the Icelandic Constitution was partly done with citizens, online. At the same time, I invite you to be careful in building this tool which adds to the perilous representative democracy. E-democracy is not synonymous with e-government, I would not want it to be adopted, lowering it from above, in order to better disseminate government opinions and sell them, giving life to a democracy that is even more protective than the one we already know. I believe that this report avoids this obstacle and is very positive, because it contains important and valuable elements, not least the proposal for the drafting of a European Charter of Internet Rights on the model of the one adopted by the Italian Parliament in 2015.

name: Max Andersson
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Tonight we are discussing the report on e-democracy, an excellent report which I hope will be approved. It contains many good things about e-administration and open source code and e-counseling - on the whole excellent. However, there is an opportunity to make it even better by also approving the Greens' demand for lobby control. Feel free to approve it. However, there is one weakness with this report, namely that it may be a little too positive for e-voting. It was even more positive at the draft level, but we have managed to get compromises that calm down the e-voting enthusiasts and hopefully make them realize that if you use e-voting, you must have data security so that the voting secret is kept. You must also make sure that you can trust the result of the vote. In today's system, it's terribly, terribly difficult. Therefore, we must be very careful with e-voting. E-government and e-democracy are extremely important. E-voting, I think we can do without. Approve this excellent report.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE).
text: – Madam President, my congratulations to Mr Jáuregui on an excellent report. There is no question in my mind that e-democracy is already happening and will assume ever greater importance in the years to come. Various aspects of governance are already structured electronically, so this report is not only timely, but is equally highly cogent. There is an ideal typical model of e—democracy, something along the lines of each and every citizen participating in political decision-making thanks to their computer or smartphone This sounds a little bit like a futuristic version of the classical Athenian agora. Reality will be different; it usually is.  In the first place, not everyone has easy and inexpensive access to the cyber world; there are cost factors that have to be taken into account. Second, there are cognitive impediments. Some citizens will simply find it difficult to follow the protocols. Whether we like it or not, cyber literacy is not universal. Equally, the enabling software has to be designed with special care. My own recent experience illustrates this, when I was trying to complete the Hungarian interim census form and failing so that I had to deal with a human enumerator.  Finally, cyber security. The provision of this is a constant struggle, but the technological leap that quantum technology promises in ensuring complete security is not that far away. The EU has to be on top of this, and this report usefully points the way.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Jáuregui.Democracy: The Unfinished Journey — democracy, an unfinished journey — is the title of a classic that assesses how democracy has changed throughout history.In the last quarter of a century the debate has revolved around the quality of democracy: how to overcome delegative democracy;how to allow citizens to participate in the decision-making process;how to organize that they can take them directly online;how to allow public agoras, deliberative public squares.The report has multiple proposals in this regard, but it also draws attention to the need to guarantee privacy, rights and security on the internet.Finally, as another classic of democracy said, what has survived is the building of representative democracy.This serves to perfect it, not to replace it.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the models of functioning of democratic societies are being strongly reconfigured by the adoption of new information and communication technologies. This report is therefore very timely. I greet rapporteur Ramón Jáuregui, for his concise, pragmatic and structured way in which he identifies the potential and challenges of electronic democracy. Technological acceleration cannot undermine the fundamental values ​​of representative democracy. On the contrary, technology must be used to strengthen it. I would like to highlight three dimensions, as long as I can, that are fundamental: the qualification of citizens for the digital society, transparency and equity in access to relevant information and, finally, the possibility of disseminating the possibility of live electronic voting. There are three opportunities and three lines of work so that we can take advantage of technology to strengthen democracy. Thank you very much for the excellent report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there can be no e-democracy without digital inclusion, especially inclusion of vulnerable people. This requires ensuring a fair, inclusive, transparent and safe access, and use of the internet for all. Digital inclusion also means closing the gap between rural and urban areas in terms of internet access. There is indeed significant contrast in broadband speeds in rural and urban areas in many Member States, and this presents a severe disadvantage to rural areas and puts at risk the social, cultural and economic life in the communities there.  We are also asked to prepare young people to a fast-changing world which we cannot yet imagine, but one thing we know is that this world will be more and more digitised and connected, and that is why digital skills and media literacy are key. But here, again, it should not limit itself to learning about the tools and technologies; it should aim at equipping individuals with the creative and critical thinking and digital curiosity necessary for them to become not only users of technology, but active citizens in connected societies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, as the report states, citizens must be informed by the media, among other things, about the activity of their elected representatives in the national parliaments and in the European Parliament. This is especially true in Greece, where the state media and the majority of private media have for the past two and a half years been systematically silencing me as an MEP, member of the ECR, the third strongest political group in the European Parliament. Even today, a few hours ago, the state television ERT1, in fact using the studio and television equipment of the European Parliament here in Strasbourg, just outside this room, once again arbitrarily excluded me from its special program on activities. of the European Parliament. What steps do you intend to take, Madam President, as a Member of the European Parliament and you, Commissioner, to ensure the free circulation of ideas, equality, impartiality, pluralism in the Greek media, at a time when many of them, Madam Mr President, they are using the equipment of the European Parliament here in Strasbourg and several of the journalists in these media are visiting Strasbourg at his own expense ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: One thing is absolutely certain, namely that we clearly accept freedom of expression in our states, and not only accept it, but respect it.That is a great good that we cannot question under any circumstances.I do not accept such allegations as they have just been made.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, it took a long time for democracy to mature and we cannot expect e-democracy to replace the current system overnight and it is not wise to immediately attack e-voting, ie the highest level of decision-making in the current democracy as a replacement for the existing voting system.I will only cite two examples where e-democracy could achieve much greater effects.So first is the smart city.We have a concept in which citizens can, through greater participation at the local level, participate more in deciding what will be invested in their environment, how the city will actually be managed and how traffic will be managed in the city to preserve public health and the environment.Secondly important are people with special needs or reduced mobility.E-democracy enables them to better and more easily participate in democratic decision-making at their local, regional or national level.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as this important report underlines, e-democracy is about grasping the potential of the internet to strengthen democracy in a digital environment. It is about empowering people and developing a digital public sphere.  In the Commission, we are trying to do our bit. We are promoting the use of online participatory platforms, for example the European Citizens’ Initiative, which allows direct participation in the development of EU policies. The REFIT exercise and the e-Government Action Plan have created participatory platforms that engage European citizens directly in the decision-making process. Projects such as D-CENT demonstrate clearly that citizen-led organisations can transform democracy and help them to develop the next generation of open source, distributed, privacy-aware tools. The Commission is looking at a pilot project, funded by the European Parliament, on making the best use of modern technologies for more active and democratic voting procedures.  But, as I think we have recognised in this discussion, for all of this to work you need digital skills and digital inclusion. In fact, if Mr Schöpflin had still been here, I would have been tempted to say that cyber-literacy could be a barrier to turkeys voting for Christmas. One of the main challenges we face, therefore, is to bridge the digital divide that exists in some of our societies. That is going to require decisive action nationally and regionally as well as at the EU level in order to build the engagement and trust that is needed to underpin and reinforce our democracy. Thank you, again, to the rapporteur for giving us this opportunity this evening to discuss this very important subject.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: speaker. - Madam president. Thank you, Commissioner, because I am grateful that the Commission embraces this idea from Parliament and that it develops its initiatives. I want to reassure my colleagues, colleagues, who have expressed some concerns. Most of them are included in the report; also some suggestions, they are almost all. I think we have made a very balanced balance between what are - let's say - advantages, opportunities and risks. In relation to e-voting, for example, we appreciate what the Estonian experience means, but today we recognize that the Netherlands has not wanted to apply electronic counting for fear of cyberattacks. So there is a fairly reasonable balance between what technology eventually provides for democracy. I just want to thank, Madam President, all the shadow rapporteurs and all the political groups for their support. We have reached a very majority agreement and which tomorrow will - I hope - be approved by this Parliament with very strong support.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 16 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The colleague's report is very good and addresses the issue of e-democracy without prejudice."Electronic democracy" is presented as a useful tool to enrich and strengthen direct democracy and electronic voting as a useful practice if well thought out.However, the elimination of the digital divide must be guaranteed and access to the network must be made effective.At the same time, the network itself must be clearly regulated and we have noted with pleasure the reference to the Charter of Internet Rights drawn up at Italian level as a useful tool for this purpose.It is also essential to reinvigorate and implement the first direct democracy instrument devised at EU level: the European citizens' initiative.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. - In the European Union, political elites are distant, self-referential, unable to provide effective responses to citizens. E-democracy, on the other hand, could first of all promote and ensure greater information and transparency, but also increase the reliability, sense of responsibility, accessibility and participation of citizens, becoming an effective tool for social cohesion. Citizen involvement can take place through governance, deliberation, participation, consultation and digital voting tools, with inclusive systems capable of having effects in terms of direct democracy, but also of growth of human capital and the economy, as well as the efficiency of the public administration. All this is possible only on condition that greater efforts are made than those so far deployed, in particular as regards the connectivity of all the territories of the Union, even rural or sparsely populated ones, and for the digital literacy of all citizens. , also promoting the use of free and open source software. Finally, some significant challenges are represented by the maintenance of net neutrality and the guarantee of the all-round security of the infrastructures and the Internet, preventing it from becoming an instrument of intrusion and violation of privacy.

name: Ева Майдел (PPE)
text: In written form. - Just a few weeks ago, Mr Juncker launched one of the biggest debates in the history of the EU - the debate on the future of Europe. The scenarios he offers are extremely different, and it is really important for every European to make sense of them in order to choose how we want our continent to develop. When we talk about Digital Europe, however, I see only one path before us, and that is the way to unify the regulatory framework, to make the most of the development of the digital economy and to enforce the free movement of data in Europe. In order to complete this technological reality, it is necessary for our societies to be renewed to the latest version. In addition to being technologically literate, it is crucial that democracy in Europe evolves through e-government, e-participation and e-voting. E-democracy means strengthening traditional democratic practices and increased transparency of governance processes. I am glad that the DESI index took into account the achievements of the Bulgarian government of Boyko Borissov in the field of e-government and open data and that in the elections for the European Parliament in 2019 as a Bulgarian I will be able to cast my vote technologically neutral via smartphone, tablet or computer. , both from Bulgaria and from Brussels.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - The development of new information and communication technologies (ICT) causes profound changes in modern society. We are currently dealing with a huge technological revolution, the main factor of which is the Internet and related social interactions. Therefore, it was necessary to use digital communication tools to create a new way of discussion and social participation in public matters. This project aims to strengthen the relationship between citizens and public institutions by facilitating the use of online tools. Due to the rather unfavorable image of public administration bodies among citizens, certain facilitations are introduced, which we can already observe today. Currently, most official matters can be dealt with without leaving home, and thanks to the unlimited possibilities of the Internet, we can enrich civic awareness. That is why I believe that the resolution presented has enormous potential to make positive use of the aspects and possibilities of the Internet. Thanks to these tools, we can facilitate the everyday life of citizens and create their awareness and real influence on the political life of each of us.
